	<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Buddhism</h1>
	
	<div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content">
		<div id="siteSub" class="noprint">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
		<div id="contentSub"></div>
		
		
		
		<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
		<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
		<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#p-search">Jump to search</a>
		<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">"Buddhadharma" redirects here. For the magazine, see <a href="/wiki/Buddhadharma:_The_Practitioner%27s_Quarterly" title="Buddhadharma: The Practitioner&#39;s Quarterly">Buddhadharma: The Practitioner's Quarterly</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">World religion, founded by the Buddha</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">

</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gandhara_Buddha_(tnm).jpeg" class="image"><img alt="standing Buddha statue with draped garmet and halo" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Gandhara_Buddha_%28tnm%29.jpeg/220px-Gandhara_Buddha_%28tnm%29.jpeg" decoding="async" width="220" height="365" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Gandhara_Buddha_%28tnm%29.jpeg/330px-Gandhara_Buddha_%28tnm%29.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Gandhara_Buddha_%28tnm%29.jpeg/440px-Gandhara_Buddha_%28tnm%29.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="1746" data-file-height="2894" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Gandhara_Buddha_(tnm).jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Standing_Buddha" title="Standing Buddha">Standing Buddha</a> statue at the <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_National_Museum" title="Tokyo National Museum">Tokyo National Museum</a>. One of the earliest known representations of the <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Buddha</a>, 1st–2nd century CE.</div></div></div>

<p><b>Buddhism</b> (<span class="nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="&#39;b&#39; in &#39;buy&#39;">b</span><span title="/ʊ/: &#39;u&#39; in &#39;push&#39;">ʊ</span><span title="&#39;d&#39; in &#39;dye&#39;">d</span><span title="/ɪ/: &#39;i&#39; in &#39;kit&#39;">ɪ</span><span title="&#39;z&#39; in &#39;zoom&#39;">z</span><span title="/əm/: &#39;m&#39; in &#39;rhythm&#39;">əm</span></span>/</a></span></span>, <span class="nowrap"><small><a href="/wiki/American_English" title="American English">US</a>: </small><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="&#39;b&#39; in &#39;buy&#39;">b</span><span title="/uː/: &#39;oo&#39; in &#39;goose&#39;">uː</span><span title="&#39;d&#39; in &#39;dye&#39;">d</span></span>-/</a></span></span>)<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWells2008_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWells2008-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoach2011_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoach2011-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> is the <a href="/wiki/Major_religious_groups#Largest_religions" title="Major religious groups">world's fourth-largest</a> <a href="/wiki/Religion" title="Religion">religion</a><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELopez2001239_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELopez2001239-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup> with over 520 million followers, or over 7% of the global population, known as <b>Buddhists</b>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-5">&#91;web 1&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-gordonconwell.edu_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gordonconwell.edu-6">&#91;5&#93;</a></sup>
Buddhism encompasses a variety of <a href="/wiki/Tradition" title="Tradition">traditions</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belief" title="Belief">beliefs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spiritual_practice" title="Spiritual practice">spiritual practices</a> largely based on <a href="/wiki/Original_Teachings_of_the_Buddha" class="mw-redirect" title="Original Teachings of the Buddha">original teachings</a> attributed to <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">the Buddha</a> and resulting <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_philosophy" title="Buddhist philosophy">interpreted philosophies</a>. Buddhism originated in <a href="/wiki/Ancient_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Ancient India">ancient India</a> as a <a href="/wiki/Sramana" class="mw-redirect" title="Sramana">Sramana</a> tradition sometime between the 6th and 4th centuries BCE, spreading through much of <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>. Two major extant branches of Buddhism are generally recognised by scholars: <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada</a> (<a href="/wiki/Pali" title="Pali">Pali</a>: "The School of the Elders") and <a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahayana</a> (<a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>: "The Great Vehicle").
</p><p>Most Buddhist traditions share the goal of overcoming <a href="/wiki/Dukkha" title="Dukkha">suffering</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83s%C4%81ra_(Buddhism)" title="Saṃsāra (Buddhism)">cycle of death and rebirth</a>, either by the attainment of <a href="/wiki/Nirvana_(Buddhism)" title="Nirvana (Buddhism)">Nirvana</a> or through the <a href="/wiki/Bodhisattva" title="Bodhisattva">path of Buddhahood</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199827–28,_73–74_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199827–28,_73–74-7">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201399_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201399-8">&#91;7&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Schools_of_Buddhism" title="Schools of Buddhism">Buddhist schools</a> vary in their interpretation of the <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_paths_to_liberation" title="Buddhist paths to liberation">path to liberation</a>, the relative importance and canonicity assigned to the various <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_texts" title="Buddhist texts">Buddhist texts</a>, and their specific teachings and practices.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams1989275ff_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams1989275ff-10">&#91;9&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobinson1997xx_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobinson1997xx-11">&#91;10&#93;</a></sup> Widely observed practices include taking <a href="/wiki/Refuge_(Buddhism)" title="Refuge (Buddhism)">refuge</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Buddha</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Dharma#Buddhism" title="Dharma">Dharma</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sangha" title="Sangha">Sangha</a>, observance of <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_ethics" title="Buddhist ethics">moral precepts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_monasticism" title="Buddhist monasticism">monasticism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_meditation" title="Buddhist meditation">meditation</a>, and the cultivation of the <a href="/wiki/Paramitas" class="mw-redirect" title="Paramitas">Paramitas</a> (virtues).
</p><p>Theravada Buddhism has a widespread following in <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Sri_Lanka" title="Buddhism in Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a> and <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Southeast_Asia" title="Buddhism in Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a>. Mahayana, which includes the traditions of <a href="/wiki/Pure_Land_Buddhism" title="Pure Land Buddhism">Pure Land</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zen" title="Zen">Zen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nichiren_Buddhism" title="Nichiren Buddhism">Nichiren Buddhism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shingon_Buddhism" title="Shingon Buddhism">Shingon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tiantai" title="Tiantai">Tiantai</a> (<a href="/wiki/Tendai" title="Tendai">Tendai</a>), is found throughout <a href="/wiki/East_Asian_Buddhism" title="East Asian Buddhism">East Asia</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Vajrayana" title="Vajrayana">Vajrayana</a>, a body of teachings attributed to <a href="/wiki/Mahasiddha" title="Mahasiddha">Indian adepts</a>, may be viewed as a separate branch or as an aspect of Mahayana Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-White_2000_21_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-White_2000_21-12">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism" title="Tibetan Buddhism">Tibetan Buddhism</a>, which preserves the Vajrayana teachings of eighth-century India, is practised in the countries of the <a href="/wiki/Himalayas" title="Himalayas">Himalayan region</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Mongolia" title="Buddhism in Mongolia">Mongolia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Kalmykia" title="Kalmykia">Kalmykia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-3"><div id="toc" class="toc"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2>Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Life_of_the_Buddha">Life of the Buddha</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Buddha_in_Sarnath_Museum_(Dhammajak_Mutra).jpg" class="image"><img alt="Buddha in Sarnath Museum (Dhammajak Mutra).jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Buddha_in_Sarnath_Museum_%28Dhammajak_Mutra%29.jpg/220px-Buddha_in_Sarnath_Museum_%28Dhammajak_Mutra%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="282" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Buddha_in_Sarnath_Museum_%28Dhammajak_Mutra%29.jpg/330px-Buddha_in_Sarnath_Museum_%28Dhammajak_Mutra%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Buddha_in_Sarnath_Museum_%28Dhammajak_Mutra%29.jpg/440px-Buddha_in_Sarnath_Museum_%28Dhammajak_Mutra%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1188" data-file-height="1521" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Buddha_in_Sarnath_Museum_(Dhammajak_Mutra).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Buddha in Sarnath Museum (Dhammajak Mutra)</div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Gautama Buddha</a></div>
<p>Buddhism is an <a href="/wiki/Indian_religion" class="mw-redirect" title="Indian religion">Indian religion</a><sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> attributed to the teachings of the Buddha,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin19987–8_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin19987–8-16">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst2013ix–xi_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst2013ix–xi-17">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup> supposedly born Siddhārtha Gautama, and also known as the <i>Tathāgata</i> ("thus-gone") and <i>Sakyamuni</i> ("sage of the Sakyas"). Early texts have his personal name as "Gautama" or "Gotama" (Pali) without any mention of "Siddhārtha," ("Achieved the Goal") which appears to have been a kind of honorific title when it does appear. The details of Buddha's life are mentioned in many <a href="/wiki/Early_Buddhist_Texts" title="Early Buddhist Texts">Early Buddhist Texts</a> but are inconsistent, and his social background and life details are difficult to prove, the precise dates uncertain.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199813–14_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199813–14-18">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;note 1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The evidence of the early texts suggests that he was born as <a href="/wiki/Siddh%C4%81rtha_Gautama" class="mw-redirect" title="Siddhārtha Gautama">Siddhārtha Gautama</a> in <a href="/wiki/Lumbini" title="Lumbini">Lumbini</a> and grew up in Kapilavasthu,<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;note 2&#93;</a></sup> a town in the plains region of the modern Nepal–India border, and that he spent his life in what is now modern <a href="/wiki/Bihar" title="Bihar">Bihar</a><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">&#91;note 3&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh" title="Uttar Pradesh">Uttar Pradesh</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198849_28-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198849-28">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199813–14_18-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199813–14-18">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> Some hagiographic legends state that his father was a king named Suddhodana, his mother was Queen Maya, and he was born in Lumbini gardens.<sup id="cite_ref-Thomas2013p16_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thomas2013p16-30">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup> However, scholars such as Richard Gombrich consider this a dubious claim because a combination of evidence suggests he was born in the <i>Shakyas</i> community – one that later gave him the title <i>Shakyamuni</i>, and the <i>Shakya</i> community was governed by a small oligarchy or republic-like council where there were no ranks but where seniority mattered instead.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198849–50_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198849–50-31">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">&#91;note 4&#93;</a></sup> Some of the stories about Buddha, his life, his teachings, and claims about the society he grew up in may have been invented and interpolated at a later time into the Buddhist texts.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198818–19,_50–51_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198818–19,_50–51-35">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Le_grand_d%C3%A9part.jpg" class="image"><img alt="stone relief sculpture of horse and men" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Le_grand_d%C3%A9part.jpg/220px-Le_grand_d%C3%A9part.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Le_grand_d%C3%A9part.jpg/330px-Le_grand_d%C3%A9part.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Le_grand_d%C3%A9part.jpg/440px-Le_grand_d%C3%A9part.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4962" data-file-height="3308" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Le_grand_d%C3%A9part.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>"The Great Departure", relic depicting Gautama leaving home, first or second century (<a href="/wiki/Guimet_Museum" title="Guimet Museum">Musée Guimet</a>)</div></div></div>
<p>According to the Buddhist sutras, Gautama was moved by the innate suffering of humanity and its <a href="/wiki/Samsara" class="mw-redirect" title="Samsara">endless repetition</a> due to rebirth. He set out on a quest to end this repeated suffering. Early Buddhist canonical texts and early biographies of Gautama state that Gautama first studied under <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedic</a> teachers, namely Alara Kalama (Sanskrit: Arada Kalama) and Uddaka Ramaputta (Sanskrit: Udraka Ramaputra), learning meditation and ancient philosophies, particularly the concept of "nothingness, emptiness" from the former, and "what is neither seen nor unseen" from the latter.<sup id="cite_ref-Wynne2007p8_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wynne2007p8-37">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">&#91;note 5&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%87%E0%B8%9A%E0%B8%B3%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%9E%E0%B9%87%E0%B8%8D%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%B8%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%B2_%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B0%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%A8%E0%B9%84%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%A2.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%87%E0%B8%9A%E0%B8%B3%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%9E%E0%B9%87%E0%B8%8D%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%B8%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%B2_%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B0%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%A8%E0%B9%84%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%A2.png/220px-%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%87%E0%B8%9A%E0%B8%B3%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%9E%E0%B9%87%E0%B8%8D%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%B8%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%B2_%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B0%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%A8%E0%B9%84%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%A2.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%87%E0%B8%9A%E0%B8%B3%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%9E%E0%B9%87%E0%B8%8D%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%B8%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%B2_%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B0%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%A8%E0%B9%84%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%A2.png/330px-%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%87%E0%B8%9A%E0%B8%B3%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%9E%E0%B9%87%E0%B8%8D%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%B8%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%B2_%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B0%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%A8%E0%B9%84%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%A2.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%87%E0%B8%9A%E0%B8%B3%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%9E%E0%B9%87%E0%B8%8D%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%B8%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%B2_%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B0%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%A8%E0%B9%84%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%A2.png/440px-%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%87%E0%B8%9A%E0%B8%B3%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%9E%E0%B9%87%E0%B8%8D%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%B8%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%B2_%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B0%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%A8%E0%B9%84%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%A2.png 2x" data-file-width="2560" data-file-height="1440" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%87%E0%B8%9A%E0%B8%B3%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%9E%E0%B9%87%E0%B8%8D%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%B8%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%B2_%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B0%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%A8%E0%B9%84%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%A2.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The gilded "Emaciated Buddha statue" in an <a href="/wiki/Ubosoth" class="mw-redirect" title="Ubosoth">Ubosoth</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bangkok" title="Bangkok">Bangkok</a> representing the stage of his <a href="/wiki/Asceticism" title="Asceticism">asceticism</a></div></div></div>
<p>Finding these teachings to be insufficient to attain his goal, he turned to the practice of <a href="/wiki/Asceticism" title="Asceticism">asceticism</a>. This too fell short of attaining his goal, and then he turned to the practice of <i>dhyana</i>, meditation. He famously sat in <a href="/wiki/Meditation" title="Meditation">meditation</a> under a <i><a href="/wiki/Ficus_religiosa" title="Ficus religiosa">Ficus religiosa</a></i> tree now called the <a href="/wiki/Bodhi_Tree" title="Bodhi Tree">Bodhi Tree</a> in the town of <a href="/wiki/Bodh_Gaya" title="Bodh Gaya">Bodh Gaya</a> in the Gangetic plains region of South Asia. He gained insight into the workings of karma and his former lives, and attained <a href="/wiki/Bodhi" class="mw-redirect" title="Bodhi">enlightenment</a>, certainty about the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Way" title="Middle Way">Middle Way</a> (Skt. <i>madhyamā-pratipad</i>)<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKohn1991143_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKohn1991143-42">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup> as the right path of spiritual practice to end suffering (<i><a href="/wiki/Dukkha" title="Dukkha">dukkha</a></i>) from rebirths in <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83s%C4%81ra" title="Saṃsāra">Saṃsāra</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup>
As a <a href="/wiki/Buddhahood#Samyaksambuddha" title="Buddhahood">fully enlightened Buddha</a> (Skt. <i><i lang="sa-Latn" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration">samyaksaṃbuddha</i></i>), he attracted followers and founded a <i><a href="/wiki/Sangha_(Buddhism)" class="mw-redirect" title="Sangha (Buddhism)">Sangha</a></i> (monastic order).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198849–51_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198849–51-44">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup> Now, as the Buddha, he spent the rest of his life teaching the <a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">Dharma</a> he had discovered, and <a href="/wiki/Parinirvana" title="Parinirvana">died</a> at the age of 80 in <a href="/wiki/Kushinagar" title="Kushinagar">Kushinagar</a>, India.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown2003267_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown2003267-45">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2010105–106_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2010105–106-21">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Buddha's teachings were propagated by his followers, which in the last centuries of the 1st millennium BCE became over 18 Buddhist sub-schools of thought, each with its own <a href="/wiki/Tripi%E1%B9%ADaka" title="Tripiṭaka">basket of texts</a> containing different interpretations and authentic teachings of the Buddha;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199854–55_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199854–55-46">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-britannicatipitaka_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannicatipitaka-48">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup> these over time evolved into many traditions of which the more well known and widespread in the modern era are <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahayana</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vajrayana" title="Vajrayana">Vajrayana</a> Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin19981–5_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin19981–5-50">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">&#91;note 6&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="The_problems_of_life:_dukkha_and_sa.E1.B9.83s.C4.81ra"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="The_problems_of_life:_dukkha_and_saṃsāra">The problems of life: <i>dukkha</i> and <i>saṃsāra</i></span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_Buddhism" title="Glossary of Buddhism">Glossary of Buddhism</a></div>
<h3><span id="Four_Noble_Truths_.E2.80.93_dukkha_and_its_ending"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Four_Noble_Truths_–_dukkha_and_its_ending">Four Noble Truths – <i>dukkha</i> and its ending</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Dukkha" title="Dukkha">Dukkha</a> and <a href="/wiki/Four_Noble_Truths" title="Four Noble Truths">Four Noble Truths</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Astasahasrika_Prajnaparamita_Dharmacakra_Discourse.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="color manuscript illustration of Buddha teaching the Four Noble Truths, Nalanda, Bihar, India" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Astasahasrika_Prajnaparamita_Dharmacakra_Discourse.jpeg/220px-Astasahasrika_Prajnaparamita_Dharmacakra_Discourse.jpeg" decoding="async" width="220" height="137" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Astasahasrika_Prajnaparamita_Dharmacakra_Discourse.jpeg/330px-Astasahasrika_Prajnaparamita_Dharmacakra_Discourse.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Astasahasrika_Prajnaparamita_Dharmacakra_Discourse.jpeg/440px-Astasahasrika_Prajnaparamita_Dharmacakra_Discourse.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="456" data-file-height="283" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Astasahasrika_Prajnaparamita_Dharmacakra_Discourse.jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Buddha teaching the Four Noble Truths. <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> manuscript. <a href="/wiki/Nalanda" title="Nalanda">Nalanda</a>, Bihar, India.</div></div></div>
<p>The Four Truths express the basic orientation of Buddhism: we <a href="/wiki/Up%C4%81d%C4%81na" title="Upādāna">crave and cling</a> to <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%85kh%C4%81ra#Conditioned_things" title="Saṅkhāra">impermanent states and things</a>, which is dukkha, "incapable of satisfying" and painful.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENyanatiloka198065_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENyanatiloka198065-54">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201530_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201530-55">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup> This keeps us caught in <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83s%C4%81ra_(Buddhism)" title="Saṃsāra (Buddhism)">saṃsāra</a>, the endless cycle of repeated <a href="/wiki/Rebirth_(Buddhism)" title="Rebirth (Buddhism)">rebirth</a>, dukkha and dying again.<sup id="cite_ref-Samsara_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Samsara-61">&#91;note 7&#93;</a></sup>
But there is a way to <a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">liberation</a> from this endless cycle<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarder200045–46_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarder200045–46-62">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup> to the state of <a href="/wiki/Nirvana" title="Nirvana">nirvana</a>, namely following the <a href="/wiki/Noble_Eightfold_Path" title="Noble Eightfold Path">Noble Eightfold Path</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Moksha_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Moksha-77">&#91;note 8&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The truth of <i><a href="/wiki/Dukkha" title="Dukkha">dukkha</a></i> is the basic insight that life in this mundane world, with its clinging and craving to <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%85kh%C4%81ra#Conditioned_things" title="Saṅkhāra">impermanent states and things</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENyanatiloka198065_54-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENyanatiloka198065-54">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup> is <i>dukkha</i>, and unsatisfactory.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200274–75_56-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200274–75-56">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELopez2009147_68-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELopez2009147-68">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-EB-DL_Four_Truths_70-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB-DL_Four_Truths-70">&#91;web 2&#93;</a></sup> <i>Dukkha</i> can be translated as "incapable of satisfying,"<sup id="cite_ref-Sumedho-first_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sumedho-first-78">&#91;web 6&#93;</a></sup> "the unsatisfactory nature and the general insecurity of all <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%85kh%C4%81ra#Conditioned_things" title="Saṅkhāra">conditioned phenomena</a>"; or "painful."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENyanatiloka198065_54-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENyanatiloka198065-54">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201530_55-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201530-55">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup> <i>Dukkha</i> is most commonly translated as "suffering," but this is inaccurate, since it refers not to episodic suffering, but to the intrinsically unsatisfactory nature of temporary states and things, including pleasant but temporary experiences.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">&#91;note 9&#93;</a></sup> We expect happiness from states and things which are impermanent, and therefore cannot attain real happiness.
</p><p>In Buddhism, dukkha is one of the <a href="/wiki/Three_marks_of_existence" title="Three marks of existence">three marks of existence</a>, along with <a href="/wiki/Impermanence" title="Impermanence">impermanence</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anatt%C4%81" class="mw-redirect" title="Anattā">anattā</a> (non-self).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich200647,_Quote:_&quot;All_phenomenal_existence_&#91;in_Buddhism&#93;_is_said_to_have_three_interlocking_characteristics:_impermanence,_suffering_and_lack_of_soul_or_essence.&quot;_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich200647,_Quote:_&quot;All_phenomenal_existence_[in_Buddhism]_is_said_to_have_three_interlocking_characteristics:_impermanence,_suffering_and_lack_of_soul_or_essence.&quot;-81">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup> Buddhism, like other major Indian religions, asserts that everything is impermanent (anicca), but, unlike them, also asserts that there is no permanent self or soul in living beings (<i>anattā</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-britannicaanatta_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannicaanatta-82">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-5sourcesanatta_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5sourcesanatta-84">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup> The ignorance or misperception (<i><a href="/wiki/Avidy%C4%81_(Buddhism)" title="Avidyā (Buddhism)">avijjā</a></i>) that anything is permanent or that there is self in any being is considered a wrong understanding, and the primary source of clinging and dukkha.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-GombrichScherrer2008p209_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GombrichScherrer2008p209-86">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-HoffmanMahinda2013p162_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HoffmanMahinda2013p162-87">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><i>Dukkha</i> <a href="/wiki/Samudaya_sacca" class="mw-redirect" title="Samudaya sacca">arises</a> when we crave (Pali: <i><a href="/wiki/Tanha" class="mw-redirect" title="Tanha">tanha</a></i>) and cling to these changing phenomena. The clinging and craving produces <a href="/wiki/Karma_in_Buddhism" title="Karma in Buddhism">karma</a>, which ties us to samsara, the round of death and rebirth.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERahula2014loc._791–809_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERahula2014loc._791–809-88">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bodhi1_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bodhi1-89">&#91;web 7&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">&#91;note 10&#93;</a></sup> Craving includes <i>kama-tanha</i>, craving for sense-pleasures; <i><a href="/wiki/Bhava" title="Bhava">bhava</a>-tanha</i>, craving to continue the cycle of life and death, including rebirth; and <i>vibhava-tanha</i>, craving to not experience the world and painful feelings.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERahula2014loc._791–809_88-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERahula2014loc._791–809-88">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199870_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199870-91">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAjahn_Sucitto2010Kindle_loc._943–946_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAjahn_Sucitto2010Kindle_loc._943–946-92">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><i>Dukkha</i> ceases, or can be confined,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrazier2001_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrazier2001-93">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup> when craving and clinging cease or are confined. This also means that no more karma is being produced, and rebirth ends.<sup id="cite_ref-Nirodha_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nirodha-95">&#91;note 11&#93;</a></sup> Cessation is <i><a href="/wiki/Nirvana_(Buddhism)" title="Nirvana (Buddhism)">nirvana</a></i>, "blowing out," and peace of mind.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERahula2014loc._904–923_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERahula2014loc._904–923-96">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199875_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199875-97">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>By following the Buddhist path to <i><a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">moksha</a></i>, liberation,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2008136_64-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2008136-64">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup> one starts to disengage from craving and clinging to impermanent states and things. The term "path" is usually taken to mean the <a href="/wiki/Noble_Eightfold_Path" title="Noble Eightfold Path">Noble Eightfold Path</a>, but <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_Paths_to_liberation" class="mw-redirect" title="Buddhist Paths to liberation">other versions</a> of "the path" can also be found in the Nikayas.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBucknell1984_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBucknell1984-98">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup> The Theravada tradition regards insight into the four truths as liberating in itself.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarter19873179_72-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarter19873179-72">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="The_cycle_of_rebirth">The cycle of rebirth</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bhavachakra.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Traditional Tibetan Buddhist Thangka depicting the Wheel of Life" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Bhavachakra.jpg/220px-Bhavachakra.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="300" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/21/Bhavachakra.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="330" data-file-height="450" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Bhavachakra.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Traditional <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism" title="Tibetan Buddhism">Tibetan Buddhist</a> <a href="/wiki/Thangka" title="Thangka">Thangka</a> depicting the <a href="/wiki/Bhavacakra" title="Bhavacakra">Wheel of Life</a> with its six realms</div></div></div>
<h4><span id="Sa.E1.B9.83s.C4.81ra"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Saṃsāra">Saṃsāra</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83s%C4%81ra_(Buddhism)" title="Saṃsāra (Buddhism)">Saṃsāra (Buddhism)</a></div>
<p><i>Saṃsāra</i> means "wandering" or "world", with the connotation of cyclic, circuitous change.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlaus_Klostermaier2010604_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlaus_Klostermaier2010604-99">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJuergensmeyerRoof2011271–272_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJuergensmeyerRoof2011271–272-100">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup> It refers to the theory of rebirth and "cyclicality of all life, matter, existence", a fundamental assumption of Buddhism, as with all major Indian religions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJuergensmeyerRoof2011271–272_100-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJuergensmeyerRoof2011271–272-100">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200458,_Quote:_&quot;Buddhism_shares_with_Hinduism_the_doctrine_of_Samsara,_whereby_all_beings_pass_through_an_unceasing_cycle_of_birth,_death_and_rebirth_until_they_find_a_means_of_liberation_from_the_cycle._However,_Buddhism_differs_from_Hinduism_in_rejecting_the_assertion_that_every_human_being_possesses_a_changeless_soul_which_constitutes_his_or_her_ultimate_identity,_and_which_transmigrates_from_one_incarnation_to_the_next._101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200458,_Quote:_&quot;Buddhism_shares_with_Hinduism_the_doctrine_of_Samsara,_whereby_all_beings_pass_through_an_unceasing_cycle_of_birth,_death_and_rebirth_until_they_find_a_means_of_liberation_from_the_cycle._However,_Buddhism_differs_from_Hinduism_in_rejecting_the_assertion_that_every_human_being_possesses_a_changeless_soul_which_constitutes_his_or_her_ultimate_identity,_and_which_transmigrates_from_one_incarnation_to_the_next.-101">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup> Samsara in Buddhism is considered to be <i><a href="/wiki/Dukkha" title="Dukkha">dukkha</a></i>, unsatisfactory and painful,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilson2010_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilson2010-102">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup> perpetuated by desire and <i><a href="/wiki/Avidy%C4%81_(Buddhism)" title="Avidyā (Buddhism)">avidya</a></i> (ignorance), and the resulting <a href="/wiki/Karma" title="Karma">karma</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJuergensmeyerRoof2011271–272_100-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJuergensmeyerRoof2011271–272-100">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcClelland2010172,_240_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcClelland2010172,_240-103">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliamsTribeWynne201218–19,_chapter_1_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliamsTribeWynne201218–19,_chapter_1-104">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The theory of rebirths, and realms in which these rebirths can occur, is extensively developed in Buddhism, in particular Tibetan Buddhism with its wheel of existence (<i>Bhavacakra</i>) doctrine.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilson2010_102-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilson2010-102">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup> Liberation from this cycle of existence, <i>nirvana</i>, has been the foundation and the most important historical justification of Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConze201371,_Quote:_&quot;Nirvana_is_the_&#39;&#39;raison_d&#39;être&#39;&#39;_of_Buddhism,_and_its_ultimate_justification.&quot;_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConze201371,_Quote:_&quot;Nirvana_is_the_&#39;&#39;raison_d&#39;être&#39;&#39;_of_Buddhism,_and_its_ultimate_justification.&quot;-105">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin1998119_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin1998119-106">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The later Buddhist texts assert that rebirth can occur in six realms of existence, namely three good realms (heavenly, demi-god, human) and three evil realms (animal, hungry ghosts, hellish).<sup id="cite_ref-realms2_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-realms2-108">&#91;note 12&#93;</a></sup> Samsara ends if a person attains <a href="/wiki/Nirvana" title="Nirvana">nirvana</a>, the "blowing out" of the desires and the gaining of true insight into <a href="/wiki/Impermanence" title="Impermanence">impermanence</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anatta" title="Anatta">non-self</a> reality.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellGimello19927–8,_83–84_109-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellGimello19927–8,_83–84-109">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChoong199928–29,_Quote:_&quot;Seeing_(&#39;&#39;passati&#39;&#39;)_the_nature_of_things_as_impermanent_leads_to_the_removal_of_the_view_of_self,_and_so_to_the_realisation_of_nirvana.&quot;_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChoong199928–29,_Quote:_&quot;Seeing_(&#39;&#39;passati&#39;&#39;)_the_nature_of_things_as_impermanent_leads_to_the_removal_of_the_view_of_self,_and_so_to_the_realisation_of_nirvana.&quot;-110">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERahula201451-58_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERahula201451-58-111">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Rebirth">Rebirth</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kushinara1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="A very large hill behind two palm trees and a boulevard, where the Buddha is believed to have been cremated" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Kushinara1.jpg/220px-Kushinara1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="138" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Kushinara1.jpg/330px-Kushinara1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Kushinara1.jpg/440px-Kushinara1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2500" data-file-height="1563" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Kushinara1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ramabhar Stupa in <a href="/wiki/Kushinagar" title="Kushinagar">Kushinagar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uttar_Pradesh" title="Uttar Pradesh">Uttar Pradesh</a>, <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> is regionally believed to be Buddha's cremation site.</div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Rebirth_(Buddhism)" title="Rebirth (Buddhism)">Rebirth (Buddhism)</a></div>
<p>Rebirth refers to a process whereby beings go through a succession of lifetimes as one of many possible forms of <a href="/wiki/Sentient_beings_(Buddhism)" title="Sentient beings (Buddhism)">sentient life</a>, each running from conception to death.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown1996107_112-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown1996107-112">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup> In Buddhist thought, this rebirth does not involve any soul, because of its doctrine of <a href="/wiki/Anatta" title="Anatta">anattā</a> (Sanskrit: <i>anātman</i>, no-self doctrine) which rejects the concepts of a permanent self or an unchanging, eternal soul, as it is called in <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Leaman2002p23_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Leaman2002p23-113">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup> According to Buddhism there ultimately is no such thing as a self in any being or any essence in any thing.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">&#91;95&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Buddhist traditions have traditionally disagreed on what it is in a person that is reborn, as well as how quickly the rebirth occurs after each death.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709-115">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Neufeldt1986p123_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Neufeldt1986p123-116">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup> Some Buddhist traditions assert that "no self" doctrine means that there is no perduring self, but there is <i>avacya</i> (inexpressible) self which migrates from one life to another.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709_115-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709-115">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup> The majority of Buddhist traditions, in contrast, assert that <a href="/wiki/Vij%C3%B1%C4%81na" title="Vijñāna">vijñāna</a> (a person's consciousness) though evolving, exists as a continuum and is the mechanistic basis of what undergoes rebirth, rebecoming and redeath.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200274–75_56-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200274–75-56">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709_115-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709-115">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup> The rebirth depends on the <a href="/wiki/Merit_(Buddhism)" title="Merit (Buddhism)">merit</a> or demerit gained by one's karma, as well as that accrued on one's behalf by a family member.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">&#91;note 13&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Each rebirth takes place within one of five realms according to Theravadins, or six according to other schools – heavenly, demi-gods, humans, animals, hungry ghosts and hellish.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey199034_119-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey199034-119">&#91;99&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004711_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004711-120">&#91;100&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">&#91;note 14&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In East Asian and <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism" title="Tibetan Buddhism">Tibetan Buddhism</a>, rebirth is not instantaneous, and there is an intermediate state (Tibetan "<a href="/wiki/Bardo" title="Bardo">bardo</a>") between one life and the next.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez200349–50,_708–709_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez200349–50,_708–709-133">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">&#91;111&#93;</a></sup> The orthodox Theravada position rejects the wait, and asserts that rebirth of a being is immediate.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez200349–50,_708–709_133-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez200349–50,_708–709-133">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup> However there are passages in the <i><a href="/wiki/Samyutta_Nikaya" class="mw-redirect" title="Samyutta Nikaya">Samyutta Nikaya</a></i> of the Pali Canon that seem to lend support to the idea that the Buddha taught about an intermediate stage between one life and the next.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004377_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004377-135">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBodhi2000_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBodhi2000-136">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (March 2015)">page&#160;needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Karma">Karma</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Karma_in_Buddhism" title="Karma in Buddhism">Karma in Buddhism</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Karma_in_Buddhism" title="Karma in Buddhism">In Buddhism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karma" title="Karma">karma</a> (from <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>: "action, work") drives <i><a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83s%C4%81ra" title="Saṃsāra">saṃsāra</a></i> – the endless cycle of suffering and rebirth for each being. Good, skilful deeds (Pāli: <i>kusala</i>) and bad, unskilful deeds (Pāli: <i>akusala</i>) produce "seeds" in the unconscious receptacle (<i>ālaya</i>) that mature later either in this life or in a subsequent <a href="/wiki/Rebirth_(Buddhism)" title="Rebirth (Buddhism)">rebirth</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013131,_32–34_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013131,_32–34-137">&#91;114&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKasulis20061–12_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKasulis20061–12-138">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup> The existence of karma is a core belief in Buddhism, as with all major Indian religions, it implies neither fatalism nor that everything that happens to a person is caused by karma.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340–41_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340–41-139">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">&#91;note 15&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>A central aspect of Buddhist theory of karma is that intent (<i><a href="/wiki/Cetan%C4%81" title="Cetanā">cetanā</a></i>) matters and is essential to bring about a consequence or <i><a href="/wiki/Phala" title="Phala">phala</a></i> "fruit" or <a href="/wiki/Vip%C4%81ka" title="Vipāka">vipāka</a> "result".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKrishan199759–78_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKrishan199759–78-141">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">&#91;note 16&#93;</a></sup> However, good or bad karma accumulates even if there is no physical action, and just having ill or good thoughts creates karmic seeds; thus, actions of body, speech or mind all lead to karmic seeds.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340–41_139-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340–41-139">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup> In the Buddhist traditions, life aspects affected by the law of karma in past and current births of a being include the form of rebirth, realm of rebirth, social class, character and major circumstances of a lifetime.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340–41_139-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340–41-139">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpiro1982430_with_footnote_1_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpiro1982430_with_footnote_1-146">&#91;121&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup> It operates like the laws of physics, without external intervention, on every being in all <a href="/wiki/Samsara_(Buddhism)" class="mw-redirect" title="Samsara (Buddhism)">six realms</a> of existence including human beings and gods.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340–41_139-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340–41-139">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELopez2001239–248_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELopez2001239–248-148">&#91;123&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>A notable aspect of the karma theory in Buddhism is merit transfer.<sup id="cite_ref-appletonp129_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-appletonp129-149">&#91;124&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpiro1982124–128_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpiro1982124–128-150">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup> A person accumulates merit not only through intentions and ethical living, but also is able to gain merit from others by exchanging goods and services, such as through <i>dāna</i> (charity to monks or nuns).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201345–46_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201345–46-151">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup> Further, a person can transfer one's own good karma to living family members and ancestors.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpiro1982124–128_150-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpiro1982124–128-150">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">&#91;note 17&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Liberation">Liberation</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mahabodhitemple.jpg" class="image"><img alt="stone Mahabodhi temple in Bodh Gaya, India, where Gautama Buddha attained Nirvana under the Bodhi Tree" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Mahabodhitemple.jpg/220px-Mahabodhitemple.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="293" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Mahabodhitemple.jpg/330px-Mahabodhitemple.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Mahabodhitemple.jpg/440px-Mahabodhitemple.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1944" data-file-height="2592" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Mahabodhitemple.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mahabodhi_Temple" title="Mahabodhi Temple">Mahabodhi Temple</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bodh_Gaya" title="Bodh Gaya">Bodh Gaya</a>, India, where Gautama Buddha attained <a href="/wiki/Nirvana_(Buddhism)" title="Nirvana (Buddhism)">nirvana</a> under the <a href="/wiki/Bodhi_Tree" title="Bodhi Tree">Bodhi Tree</a> (left)</div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">Moksha</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nirvana_(Buddhism)" title="Nirvana (Buddhism)">Nirvana (Buddhism)</a></div>
<p>The cessation of the <i><a href="/wiki/Kleshas_(Buddhism)" title="Kleshas (Buddhism)">kleshas</a></i> and the attainment of <a href="/wiki/Nirvana" title="Nirvana">nirvana</a> (<i>nibbāna</i>), with which the cycle of rebirth ends, has been the primary and the soteriological goal of the Buddhist path for monastic life since the time of the Buddha.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2008136_64-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2008136-64">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003589–590_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003589–590-155">&#91;129&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">&#91;130&#93;</a></sup> The term "path" is usually taken to mean the <a href="/wiki/Noble_Eightfold_Path" title="Noble Eightfold Path">Noble Eightfold Path</a>, but <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_Paths_to_liberation" class="mw-redirect" title="Buddhist Paths to liberation">other versions</a> of "the path" can also be found in the Nikayas.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">&#91;note 18&#93;</a></sup> In some passages in the Pali Canon, a distinction is being made between right knowledge or insight (<i>sammā-ñāṇa</i>), and right liberation or release (<i>sammā-vimutti</i>), as the means to attain cessation and liberation.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChoong2000141_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChoong2000141-158">&#91;131&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFuller200555–56_159-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFuller200555–56-159">&#91;132&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Nirvana literally means "blowing out, quenching, becoming extinguished".<sup id="cite_ref-Collins2010p63_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Collins2010p63-160">&#91;133&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECousins19969_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECousins19969-161">&#91;134&#93;</a></sup> In early Buddhist texts, it is the state of restraint and self-control that leads to the "blowing out" and the ending of the cycles of sufferings associated with rebirths and redeaths.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988-162">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich199766_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich199766-163">&#91;136&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">&#91;137&#93;</a></sup> Many later Buddhist texts describe nirvana as identical with <i><a href="/wiki/Anatta" title="Anatta">anatta</a></i> with complete "emptiness, nothingness".<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">&#91;138&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">&#91;139&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">&#91;140&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">&#91;note 19&#93;</a></sup> In some texts, the state is described with greater detail, such as passing through the gate of emptiness (<i>sunyata</i>) – realising that there is no soul or self in any living being, then passing through the gate of signlessness (<i>animitta</i>) – realising that nirvana cannot be perceived, and finally passing through the gate of wishlessness (<i>apranihita</i>) – realising that nirvana is the state of not even wishing for nirvana.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003589–590_155-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003589–590-155">&#91;129&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">&#91;142&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">&#91;note 20&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The nirvana state has been described in Buddhist texts partly in a manner similar to other Indian religions, as the state of complete liberation, enlightenment, highest happiness, bliss, fearlessness, freedom, permanence, non-dependent origination, unfathomable, and indescribable.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">&#91;144&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">&#91;145&#93;</a></sup> It has also been described in part differently, as a state of spiritual release marked by "emptiness" and realisation of <i><a href="/wiki/Anatta" title="Anatta">non-self</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">&#91;146&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">&#91;note 21&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>While Buddhism considers the liberation from <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83s%C4%81ra_(Buddhism)" title="Saṃsāra (Buddhism)">saṃsāra</a> as the ultimate spiritual goal, in traditional practice, the primary focus of a vast majority of lay Buddhists has been to seek and accumulate merit through good deeds, donations to monks and various Buddhist rituals in order to gain better rebirths rather than nirvana.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200462_127-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200462-127">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">&#91;note 22&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="The_path_to_liberation:_Bhavana_.28practice.2C_cultivation.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="The_path_to_liberation:_Bhavana_(practice,_cultivation)">The path to liberation: <i>Bhavana</i> (practice, cultivation)</span></h2>
<p>While the Noble Eightfold Path is best-known in the west, a wide variety of practices and stages have been used and described in the Buddhist traditions. Basic practices include <i>sila</i> (ethics), <i>samadhi</i> (meditation, <i>dhyana</i>) and <i>prajna</i> (wisdom), as described in the Noble Eightfold Path. An important additional practice is a kind and compassionate attitude toward every living being and the world. <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_devotion" title="Buddhist devotion">Devotion</a> is also important in some Buddhist traditions, and in the Tibetan traditions visualisations of deities and mandalas are important. The value of textual study is regarded differently in the various Buddhist traditions. It is central to Theravada and highly important to Tibetan Buddhism, while the Zen tradition takes an ambiguous stance.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Refuge_in_the_Three_Jewels">Refuge in the Three Jewels</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Buddha-Footprint.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="stone footprint Gautama Buddha with Dharmachakra and Three Jewels" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Buddha-Footprint.jpeg/220px-Buddha-Footprint.jpeg" decoding="async" width="220" height="383" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Buddha-Footprint.jpeg/330px-Buddha-Footprint.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Buddha-Footprint.jpeg/440px-Buddha-Footprint.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="459" data-file-height="800" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Buddha-Footprint.jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Relic depicting a footprint of <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">the Buddha</a> with <a href="/wiki/Dharmachakra" title="Dharmachakra">Dharmachakra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Triratna" title="Triratna">Triratna</a>, first century CE, <a href="/wiki/Gandhara" title="Gandhara">Gandhāra</a></div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Refuge_(Buddhism)" title="Refuge (Buddhism)">Refuge (Buddhism)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Three_Jewels" class="mw-redirect" title="Three Jewels">Three Jewels</a></div>
<p>Traditionally, the first step in most Buddhist schools requires taking Three Refuges, also called the Three Jewels (<a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>: <i>triratna</i>, <a href="/wiki/Pali" title="Pali">Pali</a>: <i>tiratana</i>) as the foundation of one's religious practice.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013249_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013249-183">&#91;152&#93;</a></sup> Pali texts employ the <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Brahmanical</a> motif of the triple refuge, found in the <i><a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a></i> 9.97.47, <i>Rigveda</i> 6.46.9 and <i><a href="/wiki/Chandogya_Upanishad" title="Chandogya Upanishad">Chandogya Upanishad</a></i> 2.22.3–4.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShults2014108_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShults2014108-184">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup> Tibetan Buddhism sometimes adds a fourth refuge, in the <i><a href="/wiki/Lama" title="Lama">lama</a></i>. The three refuges are believed by Buddhists to be protective and a form of reverence.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013249_183-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013249-183">&#91;152&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Three Jewels are:<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013244–245_185-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013244–245-185">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li>The <a href="/wiki/Gautama" class="mw-redirect" title="Gautama">Gautama Buddha</a>, the historical Buddha, the Blessed One, the Awakened with true knowledge</li>
<li>The <a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">Dharma</a>, the precepts, the practice, the Four Truths, the Eightfold Path</li>
<li>The <a href="/wiki/Sangha" title="Sangha">Sangha</a>, order of monks, the community of Buddha's disciples</li></ul>
<p>Reciting the three refuges is considered in Buddhism not as a place to hide, rather a thought that purifies, uplifts and strengthens.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013244–245_185-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013244–245-185">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Buddhist_path">The Buddhist path</span></h3>
<h4><span id="Theravada_.E2.80.93_Noble_Eightfold_Path"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Theravada_–_Noble_Eightfold_Path">Theravada – Noble Eightfold Path</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Dharma_Wheel.svg" class="image"><img alt="ship&#39;s wheel with eight spokes represents the Noble Eightfold Path" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Dharma_Wheel.svg/170px-Dharma_Wheel.svg.png" decoding="async" width="170" height="170" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Dharma_Wheel.svg/255px-Dharma_Wheel.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Dharma_Wheel.svg/340px-Dharma_Wheel.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="697" data-file-height="697" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Dharma_Wheel.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <i><a href="/wiki/Dharmachakra" title="Dharmachakra">Dharmachakra</a></i> represents the <a href="/wiki/Noble_Eightfold_Path" title="Noble Eightfold Path">Noble Eightfold Path</a>.</div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Noble_Eightfold_Path" title="Noble Eightfold Path">Noble Eightfold Path</a> and <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_Paths_to_liberation" class="mw-redirect" title="Buddhist Paths to liberation">Buddhist Paths to liberation</a></div>
<p>An important guiding principle of Buddhist practice is the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Way" title="Middle Way">Middle Way</a> (<i>madhyamapratipad</i>). It was a part of Buddha's first sermon, where he presented the <a href="/wiki/Noble_Eightfold_Path" title="Noble Eightfold Path">Noble Eightfold Path</a> that was a 'middle way' between the extremes of asceticism and hedonistic sense pleasures.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201323,_81_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201323,_81-186">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown199624,_59_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown199624,_59-187">&#91;156&#93;</a></sup> In Buddhism, states Harvey, the doctrine of "dependent arising" (conditioned arising, <i>pratītyasamutpāda</i>) to explain rebirth is viewed as the 'middle way' between the doctrines that a being has a "permanent soul" involved in rebirth (eternalism) and "death is final and there is no rebirth" (annihilationism).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201372_188-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201372-188">&#91;157&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez200349,_&#39;&#39;antagrahadrsti&#39;&#39;_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez200349,_&#39;&#39;antagrahadrsti&#39;&#39;-189">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the Theravada canon, the Pali-suttas, various often irreconcilable sequences can be found. According to Carol Anderson, the Theravada canon lacks "an overriding and comprehensive structure of the path to <i>nibbana</i>."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnderson1999131_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnderson1999131-190">&#91;159&#93;</a></sup> Nevertheless, the <a href="/wiki/Noble_Eightfold_Path" title="Noble Eightfold Path">Noble Eightfold Path</a>, or "Eightfold Path of the Noble Ones", has become an important description of the Buddhist path. It consists of a set of eight interconnected factors or conditions, that when developed together, lead to the cessation of <a href="/wiki/Dukkha" title="Dukkha">dukkha</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAjahn_Sucitto201087–88_191-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAjahn_Sucitto201087–88-191">&#91;160&#93;</a></sup> These eight factors are: Right View (or Right Understanding), Right Intention (or Right Thought), Right Speech, Right Action, Right Livelihood, Right Effort, Right Mindfulness, and Right Concentration.
</p><p>This Eightfold Path is the fourth of the <a href="/wiki/Four_Noble_Truths" title="Four Noble Truths">Four Noble Truths</a>, and asserts the path to the cessation of <i>dukkha</i> (suffering, pain, unsatisfactoriness).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199881–83_192-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199881–83-192">&#91;161&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnderson201364–65_193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnderson201364–65-193">&#91;162&#93;</a></sup> The path teaches that the way of the enlightened ones stopped their craving, clinging and <a href="/wiki/Karma" title="Karma">karmic</a> accumulations, and thus ended their endless cycles of rebirth and suffering.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2016253–255_194-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2016253–255-194">&#91;163&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhikkhu_Bodhi20101–13_195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhikkhu_Bodhi20101–13-195">&#91;164&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliamsTribeWynne201252_196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliamsTribeWynne201252-196">&#91;165&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Noble Eightfold Path is grouped into <a href="/wiki/Three_disciplines_of_Buddhism" class="mw-redirect" title="Three disciplines of Buddhism">three basic divisions</a>, as follows:<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13_197-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13-197">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–85_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–85-198">&#91;167&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhikkhu_Bodhi201047–48_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhikkhu_Bodhi201047–48-199">&#91;168&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable">

<tbody><tr>
<th>Division
</th>
<th>Eightfold factor
</th>
<th><i>Sanskrit, Pali</i>
</th>
<th>Description
</th></tr>
<tr style="background:#cff;">
<td rowspan="2">Wisdom<br />(Sanskrit: <i><a href="/wiki/Wisdom_in_Buddhism" class="mw-redirect" title="Wisdom in Buddhism">prajñā</a></i>,<br />Pāli: <i>paññā</i>)
</td>
<td>1. Right view
</td>
<td><i>samyag dṛṣṭi,<br />sammā ditthi</i>
</td>
<td>The belief that there is an afterlife and not everything ends with death, that Buddha taught and followed a successful path to nirvana;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13_197-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13-197">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup> according to Peter Harvey, the right view is held in Buddhism as a belief in the Buddhist principles of <a href="/wiki/Karma" title="Karma">karma</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rebirth_(Buddhism)" title="Rebirth (Buddhism)">rebirth</a>, and the importance of the <a href="/wiki/Four_Noble_Truths" title="Four Noble Truths">Four Noble Truths</a> and the True Realities.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–84_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–84-200">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#cff;">
<td>2. Right intention
</td>
<td><i>samyag saṃkalpa,<br />sammā saṅkappa</i>
</td>
<td>Giving up home and adopting the life of a religious mendicant in order to follow the path;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13_197-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13-197">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup> this concept, states Harvey, aims at peaceful renunciation, into an environment of non-sensuality, non-ill-will (to lovingkindness), away from cruelty (to compassion).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–84_200-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–84-200">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#cfc;">
<td rowspan="3">Moral virtues<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–85_198-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–85-198">&#91;167&#93;</a></sup><br />(Sanskrit: <i><a href="/wiki/%C5%9A%C4%ABla" class="mw-redirect" title="Śīla">śīla</a></i>,<br />Pāli: <i>sīla</i>)
</td>
<td>3. Right speech
</td>
<td><i>samyag vāc,<br />sammā vāca</i>
</td>
<td>No lying, no rude speech, no telling one person what another says about him, speaking that which leads to salvation.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13_197-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13-197">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#cfc;">
<td>4. Right action
</td>
<td><i>samyag karman,<br />sammā kammanta</i>
</td>
<td>No killing or injuring, no taking what is not given; no sexual acts in monastic pursuit,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13_197-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13-197">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup> for lay Buddhists no sensual misconduct such as sexual involvement with someone married, or with an unmarried woman protected by her parents or relatives.<sup id="cite_ref-Emmanuel2015p440_201-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Emmanuel2015p440-201">&#91;170&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">&#91;171&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#cfc;">
<td>5. Right livelihood
</td>
<td><i>samyag ājīvana,<br />sammā ājīva</i>
</td>
<td>For monks, beg to feed, only possessing what is essential to sustain life.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter198812_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter198812-204">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup> For lay Buddhists, the canonical texts state right livelihood as abstaining from wrong livelihood, explained as not becoming a source or means of suffering to sentient beings by cheating them, or harming or killing them in any way.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383,_273–274_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383,_273–274-205">&#91;174&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#9fff80;">
<td rowspan="3">Meditation<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–85_198-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–85-198">&#91;167&#93;</a></sup><br />(Sanskrit and Pāli: <i><a href="/wiki/Sam%C4%81dhi" class="mw-redirect" title="Samādhi">samādhi</a></i>)
</td>
<td>6. Right effort
</td>
<td><i>samyag vyāyāma,<br />sammā vāyāma</i>
</td>
<td>Guard against sensual thoughts; this concept, states Harvey, aims at preventing unwholesome states that disrupt meditation.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383-207">&#91;176&#93;</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#9fff80;">
<td>7. Right mindfulness
</td>
<td><i>samyag smṛti,<br />sammā sati</i>
</td>
<td>Never be absent minded, conscious of what one is doing; this, states Harvey, encourages mindfulness about impermanence of the body, feelings and mind, as well as to experience the five <a href="/wiki/Skandha" title="Skandha">skandhas</a>, the five hindrances, the four True Realities and seven factors of awakening.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383_207-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383-207">&#91;176&#93;</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr style="background:#9fff80;">
<td>8. Right concentration
</td>
<td><i>samyag samādhi,<br />sammā samādhi</i>
</td>
<td>Correct meditation or concentration (<i>dhyana</i>), explained as the four jhānas.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13_197-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter198812–13-197">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bucknellkangp12_208-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bucknellkangp12-208">&#91;177&#93;</a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<h4><span id="Mahayana_.E2.80.93_Bodhisattva-path_and_the_six_paramitas"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Mahayana_–_Bodhisattva-path_and_the_six_paramitas">Mahayana – Bodhisattva-path and the six paramitas</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Novices_alms_bowls_2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Novices_alms_bowls_2.jpg/220px-Novices_alms_bowls_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Novices_alms_bowls_2.jpg/330px-Novices_alms_bowls_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Novices_alms_bowls_2.jpg/440px-Novices_alms_bowls_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2560" data-file-height="1440" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Novices_alms_bowls_2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/D%C4%81na" title="Dāna">Dāna</a> or charitable giving to monks is a virtue in Buddhism, leading to merit accumulation and better rebirths.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">&#91;178&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahāyāna</a> Buddhism is based principally upon the path of a <a href="/wiki/Bodhisattva" title="Bodhisattva">Bodhisattva</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENattier2003137–138,_142–146_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENattier2003137–138,_142–146-210">&#91;179&#93;</a></sup> A <i>Bodhisattva</i> refers to one who is on the path to buddhahood.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGyatso19951_211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGyatso19951-211">&#91;180&#93;</a></sup> The term <i>Mahāyāna</i> was originally a synonym for <i>Bodhisattvayāna</i> or "Bodhisattva Vehicle."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENattier2003174_212-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENattier2003174-212">&#91;181&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirakawa1993297_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirakawa1993297-213">&#91;182&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConze20012001_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConze20012001-214">&#91;183&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the earliest texts of Mahayana Buddhism, the path of a bodhisattva was to awaken the <i>bodhicitta</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson199799_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson199799-215">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup> Between the 1st and 3rd century CE, this tradition introduced the <i>Ten Bhumi</i> doctrine, which means ten levels or stages of awakening.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson199799_215-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson199799-215">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup> This development was followed by the acceptance that it is impossible to achieve Buddhahood in one (current) lifetime, and the best goal is not nirvana for oneself, but Buddhahood after climbing through the ten levels during multiple rebirths.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENattier2003142–152_216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENattier2003142–152-216">&#91;185&#93;</a></sup> Mahayana scholars then outlined an elaborate path, for monks and laypeople, and the path includes the vow to help teach Buddhist knowledge to other beings, so as to help them cross samsara and liberate themselves, once one reaches the Buddhahood in a future rebirth.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENattier2003137–138,_142–146_210-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENattier2003137–138,_142–146-210">&#91;179&#93;</a></sup> One part of this path are the <i><a href="/wiki/P%C4%81ramit%C4%81" title="Pāramitā">Pāramitā</a></i> (perfections, to cross over), derived from the <i>Jatakas</i> tales of Buddha's numerous rebirths.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson1997101–102_217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson1997101–102-217">&#91;186&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004631–632_218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004631–632-218">&#91;187&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Mahayana texts are inconsistent in their discussion of the <i>Paramitas</i>, and some texts include lists of two, others four, six, ten and fifty-two.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENattier2003151–154_219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENattier2003151–154-219">&#91;188&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown2003212_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown2003212-220">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ichimura2001p28_221-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ichimura2001p28-221">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup> The six paramitas have been most studied, and these are:<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson1997101–102_217-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson1997101–102-217">&#91;186&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ichimura2001p28_221-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ichimura2001p28-221">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGyatso19954–12_222-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGyatso19954–12-222">&#91;191&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
