<ol><li><i><a href="/wiki/D%C4%81na" title="Dāna">Dāna</a> pāramitā</i>: perfection of giving; primarily to monks, nuns and the Buddhist monastic establishment dependent on the alms and gifts of the lay householders, in return for generating religious merit;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004196_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004196-223">&#91;192&#93;</a></sup> some texts recommend ritually transferring the merit so accumulated for better rebirth to someone else</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/%C5%9A%C4%ABla" class="mw-redirect" title="Śīla">Śīla</a> pāramitā</i>: perfection of morality; it outlines ethical behaviour for both the laity and the Mahayana monastic community; this list is similar to Śīla in the Eightfold Path (i.e. Right Speech, Right Action, Right Livelihood)<sup id="cite_ref-MizunoSekimori1996p28_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MizunoSekimori1996p28-224">&#91;193&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Kshanti" title="Kshanti"><i lang="sa-Latn" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration">Kṣānti</i></a> pāramitā</i>: perfection of patience, willingness to endure hardship</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/V%C4%ABrya" title="Vīrya">Vīrya</a> pāramitā</i>: perfection of vigour; this is similar to Right Effort in the Eightfold Path<sup id="cite_ref-MizunoSekimori1996p28_224-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MizunoSekimori1996p28-224">&#91;193&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Dhy%C4%81na_in_Buddhism" title="Dhyāna in Buddhism">Dhyāna</a> pāramitā</i>: perfection of meditation; this is similar to Right Concentration in the Eightfold Path</li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Praj%C3%B1%C4%81_(Buddhism)" title="Prajñā (Buddhism)">Prajñā</a> pāramitā</i>: perfection of insight (wisdom), awakening to the characteristics of existence such as karma, rebirths, impermanence, no-self, dependent origination and emptiness;<sup id="cite_ref-Ichimura2001p28_221-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ichimura2001p28-221">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004631–632,_664–665,_809_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004631–632,_664–665,_809-225">&#91;194&#93;</a></sup> this is complete acceptance of the Buddha teaching, then conviction, followed by ultimate realisation that "dharmas are non-arising".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson1997101–102_217-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobinsonJohnson1997101–102-217">&#91;186&#93;</a></sup></li></ol>
<p>In Mahayana Sutras that include ten <i>Paramitas</i>, the additional four perfections are "skillful means, vow, power and knowledge".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown2003212_220-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown2003212-220">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup> The most discussed <i>Paramita</i> and the highest rated perfection in Mahayana texts is the "Prajna-paramita", or the "perfection of insight".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown2003212_220-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown2003212-220">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup> This insight in the Mahayana tradition, states Shōhei Ichimura, has been the "insight of non-duality or the absence of reality in all things".<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">&#91;196&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id=".C5.9A.C4.ABla_.E2.80.93_Buddhist_ethics"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Śīla_–_Buddhist_ethics"><i>Śīla</i> – Buddhist ethics</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_ethics" title="Buddhist ethics">Buddhist ethics</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:StandingBuddha.jpg" class="image"><img alt="stone statue of Gautama Buddha, 1st century CE, Gandhara" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/StandingBuddha.jpg/220px-StandingBuddha.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="385" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/StandingBuddha.jpg/330px-StandingBuddha.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/8a/StandingBuddha.jpg 2x" data-file-width="428" data-file-height="749" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:StandingBuddha.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Statue of <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Gautama Buddha</a>, first century CE, <a href="/wiki/Gandhara" title="Gandhara">Gandhara</a>, present-day <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a> (<a href="/wiki/Guimet_Museum" title="Guimet Museum">Guimet Museum</a>)</div></div></div>
<p><i>Śīla</i> (Sanskrit) or <i>sīla</i> (Pāli) is the concept of "moral virtues", that is the second group and an integral part of the Noble Eightfold Path.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–84_200-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–84-200">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup> It consists of right speech, right action and right livelihood.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–84_200-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201383–84-200">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><i>Śīla</i> appear as ethical precepts for both lay and ordained Buddhist devotees. It includes the Five Precepts for laypeople, Eight or Ten Precepts for monastic life, as well as rules of Dhamma (<i>Vinaya</i> or <i>Patimokkha</i>) adopted by a monastery.<sup id="cite_ref-Williams2005p398_228-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Williams2005p398-228">&#91;197&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcFarlane2001187–193_229-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcFarlane2001187–193-229">&#91;198&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Precepts">Precepts</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Five_precepts" title="Five precepts">Five precepts</a></div>
<p>Buddhist scriptures explain the five precepts (<a href="/wiki/Pali_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Pali language">Pali</a>: <i lang="pi">pañcasīla</i>; <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Sanskrit language">Sanskrit</a>: <i lang="sa">pañcaśīla</i>) as the minimal standard of Buddhist morality.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGowans2013440_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGowans2013440-230">&#91;199&#93;</a></sup> It is the most important system of morality in Buddhism, together with the <a href="/wiki/Patimokkha" class="mw-redirect" title="Patimokkha">monastic rules</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Goodman_231-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Goodman-231">&#91;200&#93;</a></sup> The five precepts apply to both male and female devotees, and these are:<sup id="cite_ref-Williams2005p398_228-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Williams2005p398-228">&#91;197&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">&#91;201&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<ol><li>Abstain from killing (<a href="/wiki/Ahimsa#Buddhism" title="Ahimsa">Ahimsa</a>);</li>
<li>Abstain from stealing;</li>
<li>Abstain from sensual (including sexual) misconduct;</li>
<li>Abstain from lying;</li>
<li>Abstain from intoxicants.</li></ol>
<p>Undertaking and upholding the five precepts is based on the principle of <a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">non-harming</a> (<a href="/wiki/P%C4%81li" class="mw-redirect" title="Pāli">Pāli</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Sanskrit language">Sanskrit</a>: <i lang="sa">ahiṃsa</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown2013616_233-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown2013616-233">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Pali_Canon" class="mw-redirect" title="Pali Canon">Pali Canon</a> recommends one to compare oneself with others, and on the basis of that, not to hurt others.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey200033,_71_234-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey200033,_71-234">&#91;203&#93;</a></sup> Compassion and a belief in <a href="/wiki/Karma_(Buddhism)" class="mw-redirect" title="Karma (Buddhism)">karmic retribution</a> form the foundation of the precepts.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERatanakul2007241_235-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERatanakul2007241-235">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHorigan1996276_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHorigan1996276-236">&#91;205&#93;</a></sup> Undertaking the five precepts is part of regular lay devotional practice, both at home and at the local temple.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETerwiel2012178–179_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETerwiel2012178–179-237">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey200080_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey200080-238">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup> However, the extent to which people keep them differs per region and time.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELedgerwood2008152_239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELedgerwood2008152-239">&#91;208&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey200080_238-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey200080-238">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup> They are sometimes referred to as the <i><a href="/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C4%81vakay%C4%81na" title="Śrāvakayāna">śrāvakayāna</a> precepts</i> in the <a href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81y%C4%81na" class="mw-redirect" title="Mahāyāna">Mahāyāna</a> tradition, contrasting them with the <a href="/wiki/Bodhisattva_Precepts" title="Bodhisattva Precepts"><i>bodhisattva</i> precepts</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFunayama2004105_240-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFunayama2004105-240">&#91;209&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The five precepts are not commandments and transgressions do not invite religious sanctions, but their power has been based on the Buddhist belief in karmic consequences and their impact in the afterlife. Killing in Buddhist belief leads to rebirth in the hell realms, and for a longer time in more severe conditions if the murder victim was a monk. Adultery, similarly, invites a rebirth as prostitute or in hell, depending on whether the partner was unmarried or married.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcFarlane2001187_241-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcFarlane2001187-241">&#91;210&#93;</a></sup> These moral precepts have been voluntarily self-enforced in lay Buddhist culture through the associated belief in karma and rebirth.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcFarlane2001187–191_242-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcFarlane2001187–191-242">&#91;211&#93;</a></sup> Within the Buddhist doctrine, the precepts are meant to develop mind and character to make progress on the path to <a href="/wiki/Enlightenment_(Buddhism)" class="mw-redirect" title="Enlightenment (Buddhism)">enlightenment</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGetz2004673_243-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGetz2004673-243">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The monastic life in Buddhism has additional precepts as part of <i>patimokkha</i>, and unlike lay people, transgressions by monks do invite sanctions. Full expulsion from <i>sangha</i> follows any instance of killing, engaging in sexual intercourse, theft or false claims about one's knowledge. Temporary expulsion follows a lesser offence.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcFarlane2001192_244-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcFarlane2001192-244">&#91;213&#93;</a></sup> The sanctions vary per monastic fraternity (<i>nikaya</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcFarlane2001192–193_245-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcFarlane2001192–193-245">&#91;214&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Lay people and novices in many Buddhist fraternities also uphold <a href="/wiki/Eight_precepts" title="Eight precepts">eight (<i>asta shila</i>)</a> or ten (<i>das shila</i>) from time to time. Four of these are same as for the lay devotee: no killing, no stealing, no lying, and no intoxicants.<sup id="cite_ref-gombrichpreceptsp76_246-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gombrichpreceptsp76-246">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup> The other four precepts are:<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan200762–63_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan200762–63-247">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-gombrichpreceptsp76_246-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gombrichpreceptsp76-246">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<ol><li>No sexual activity;</li>
<li>Abstain from eating at the wrong time (e.g. only eat solid food before noon);</li>
<li>Abstain from jewellery, perfume, adornment, entertainment;</li>
<li>Abstain from sleeping on high bed i.e. to sleep on a mat on the ground.</li></ol>
<p>All eight precepts are sometimes observed by lay people on <i><a href="/wiki/Uposatha" title="Uposatha">uposatha</a></i> days: full moon, new moon, the first and last quarter following the lunar calendar.<sup id="cite_ref-gombrichpreceptsp76_246-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gombrichpreceptsp76-246">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup> The ten precepts also include to abstain from accepting money.<sup id="cite_ref-gombrichpreceptsp76_246-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gombrichpreceptsp76-246">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In addition to these precepts, Buddhist monasteries have hundreds of rules of conduct, which are a part of its <i>patimokkha</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">&#91;217&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">&#91;note 23&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Vinaya">Vinaya</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chinese_Buddhist_Monks_Ceremony_Hangzhou.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="Buddhist monks in saffron robes standing performing a ceremony in Hangzhou, China" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Chinese_Buddhist_Monks_Ceremony_Hangzhou.jpeg/220px-Chinese_Buddhist_Monks_Ceremony_Hangzhou.jpeg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Chinese_Buddhist_Monks_Ceremony_Hangzhou.jpeg/330px-Chinese_Buddhist_Monks_Ceremony_Hangzhou.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Chinese_Buddhist_Monks_Ceremony_Hangzhou.jpeg/440px-Chinese_Buddhist_Monks_Ceremony_Hangzhou.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="683" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Chinese_Buddhist_Monks_Ceremony_Hangzhou.jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Monks performing a ceremony in <a href="/wiki/Hangzhou" title="Hangzhou">Hangzhou</a>, China</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Vinaya" title="Vinaya">Vinaya</a> is the specific code of conduct for a <i>sangha</i> of monks or nuns. It includes the <a href="/wiki/Patimokkha" class="mw-redirect" title="Patimokkha">Patimokkha</a>, a set of 227 offences including 75 rules of decorum for monks, along with penalties for transgression, in the Theravadin tradition.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich1988109_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich1988109-251">&#91;219&#93;</a></sup> The precise content of the <i><a href="/wiki/Vinaya_Pitaka" class="mw-redirect" title="Vinaya Pitaka">Vinaya Pitaka</a></i> (scriptures on the Vinaya) differs in different schools and tradition, and different monasteries set their own standards on its implementation. The list of <i>pattimokkha</i> is recited every fortnight in a ritual gathering of all monks.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich1988109_251-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich1988109-251">&#91;219&#93;</a></sup> Buddhist text with vinaya rules for monasteries have been traced in all Buddhist traditions, with the oldest surviving being the ancient Chinese translations.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198893_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198893-252">&#91;220&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Monastic communities in the Buddhist tradition cut normal social ties to family and community, and live as "islands unto themselves".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198889–92_253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198889–92-253">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup> Within a monastic fraternity, a <i>sangha</i> has its own rules.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198889–92_253-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198889–92-253">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup> A monk abides by these institutionalised rules, and living life as the vinaya prescribes it is not merely a means, but very nearly the end in itself.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198889–92_253-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198889–92-253">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup> Transgressions by a monk on <i>Sangha</i> vinaya rules invites enforcement, which can include temporary or permanent expulsion.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich1988101–107_254-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich1988101–107-254">&#91;222&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Samadhi_.28dhyana.29_.E2.80.93_meditation"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Samadhi_(dhyana)_–_meditation"><i>Samadhi</i> (<i>dhyana</i>) – meditation</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rank_celebration_of_Thai_Buddhist_monk_1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Bhikkhus in saffron robes kneeling in Thailand" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Rank_celebration_of_Thai_Buddhist_monk_1.jpg/220px-Rank_celebration_of_Thai_Buddhist_monk_1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="190" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Rank_celebration_of_Thai_Buddhist_monk_1.jpg/330px-Rank_celebration_of_Thai_Buddhist_monk_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Rank_celebration_of_Thai_Buddhist_monk_1.jpg/440px-Rank_celebration_of_Thai_Buddhist_monk_1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1525" data-file-height="1316" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Rank_celebration_of_Thai_Buddhist_monk_1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Bhikkhu" title="Bhikkhu">Bhikkhus</a> in Thailand</div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_meditation" title="Buddhist meditation">Buddhist meditation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samadhi" title="Samadhi">Samadhi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samatha" title="Samatha">Samatha</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rupajhana" class="mw-redirect" title="Rupajhana">Rupajhana</a></div>
<p>A wide range of meditation practices has developed in the Buddhist traditions, but "meditation" primarily refers to the practice of <i>dhyana</i> c.q. <i>jhana</i>. It is a practice in which the attention of the mind is first narrowed to the focus on one specific object, such as the breath, a concrete object, or a specific thought, mental image or mantra. After this initial focusing of the mind, the focus is coupled to mindfulness, maintaining a calm mind while being aware of one's surroundings.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich2007_255-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich2007-255">&#91;223&#93;</a></sup> The practice of <i>dhyana</i> aids in maintaining a calm mind, and avoiding disturbance of this calm mind by mindfulness of disturbing thoughts and feelings.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200045–46_256-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200045–46-256">&#91;224&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">&#91;note 24&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Origins">Origins</span></h4>
<p>The earliest evidence of yogis and their meditative tradition, states Karel Werner, is found in the <a href="/wiki/Ke%C5%9Bin" title="Keśin">Keśin</a> hymn 10.136 of the <a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-karelwernerkesinrv_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-karelwernerkesinrv-258">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup> While evidence suggests <a href="/wiki/Meditation" title="Meditation">meditation</a> was practised in the centuries preceding the Buddha,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarrithers198630_259-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarrithers198630-259">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup> the meditative methodologies described in the Buddhist texts are some of the earliest among texts that have survived into the modern era.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198844_260-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198844-260">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiller19968_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiller19968-261">&#91;228&#93;</a></sup> These methodologies likely incorporate what existed before the Buddha as well as those first developed within Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst19931–17_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst19931–17-262">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">&#91;note 25&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Bronkhorst, the <i>Four Dhyanas</i> was a Buddhist invention.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199399_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199399-267">&#91;233&#93;</a></sup> Bronkhorst notes that the Buddhist canon has a mass of contradictory statements, little is known about their relative chronology, and "there can be no doubt that the canon – including the older parts, the Sutra and Vinaya Pitaka – was composed over a long period of time".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993xvii_268-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993xvii-268">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup> Meditative practices were incorporated from other <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Arama%E1%B9%87a" title="Śramaṇa">sramanic</a> movements;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993_269-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993-269">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup> the Buddhist texts describe how Buddha learnt the practice of the formless dhyana from Brahmanical practices, in the Nikayas ascribed to Alara Kalama and Uddaka Ramaputta.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWynne200750–56_270-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWynne200750–56-270">&#91;236&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKalupahana199424_271-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKalupahana199424-271">&#91;237&#93;</a></sup> The Buddhist canon also describes and criticises alternative dhyana practices, which likely mean the pre-existing mainstream meditation practices of Jainism and Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993xvii,_Part_I:_1–3,_10–11,_24,_Part_II:_20–28_272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993xvii,_Part_I:_1–3,_10–11,_24,_Part_II:_20–28-272">&#91;238&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Buddha added a new focus and interpretation, particularly through the Four Dhyanas methodology,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993Part_I:_page_5_273-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993Part_I:_page_5-273">&#91;239&#93;</a></sup> in which mindfulness is maintained.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199388_274-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199388-274">&#91;240&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich2007_255-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich2007-255">&#91;223&#93;</a></sup> Further, the focus of meditation and the underlying theory of liberation guiding the meditation has been different in Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarrithers198630_259-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarrithers198630-259">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENorman199729_275-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorman199729-275">&#91;241&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich1997131_276-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich1997131-276">&#91;242&#93;</a></sup> For example, states Bronkhorst, the verse 4.4.23 of the Brihadaranyaka Upanishad with its "become calm, subdued, quiet, patiently enduring, concentrated, one sees soul in oneself" is most probably a meditative state.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993Chapter_9,_page_86_277-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993Chapter_9,_page_86-277">&#91;243&#93;</a></sup> The Buddhist discussion of meditation is without the concept of soul and the discussion criticises both the ascetic meditation of Jainism and the "real self, soul" meditation of Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199374_(Chapter_8);_102_(Conclusion)_278-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199374_(Chapter_8);_102_(Conclusion)-278">&#91;244&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Four_rupa-jh.C4.81na_and_four_arupa-jh.C4.81na"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Four_rupa-jhāna_and_four_arupa-jhāna">Four <i>rupa-jhāna</i> and four <i>arupa-jhāna</i></span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Buddhist_Monuments_in_the_Horyu-ji_Area-122502.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Buddhist_Monuments_in_the_Horyu-ji_Area-122502.jpg/220px-Buddhist_Monuments_in_the_Horyu-ji_Area-122502.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="293" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Buddhist_Monuments_in_the_Horyu-ji_Area-122502.jpg/330px-Buddhist_Monuments_in_the_Horyu-ji_Area-122502.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Buddhist_Monuments_in_the_Horyu-ji_Area-122502.jpg/440px-Buddhist_Monuments_in_the_Horyu-ji_Area-122502.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="4000" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Buddhist_Monuments_in_the_Horyu-ji_Area-122502.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Buddhist monuments in the <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_Monuments_in_the_H%C5%8Dry%C5%AB-ji_Area" title="Buddhist Monuments in the Hōryū-ji Area">Horyu-ji Area</a></div></div></div>
<p>For Nirvana, Buddhist texts teach various meditation methodologies, of which <i>rupa-jhana</i> (four meditations in the realm of form) and <i>arupa-jhana</i> (four meditations in the formless realm) have been the most studied.<sup id="cite_ref-Wayman1984p81_279-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wayman1984p81-279">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup> These are described in the Pali Canon as trance-like states in the world of desirelessness.<sup id="cite_ref-Trainor2004p80_280-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Trainor2004p80-280">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup> The four dhyanas under <i>rupa-jhanas</i> are:<sup id="cite_ref-Trainor2004p80_280-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Trainor2004p80-280">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<ol><li>First dhyana: detach from all sensory desires and sinful states that are a source of unwholesome karma. Success here is described in Buddhist texts as leading to discursive thinking, deliberation, detachment, <i>sukha</i> (pleasure) and <i>priti</i> (rapture).<sup id="cite_ref-Wayman1984p81_279-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wayman1984p81-279">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">&#91;note 26&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>Second dhyana: cease deliberation and all discursive thoughts.<sup id="cite_ref-Trainor2004p80_280-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Trainor2004p80-280">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup> Success leads to one-pointed thinking, serenity, pleasure and rapture.<sup id="cite_ref-Wayman1984p81_279-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wayman1984p81-279">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>Third dhyana: lose feeling of rapture. Success leads to equanimity, mindfulness and pleasure, without rapture.<sup id="cite_ref-Wayman1984p81_279-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wayman1984p81-279">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>Fourth dhyana: cease all effects, lose all happiness and sadness. Success in the fourth meditation stage leads to pure equanimity and mindfulness, without any pleasure or pain.<sup id="cite_ref-Wayman1984p81_279-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wayman1984p81-279">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Trainor2004p80_280-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Trainor2004p80-280">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup></li></ol>
<p>The <i>arupa-jhanas</i> (formless realm meditation) are also four, which are entered by those who have mastered the <i>rupa-jhanas</i> (<a href="/wiki/Arhat" title="Arhat">Arhats</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-Trainor2004p80_280-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Trainor2004p80-280">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Wayman1984p86_282-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wayman1984p86-282">&#91;247&#93;</a></sup> The first formless dhyana gets to infinite space without form or colour or shape, the second to infinity of perception base of the infinite space, the third formless dhyana transcends object-subject perception base, while the fourth is where he dwells in nothing-at-all where there are no feelings, no ideas, nor are there non-ideas, unto total cessation.<sup id="cite_ref-Wayman1984p86_282-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wayman1984p86-282">&#91;247&#93;</a></sup> The four <i>rupa-dhyanas</i> in Buddhist practice lead to rebirth in successfully better <i>rupa</i> Brahma heavenly realms, while <i>arupa-dhyanas</i> lead into arupa heavens.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">&#91;248&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">&#91;249&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Richard Gombrich notes that the sequence of the four <i>rupa-jhanas</i> describes two different cognitive states. The first two describe a narrowing of attention, while in the third and fourth jhana attention is expanded again.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWynne2007140,_note_58_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWynne2007140,_note_58-285">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">&#91;note 27&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup> Alexander Wynne further explains that the <i>dhyana</i>-scheme is poorly understood.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWynne2007106_288-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWynne2007106-288">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup> According to Wynne, words expressing the inculcation of awareness, such as <i>sati</i>, <i>sampajāno</i>, and <i>upekkhā</i>, are mistranslated or understood as particular factors of meditative states,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWynne2007106_288-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWynne2007106-288">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup> whereas they refer to a particular way of perceiving the sense objects.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWynne2007106_288-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWynne2007106-288">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">&#91;note 28&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">&#91;note 29&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Meditation_and_insight">Meditation and insight</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Buddha_in_Haw_Phra_Kaew.jpg" class="image"><img alt="bronze Statue of the Buddha in meditation position, Haw Phra Kaew, Vientiane Laos" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Buddha_in_Haw_Phra_Kaew.jpg/220px-Buddha_in_Haw_Phra_Kaew.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="293" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Buddha_in_Haw_Phra_Kaew.jpg/330px-Buddha_in_Haw_Phra_Kaew.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Buddha_in_Haw_Phra_Kaew.jpg/440px-Buddha_in_Haw_Phra_Kaew.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2448" data-file-height="3264" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Buddha_in_Haw_Phra_Kaew.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Statue of the Buddha in meditation position, <a href="/wiki/Haw_Phra_Kaew" title="Haw Phra Kaew">Haw Phra Kaew</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vientiane" title="Vientiane">Vientiane</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Laos" title="Buddhism in Laos">Laos</a></div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Four_Noble_Truths#Substituting_&quot;liberating_insight&quot;" title="Four Noble Truths">Meditation and insight</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yoga" title="Yoga">Yoga</a></div>
<p>The Buddhist tradition has incorporated two traditions regarding the use of <a href="/wiki/Dhy%C4%81na_in_Buddhism" title="Dhyāna in Buddhism">dhyāna</a> (meditation, Pali <i>jhāna</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993_269-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993-269">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup> There is a tradition that stresses attaining <a href="/wiki/Praj%C3%B1%C4%81_(Buddhism)" title="Prajñā (Buddhism)">prajñā</a> (insight, <a href="/wiki/Bodhi" class="mw-redirect" title="Bodhi">bodhi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kensh%C5%8D" title="Kenshō">kenshō</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vipassana" class="mw-redirect" title="Vipassana">vipassana</a>) as the means to awakening and liberation. But it has also incorporated the <a href="/wiki/Yoga" title="Yoga">yogic tradition</a>, as reflected in the use of jhana, which is rejected in other sutras as not resulting in the final result of liberation.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988_162-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988-162">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993_269-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993-269">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich1997_292-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich1997-292">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">&#91;note 30&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lambert_Schmithausen" title="Lambert Schmithausen">Lambert Schmithausen</a>, a professor of Buddhist Studies, discerns three possible roads to liberation as described in the suttas,<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">&#91;note 31&#93;</a></sup> to which Vetter adds the sole practice of <i>dhyana</i> itself.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi–xxxvii_296-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi–xxxvii-296">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Vetter-dhyana_298-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vetter-dhyana-298">&#91;note 32&#93;</a></sup> According to Vetter and Bronkhorst, the earliest Buddhist path consisted of a set of practices which culminate in the practice of <i>dhyana</i>, leading to a calm of mind which according to Vetter <i>is</i> the liberation which is being sought.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi–xxxvii_296-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi–xxxvii-296">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199393–111_299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199393–111-299">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup> Frauwallner notes that the Buddha regarded <i>tanha</i>, "thirst," craving, to be the cause of suffering,  not ignorance. But this was in contradiction to the Indian traditions of the time, and posed a problem, which was then also incorporated into the Buddhis teachings.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrauwallner1973156_300-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrauwallner1973156-300">&#91;259&#93;</a></sup> Later on, "liberating insight" came to be regarded as equally liberating.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich199799–102_301-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich199799–102-301">&#91;260&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199393–111_299-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199393–111-299">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup> This "liberating insight" came to be exemplified by <i>prajna</i>, or the insight in the "four truths,"<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich199799–102_301-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich199799–102-301">&#91;260&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199393–111_299-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199393–111-299">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup> but also by other elements of the Buddhist teachings.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi–xxxvii_296-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi–xxxvii-296">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993chapter_7_302-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993chapter_7-302">&#91;261&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Brahma-vihara">The <i>Brahma-vihara</i></span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Phra_Buddha_Jinaraj_-_Phitsanulok.jpg" class="image"><img alt="gilded statue of Buddha in Wat Phra Si Rattana Mahathat, Thailand" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Phra_Buddha_Jinaraj_-_Phitsanulok.jpg/220px-Phra_Buddha_Jinaraj_-_Phitsanulok.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Phra_Buddha_Jinaraj_-_Phitsanulok.jpg/330px-Phra_Buddha_Jinaraj_-_Phitsanulok.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Phra_Buddha_Jinaraj_-_Phitsanulok.jpg/440px-Phra_Buddha_Jinaraj_-_Phitsanulok.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2560" data-file-height="1707" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Phra_Buddha_Jinaraj_-_Phitsanulok.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Statue of Buddha in <a href="/wiki/Wat_Phra_Si_Rattana_Mahathat" title="Wat Phra Si Rattana Mahathat">Wat Phra Si Rattana Mahathat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phitsanulok" title="Phitsanulok">Phitsanulok</a>, Thailand</div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Brahmavihara" title="Brahmavihara">Brahmavihara</a></div>
<p>The four immeasurables or four abodes, also called <i>Brahma-viharas</i>, are virtues or directions for meditation in Buddhist traditions, which helps a person be reborn in the heavenly (Brahma) realm.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirakawa1993172–174_303-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirakawa1993172–174-303">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-peterharvey2012p154_304-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-peterharvey2012p154-304">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">&#91;264&#93;</a></sup> These are traditionally believed to be a characteristic of the deity Brahma and the heavenly abode he resides in.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">&#91;265&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The four <i>Brahma-vihara</i> are:
</p>
<ol><li>Loving-kindness (Pāli: <i><a href="/wiki/Mett%C4%81" title="Mettā">mettā</a></i>, Sanskrit: <i>maitrī</i>) is active good will towards all;<sup id="cite_ref-peterharvey2012p154_304-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-peterharvey2012p154-304">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Fowler1999p60_307-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fowler1999p60-307">&#91;266&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>Compassion (Pāli and Sanskrit: <i><a href="/wiki/Karu%E1%B9%87%C4%81" title="Karuṇā">karuṇā</a></i>) results from <i>metta</i>; it is identifying the suffering of others as one's own;<sup id="cite_ref-peterharvey2012p154_304-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-peterharvey2012p154-304">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Fowler1999p60_307-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fowler1999p60-307">&#91;266&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>Empathetic joy (Pāli and Sanskrit: <i><a href="/wiki/Mudita" title="Mudita">muditā</a></i>): is the feeling of joy because others are happy, even if one did not contribute to it; it is a form of sympathetic joy;<sup id="cite_ref-Fowler1999p60_307-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fowler1999p60-307">&#91;266&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>Equanimity (Pāli: <i><a href="/wiki/Upekkha" title="Upekkha">upekkhā</a></i>, Sanskrit: <i>upekṣā</i>): is even-mindedness and serenity, treating everyone impartially.<sup id="cite_ref-peterharvey2012p154_304-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-peterharvey2012p154-304">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Fowler1999p60_307-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fowler1999p60-307">&#91;266&#93;</a></sup></li></ol>
<p>According to Peter Harvey, the Buddhist scriptures acknowledge that the four <i>Brahmavihara</i> meditation practices "did not originate within the Buddhist tradition".<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">&#91;267&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">&#91;note 33&#93;</a></sup> The Brahmavihara (sometimes as Brahmaloka), along with the tradition of meditation and the above four immeasurables are found in pre-Buddha and post-Buddha Vedic and Sramanic literature.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">&#91;269&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">&#91;270&#93;</a></sup> Aspects of the Brahmavihara practice for rebirths into the heavenly realm have been an important part of Buddhist meditation tradition.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">&#91;271&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Gombrich, the Buddhist usage of the <i>brahma-vihāra</i> originally referred to an awakened state of mind, and a concrete attitude toward other beings which was equal to "living with Brahman" here and now. The later tradition took those descriptions too literally, linking them to cosmology and understanding them as "living with Brahman" by rebirth in the Brahma-world.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich199784–85_315-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich199784–85-315">&#91;273&#93;</a></sup> According to Gombrich, "the Buddha taught that kindness – what Christians tend to call love – was a way to salvation."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich199762_316-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich199762-316">&#91;274&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Visualizations:_deities.2C_mandalas"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Visualizations:_deities,_mandalas">Visualizations: deities, mandalas</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Generation_stage" class="mw-redirect" title="Generation stage">Generation stage</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mandala" title="Mandala">Mandala</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mandala_zel-tary.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Mandala_zel-tary.jpg/220px-Mandala_zel-tary.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Mandala_zel-tary.jpg/330px-Mandala_zel-tary.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Mandala_zel-tary.jpg/440px-Mandala_zel-tary.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3088" data-file-height="2056" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Mandala_zel-tary.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Mandala are used in Buddhism for initiation ceremonies and visualisation.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200488–89_317-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200488–89-317">&#91;275&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Idols of deity and icons have been a part of the historic practice, and in Buddhist texts such as the 11th-century <i>Sadanamala</i>, a devotee visualises and identifies himself or herself with the imagined deity as part of meditation.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200487_318-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200487-318">&#91;276&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">&#91;277&#93;</a></sup> This has been particularly popular in Vajrayana meditative traditions, but also found in Mahayana and Theravada traditions, particularly in temples and with Buddha images.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200486–87_320-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200486–87-320">&#91;278&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In Tibetan Buddhism tradition, mandala are mystical maps for the visualisation process with cosmic symbolism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200488–89_317-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200488–89-317">&#91;275&#93;</a></sup> There are numerous deities, each with a mandala, and they are used during initiation ceremonies and meditation.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200488–89_317-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200488–89-317">&#91;275&#93;</a></sup> The mandalas are concentric geometric shapes symbolising layers of the external world, gates and sacred space. The meditation deity is in the centre, sometimes surrounded by protective gods and goddesses.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200488–89_317-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200488–89-317">&#91;275&#93;</a></sup> Visualizations with deities and mandalas in Buddhism is a tradition traceable to ancient times, and likely well established by the time the 5th-century text <i>Visuddhimagga</i> was composed.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200488–89_317-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200488–89-317">&#91;275&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">&#91;279&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Practice:_monks.2C_laity"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Practice:_monks,_laity">Practice: monks, laity</span></h4>
<p>According to Peter Harvey, whenever Buddhism has been healthy, not only ordained but also more committed lay people have practised formal meditation.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013319_322-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013319-322">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup> Loud devotional chanting however, adds Harvey, has been the most prevalent Buddhist practice and considered a form of meditation that produces "energy, joy, lovingkindness and calm", purifies mind and benefits the chanter.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013243–244,_257–258,_318–319_323-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013243–244,_257–258,_318–319-323">&#91;281&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Throughout most of Buddhist history, meditation has been primarily practised in Buddhist monastic tradition, and historical evidence suggests that serious meditation by lay people has been an exception.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2013502_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2013502-324">&#91;282&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">&#91;283&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">&#91;284&#93;</a></sup> In recent history, sustained meditation has been pursued by a minority of monks in Buddhist monasteries.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2013502–504_327-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2013502–504-327">&#91;285&#93;</a></sup> Western interest in meditation has led to a revival where ancient Buddhist ideas and precepts are adapted to Western mores and interpreted liberally, presenting Buddhism as a meditation-based form of spirituality.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2013502–504_327-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2013502–504-327">&#91;285&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Praj.C3.B1.C4.81_.E2.80.93_insight"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Prajñā_–_insight"><i>Prajñā</i> – insight</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Debating_Monks.JPG" class="image"><img alt="monks wearing crimson robes debating at Sera Monastery, Tibet" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Debating_Monks.JPG/220px-Debating_Monks.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="293" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Debating_Monks.JPG/330px-Debating_Monks.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Debating_Monks.JPG/440px-Debating_Monks.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1488" data-file-height="1984" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Debating_Monks.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Bhikku" class="mw-redirect" title="Bhikku">Monks</a> debating at <a href="/wiki/Sera_Monastery" title="Sera Monastery">Sera Monastery</a>, Tibet</div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Praj%C3%B1%C4%81_(Buddhism)" title="Prajñā (Buddhism)">Prajñā</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bodhi" class="mw-redirect" title="Bodhi">Bodhi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kensh%C5%8D" title="Kenshō">Kenshō</a>, <a href="/wiki/Satori" title="Satori">Satori</a>, <a href="/wiki/Subitism" title="Subitism">Subitism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vipassana" class="mw-redirect" title="Vipassana">Vipassana</a></div>
<p><i>Prajñā</i> (Sanskrit) or <i>paññā</i> (Pāli) is insight or knowledge of the true nature of existence. The Buddhist tradition regards ignorance (<a href="/wiki/Avidy%C4%81_(Buddhism)" title="Avidyā (Buddhism)">avidyā</a>), a fundamental ignorance, misunderstanding or mis-perception of the nature of reality, as one of the basic causes of <i>dukkha</i> and <i>samsara</i>. By overcoming ignorance or misunderstanding one is enlightened and liberated. This overcoming includes awakening to impermanence and the non-self nature of reality,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200474_328-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200474-328">&#91;286&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConze201339–40_329-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConze201339–40-329">&#91;287&#93;</a></sup> and this develops dispassion for the objects of <a href="/wiki/Up%C4%81d%C4%81na" title="Upādāna">clinging</a>, and liberates a being from <i>dukkha</i> and <i>saṃsāra</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">&#91;288&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">&#91;289&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199873–75,_146–159,_243_332-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199873–75,_146–159,_243-332">&#91;290&#93;</a></sup> <i>Prajñā</i> is important in all Buddhist traditions, and is the wisdom about the dharmas, functioning of karma and rebirths, realms of samsara, impermanence of everything, no-self in anyone or anything, and dependent origination.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004664–665_333-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004664–665-333">&#91;291&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Origins_2">Origins</span></h4>
<p>The origins of "liberating insight" are unclear. Buddhist texts, states Bronkhorst, do not describe it explicitly, and the content of "liberating insight" is likely not original to Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199374–75,_section_8.4,_Quote:_These_three_points_go_a_long_way_to_show_that_the_explicit_descriptions_of_the_content_of_liberating_insight_are_not_original_to_Buddhism,_and_were_added_under_the_influence_of_mainstream_&#91;Jainism,_Hinduism&#93;_meditation._334-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199374–75,_section_8.4,_Quote:_These_three_points_go_a_long_way_to_show_that_the_explicit_descriptions_of_the_content_of_liberating_insight_are_not_original_to_Buddhism,_and_were_added_under_the_influence_of_mainstream_[Jainism,_Hinduism]_meditation.-334">&#91;292&#93;</a></sup> According to Vetter and Bronkhorst, this growing importance of "liberating insight" was a response to other religious groups in India, which held that a liberating insight was indispensable for <i><a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">moksha</a></i>, liberation from rebirth.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxxii,_xxxiii_335-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxxii,_xxxiii-335">&#91;293&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199354–55,_96,_99_336-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199354–55,_96,_99-336">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338">&#91;note 34&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Bronkhorst suggests that the conception of what exactly constituted "liberating insight" for Buddhists developed over time. Whereas originally it may not have been specified as an insight, later on the Four Noble Truths served as such, to be superseded by <i>pratityasamutpada</i>, and still later, in the Hinayana schools, by the doctrine of the non-existence of a substantial self or person.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993100–101_339-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993100–101-339">&#91;296&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886047036">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Other descriptions of this "liberating insight" exist in the Buddhist canon: that the five Skandhas are impermanent, disagreeable, and neither the Self nor belonging to oneself"; "the contemplation of the arising and disappearance (<i>udayabbaya</i>) of the five Skandhas"; "the realisation of the Skandhas as empty (<i>rittaka</i>), vain (<i>tucchaka</i>) and without any pith or substance (<i>asaraka</i>).</p><div class="templatequotecite">—&#8201;<cite>Lambert Schmithausen<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993101_340-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993101-340">&#91;297&#93;</a></sup></cite></div>
</blockquote>
<p>In the Pali Canon liberating insight is attained in the fourth dhyana.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993102_section_8.4.3_341-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993102_section_8.4.3-341">&#91;298&#93;</a></sup> However, states Vetter, modern scholarship on the Pali Canon has uncovered a "whole series of inconsistencies in the transmission of the Buddha's word", and there are many conflicting versions of what constitutes higher knowledge and samadhi that leads to the liberation from rebirth and suffering.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi–xxv_342-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi–xxv-342">&#91;299&#93;</a></sup> Even within the Four Dhyana methodology of meditation, Vetter notes that "penetrating abstract truths and penetrating them successively does not seem possible in a state of mind which is without contemplation and reflection."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxvii_343-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxvii-343">&#91;300&#93;</a></sup> According to Vetter, <i>dhyāna</i> itself constituted the original "liberating practice".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi–xxxvii_296-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi–xxxvii-296">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Vetter-dhyana_298-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vetter-dhyana-298">&#91;note 32&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Carol Anderson notes that insight is often depicted in the Vinaya as the opening of the Dhamma eye, which sets one on the Buddhist path to liberation.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnderson2001131–167_344-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnderson2001131–167-344">&#91;301&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Theravada">Theravada</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Wider_perspective_on_the_Shwe_Zi_Gon_(4463515829).jpg" class="image"><img alt="color monument of Buddha in lotus position, Shwezigon Paya near Bagan, Myanmar" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Wider_perspective_on_the_Shwe_Zi_Gon_%284463515829%29.jpg/220px-Wider_perspective_on_the_Shwe_Zi_Gon_%284463515829%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Wider_perspective_on_the_Shwe_Zi_Gon_%284463515829%29.jpg/330px-Wider_perspective_on_the_Shwe_Zi_Gon_%284463515829%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Wider_perspective_on_the_Shwe_Zi_Gon_%284463515829%29.jpg/440px-Wider_perspective_on_the_Shwe_Zi_Gon_%284463515829%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Wider_perspective_on_the_Shwe_Zi_Gon_(4463515829).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Shwezigon_Pagoda" title="Shwezigon Pagoda">Shwezigon Pagoda</a> near <a href="/wiki/Bagan" title="Bagan">Bagan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Zahntempel_Kandy.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Zahntempel_Kandy.jpg/220px-Zahntempel_Kandy.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Zahntempel_Kandy.jpg/330px-Zahntempel_Kandy.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Zahntempel_Kandy.jpg/440px-Zahntempel_Kandy.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Zahntempel_Kandy.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Temple_of_the_Tooth" title="Temple of the Tooth">Temple of the Tooth</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kandy" title="Kandy">Kandy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a></div></div></div>
<h5><span id="Vipassan.C4.81"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Vipassanā">Vipassanā</span></h5>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Vipassan%C4%81" title="Vipassanā">Vipassanā</a></div>
<p>In Theravada Buddhism, but also in Tibetan Buddhism, two types of meditation Buddhist practices are being followed, namely <a href="/wiki/Samatha" title="Samatha">samatha</a> (Pāli; Sanskrit: <i>śamatha</i>; "calm") and vipassana (insight).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWelch1967396_345-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWelch1967396-345">&#91;302&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">&#91;303&#93;</a></sup> Samatha is also called "calming meditation", and was adopted into Buddhism from pre-Buddha Indian traditions. <i>Vipassanā</i> meditation was added by Buddha, and refers to "insight meditation". Vipassana does not aim at peace and tranquillity, states Damien Keown, but "the generation of penetrating and critical insight (panna)".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown1996106–107,_context:_Chapter_7_347-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown1996106–107,_context:_Chapter_7-347">&#91;304&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The focus of Vipassana meditation is to continuously and thoroughly know <a href="/wiki/Impermanence" title="Impermanence">impermanence</a> of everything (<i>annica</i>), <a href="/wiki/Anatta" title="Anatta">no-Self</a> in anything (<i>anatta</i>) and the <i>dukkha</i> teachings of Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">&#91;305&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">&#91;306&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Contemporary Theravada orthodoxy regards samatha as a preparation for vipassanā, pacifying the mind and strengthening the concentration in order to allow the work of insight, which leads to liberation. In contrast, the Vipassana Movement argues that insight levels can be discerned without the need for developing samatha further due to the risks of going out of the course when strong samatha is developed.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBond1992167_350-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBond1992167-350">&#91;307&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Dependent_arising">Dependent arising</span></h5>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Prat%C4%ABtyasamutp%C4%81da" title="Pratītyasamutpāda">Pratītyasamutpāda</a> and <a href="/wiki/Twelve_Nid%C4%81nas" class="mw-redirect" title="Twelve Nidānas">Twelve Nidānas</a></div>
<p><i>Pratityasamutpada</i>, also called "dependent arising, or dependent origination", is the Buddhist theory to explain the nature and relations of being, becoming, existence and ultimate reality. Buddhism asserts that there is nothing independent, except the state of nirvana.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey199054_351-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey199054-351">&#91;308&#93;</a></sup> All physical and mental states depend on and arise from other pre-existing states, and in turn from them arise other dependent states while they cease.<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">&#91;309&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The 'dependent arisings' have a causal conditioning, and thus <i>Pratityasamutpada</i> is the Buddhist belief that causality is the basis of <a href="/wiki/Ontology" title="Ontology">ontology</a>, not a creator God nor the ontological Vedic concept called universal Self (<a href="/wiki/Brahman" title="Brahman">Brahman</a>) nor any other 'transcendent creative principle'.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200264,_Quote:_In_the_&#39;&#39;Mahatanhasankhaya_Sutta&#39;&#39;_the_Buddha_&#91;stresses&#93;_that_things_originate_in_dependence_upon_causal_conditioning,_and_this_emphasis_on_causality_describes_the_central_feature_of_Buddhist_ontology._All_elements_of_samsara_exist_in_some_sense_or_another_relative_to_their_causes_and_conditions._353-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200264,_Quote:_In_the_&#39;&#39;Mahatanhasankhaya_Sutta&#39;&#39;_the_Buddha_[stresses]_that_things_originate_in_dependence_upon_causal_conditioning,_and_this_emphasis_on_causality_describes_the_central_feature_of_Buddhist_ontology._All_elements_of_samsara_exist_in_some_sense_or_another_relative_to_their_causes_and_conditions.-353">&#91;310&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">&#91;311&#93;</a></sup> However, the Buddhist thought does not understand causality in terms of Newtonian mechanics, rather it understands it as conditioned arising.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin1998153–155_355-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin1998153–155-355">&#91;312&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">&#91;313&#93;</a></sup> In Buddhism, dependent arising is referring to conditions created by a plurality of causes that necessarily co-originate a phenomenon within and across lifetimes, such as karma in one life creating conditions that lead to rebirth in one of the realms of existence for another lifetime.<sup id="cite_ref-Kalupahana1975p54_357-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kalupahana1975p54-357">&#91;314&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">&#91;315&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin1998151–152_359-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin1998151–152-359">&#91;316&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Buddhism applies the dependent arising theory to explain origination of endless cycles of <i>dukkha</i> and rebirth, through its <a href="/wiki/Twelve_Nid%C4%81nas" class="mw-redirect" title="Twelve Nidānas">Twelve Nidānas</a> or "twelve links" doctrine. It states that because <a href="/wiki/Avidy%C4%81_(Buddhism)" title="Avidyā (Buddhism)">Avidyā</a> (ignorance) exists <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%85kh%C4%81ra" title="Saṅkhāra">Saṃskāras</a> (karmic formations) exists, because Saṃskāras exists therefore <a href="/wiki/Vij%C3%B1%C4%81na" title="Vijñāna">Vijñāna</a> (consciousness) exists, and in a similar manner it links <a href="/wiki/N%C4%81mar%C5%ABpa" class="mw-redirect" title="Nāmarūpa">Nāmarūpa</a> (sentient body), <a href="/wiki/%E1%B9%A2a%E1%B8%8D%C4%81yatana" class="mw-redirect" title="Ṣaḍāyatana">Ṣaḍāyatana</a> (six senses), <a href="/wiki/Spar%C5%9Ba" title="Sparśa">Sparśa</a> (sensory stimulation), <a href="/wiki/Vedan%C4%81" title="Vedanā">Vedanā</a> (feeling), <a href="/wiki/Ta%E1%B9%87h%C4%81" title="Taṇhā">Taṇhā</a> (craving), <a href="/wiki/Up%C4%81d%C4%81na" title="Upādāna">Upādāna</a> (grasping), <a href="/wiki/Bhava" title="Bhava">Bhava</a> (becoming), <a href="/wiki/J%C4%81ti_(Buddhism)" title="Jāti (Buddhism)">Jāti</a> (birth), and <a href="/wiki/Jar%C4%81mara%E1%B9%87a" title="Jarāmaraṇa">Jarāmaraṇa</a> (old age, death, sorrow, pain).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201365–72_360-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201365–72-360">&#91;317&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201551–66_361-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201551–66-361">&#91;318&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>By breaking the circuitous links of the Twelve Nidanas, Buddhism asserts that liberation from these endless cycles of rebirth and dukkha can be attained.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey199054,_Quote:_&quot;The_main_concrete_application_of_the_abstract_principle_is_in_the_form_of_a_series_of_conditioned_links_(&#39;&#39;nidanas&#39;&#39;),_culminating_in_the_arising_of_dukkha.&quot;_(...)_&quot;This_&#91;doctrine&#93;_states_the_principle_of_conditionality,_that_all_things,_mental_and_physical,_arise_and_exist_due_to_the_presence_of_certain_conditions,_and_cease_once_their_conditions_are_removed:_nothing_(except_&#39;&#39;Nibbana&#39;&#39;)_is_independent._The_doctrine_thus_compliments_the_teaching_that_no_permanent,_independent_self_can_be_found.&quot;_362-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey199054,_Quote:_&quot;The_main_concrete_application_of_the_abstract_principle_is_in_the_form_of_a_series_of_conditioned_links_(&#39;&#39;nidanas&#39;&#39;),_culminating_in_the_arising_of_dukkha.&quot;_(...)_&quot;This_[doctrine]_states_the_principle_of_conditionality,_that_all_things,_mental_and_physical,_arise_and_exist_due_to_the_presence_of_certain_conditions,_and_cease_once_their_conditions_are_removed:_nothing_(except_&#39;&#39;Nibbana&#39;&#39;)_is_independent._The_doctrine_thus_compliments_the_teaching_that_no_permanent,_independent_self_can_be_found.&quot;-362">&#91;319&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Mahayana">Mahayana</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kamakura-buddha-2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="bronze Great Statue of Amitābha in Kamakura, Japan" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Kamakura-buddha-2.jpg/220px-Kamakura-buddha-2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="328" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Kamakura-buddha-2.jpg/330px-Kamakura-buddha-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Kamakura-buddha-2.jpg/440px-Kamakura-buddha-2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2680" data-file-height="4000" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Kamakura-buddha-2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Great Statue of <a href="/wiki/Amit%C4%81bha" title="Amitābha">Amitābha</a> in <a href="/wiki/Kamakura" title="Kamakura">Kamakura</a>, Japan</div></div></div>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Emptiness">Emptiness</span></h5>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/%C5%9A%C5%ABnyat%C4%81" title="Śūnyatā">Śūnyatā</a> and <a href="/wiki/Madhyamaka" title="Madhyamaka">Madhyamaka</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/%C5%9A%C5%ABnyat%C4%81" title="Śūnyatā">Śūnyatā</a>, or "emptiness", is a central concept in <a href="/wiki/Nagarjuna" title="Nagarjuna">Nagarjuna</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Madhyamaka" title="Madhyamaka">Madhyamaka</a> school, and widely attested in the <a href="/wiki/Prajnaparamita" title="Prajnaparamita">Prajñāpāramitā</a> sutras. It brings together key Buddhist doctrines, particularly anatta and <a href="/wiki/Prat%C4%ABtyasamutp%C4%81da" title="Pratītyasamutpāda">dependent origination</a>, to refute the metaphysics of <a href="/wiki/Sarvastivada" title="Sarvastivada">Sarvastivada</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sautr%C4%81ntika" title="Sautrāntika">Sautrāntika</a> (extinct non-Mahayana schools). Not only sentient beings are empty of <a href="/wiki/%C4%80tman_(Buddhism)" title="Ātman (Buddhism)">ātman</a>; all phenomena (<a href="/wiki/Dharma#Dharmas_in_Buddhist_phenomenology" title="Dharma">dharmas</a>) are without any <a href="/wiki/Svabhava" title="Svabhava">svabhava</a> (literally "own-nature" or "self-nature"), and thus without any underlying essence, and  "empty" of being independent; thus the heterodox theories of svabhava circulating at the time were refuted on the basis of the doctrines of early Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELindtner1997324_363-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELindtner1997324-363">&#91;320&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Representation-ony_c.q._mind-only">Representation-ony c.q. mind-only</span></h5>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Yogachara" title="Yogachara">Yogachara</a> and <a href="/wiki/La%E1%B9%85k%C4%81vat%C4%81ra_S%C5%ABtra" title="Laṅkāvatāra Sūtra">Laṅkāvatāra Sūtra</a></div>
<p>Sarvastivada teachings, which were criticised by Nāgārjuna, were reformulated by scholars such as <a href="/wiki/Vasubandhu" title="Vasubandhu">Vasubandhu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Asanga" title="Asanga">Asanga</a> and were adapted into the <a href="/wiki/Yogachara" title="Yogachara">Yogachara</a> school. One of the main features of Yogācāra philosophy is the concept of <i>vijñapti-mātra</i>. It is often used interchangeably with the term <i>citta-mātra</i>, but they have different meanings. The standard translation of both terms is "consciousness-only" or "mind-only." Several modern researchers object to this translation, and the accompanying label of "absolute idealism" or "idealistic monism".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKochumuttom19991_364-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKochumuttom19991-364">&#91;321&#93;</a></sup> A better translation for <i>vijñapti-mātra</i> is <i>representation-only</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKochumuttom19995_365-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKochumuttom19995-365">&#91;322&#93;</a></sup> while an alternative translation for <i>citta</i> (mind, thought) <i>mātra</i> (only, exclusively) has not been proposed.
</p><p>While the Mādhyamaka school held that asserting the existence or non-existence of any ultimately real thing was inappropriate, some later exponents of Yogachara asserted that the mind and only the mind is ultimately real (a doctrine known as <i>cittamatra</i>). Vasubandhu and Asanga however did not assert that mind was truly existent, or the basis of all reality.<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">&#91;web 9&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>These two schools of thought, in opposition or synthesis, form the basis of subsequent Mahayana metaphysics in the Indo-Tibetan tradition.
</p>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Buddha-nature">Buddha-nature</span></h5>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Buddha-nature" title="Buddha-nature">Buddha-nature</a></div>
<p>Buddha-nature is a concept found in some 1st-millennium CE Buddhist texts, such as the <i><a href="/wiki/Tath%C4%81gatagarbha_s%C5%ABtras" title="Tathāgatagarbha sūtras">Tathāgatagarbha sūtras</a></i>. This concept has been controversial in Buddhism, but has a following in East Asian Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPaul_Williams2008103–109,_161_367-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPaul_Williams2008103–109,_161-367">&#91;323&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHookham1991100–104_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHookham1991100–104-368">&#91;324&#93;</a></sup> These <a href="/wiki/Sutra" title="Sutra">Sutras</a> suggest, states Paul Williams, that 'all sentient beings contain a Tathagata' as their 'essence, core inner nature, Self'.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPaul_Williams2008104_369-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPaul_Williams2008104-369">&#91;325&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">&#91;note 35&#93;</a></sup> The <i>Tathagatagarbha</i> doctrine, at its earliest probably appeared about the later part of the 3rd century CE, and it contradicts the Anatta doctrine (non-Self) in a vast majority of Buddhist texts, leading scholars to posit that the <i>Tathagatagarbha Sutras</i> were written to promote Buddhism to non-Buddhists.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPaul_Williams2008104–105,_108–109;_Quote:_&quot;...&amp;nbsp;&#91;The_&#39;&#39;Mahaparinirvana_Sutra&#39;&#39;&#93;_refers_to_the_Buddha_using_the_term_&quot;Self&quot;_in_order_to_win_over_non-Buddhist_ascetics.&quot;_372-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPaul_Williams2008104–105,_108–109;_Quote:_&quot;...&amp;nbsp;[The_&#39;&#39;Mahaparinirvana_Sutra&#39;&#39;]_refers_to_the_Buddha_using_the_term_&quot;Self&quot;_in_order_to_win_over_non-Buddhist_ascetics.&quot;-372">&#91;327&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">&#91;328&#93;</a></sup> However, the Buddhist text <i>Ratnagotravibhāga</i> states that the "Self" implied in <i>Tathagatagarbha</i> doctrine is actually "not-Self".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPaul_Williams2008112_374-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPaul_Williams2008112-374">&#91;329&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHookham199196_375-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHookham199196-375">&#91;330&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Devotion">Devotion</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_devotion" title="Buddhist devotion">Buddhist devotion</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Prayers_in_front_of_Jokhang_temple.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Prayers_in_front_of_Jokhang_temple.jpg/220px-Prayers_in_front_of_Jokhang_temple.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Prayers_in_front_of_Jokhang_temple.jpg/330px-Prayers_in_front_of_Jokhang_temple.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Prayers_in_front_of_Jokhang_temple.jpg/440px-Prayers_in_front_of_Jokhang_temple.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1984" data-file-height="1488" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Prayers_in_front_of_Jokhang_temple.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Bhatti</i> (devotion) at a Buddhist temple, Tibet. Chanting during <i><a href="/wiki/Buddh%C4%81nusm%E1%B9%9Bti" title="Buddhānusmṛti">Bhatti Puja</a></i> (devotional worship) is often a part of the Theravada Buddhist tradition.</div></div></div>
<p>Devotion is an important part of the practice of most Buddhists.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey1990170_376-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey1990170-376">&#91;331&#93;</a></sup> Devotional practices include ritual prayer, prostration, offerings, pilgrimage, and chanting.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200484–85,_105,_108–109,_112–113,_116,_165,_185_377-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200484–85,_105,_108–109,_112–113,_116,_165,_185-377">&#91;332&#93;</a></sup> In Pure Land Buddhism, devotion to the Buddha Amitabha is the main practice. In Nichiren Buddhism, devotion to the Lotus Sutra is the main practice. Bhakti (called <i>Bhatti</i> in Pali) has been a common practice in Theravada Buddhism, where offerings and group prayers are made to deities and particularly images of Buddha.<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">&#91;333&#93;</a></sup> According to Karel Werner and other scholars, devotional worship has been a significant practice in <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada</a> Buddhism, and deep devotion is part of Buddhist traditions starting from the earliest days.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">&#91;334&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor2004108–109,_Quote:_&quot;(...)_both_textual_and_archaeological_evidence_shows_that_devotion_has_long_been_a_part_of_Buddhism._The_practice_of_venerating_relics_and_images_has_long_played_a_central_role_even_in_Buddhist_traditions_that_strongly_emphasize_that_Gautama_Buddha_was_a_human_being_(...)&quot;._380-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor2004108–109,_Quote:_&quot;(...)_both_textual_and_archaeological_evidence_shows_that_devotion_has_long_been_a_part_of_Buddhism._The_practice_of_venerating_relics_and_images_has_long_played_a_central_role_even_in_Buddhist_traditions_that_strongly_emphasize_that_Gautama_Buddha_was_a_human_being_(...)&quot;.-380">&#91;335&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Guru devotion is a central practice of Tibetan Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-Wolter2007p59_381-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wolter2007p59-381">&#91;336&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">&#91;337&#93;</a></sup> The guru is considered essential and to the Buddhist devotee, the guru is the "enlightened teacher and ritual master" in Vajrayana spiritual pursuits.<sup id="cite_ref-Wolter2007p59_381-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wolter2007p59-381">&#91;336&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-berkwitz130_383-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-berkwitz130-383">&#91;338&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>For someone seeking Buddhahood, the guru is the Buddha, the Dhamma and the Sangha, wrote the 12th-century Buddhist scholar Sadhanamala.<sup id="cite_ref-berkwitz130_383-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-berkwitz130-383">&#91;338&#93;</a></sup> The veneration of and obedience to teachers is also important in Theravada and Zen Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">&#91;339&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Buddhist_texts">Buddhist texts</span></h2>
