<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nava_Jetavana_Temple_-_Shravasti_-_013_First_Council_at_Rajagaha_(9241729223).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Nava_Jetavana_Temple_-_Shravasti_-_013_First_Council_at_Rajagaha_%289241729223%29.jpg/260px-Nava_Jetavana_Temple_-_Shravasti_-_013_First_Council_at_Rajagaha_%289241729223%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="151" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Nava_Jetavana_Temple_-_Shravasti_-_013_First_Council_at_Rajagaha_%289241729223%29.jpg/390px-Nava_Jetavana_Temple_-_Shravasti_-_013_First_Council_at_Rajagaha_%289241729223%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Nava_Jetavana_Temple_-_Shravasti_-_013_First_Council_at_Rajagaha_%289241729223%29.jpg/520px-Nava_Jetavana_Temple_-_Shravasti_-_013_First_Council_at_Rajagaha_%289241729223%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3399" data-file-height="1977" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Nava_Jetavana_Temple_-_Shravasti_-_013_First_Council_at_Rajagaha_(9241729223).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A depiction of the supposed <a href="/wiki/First_Buddhist_council" title="First Buddhist council">First Buddhist council</a> at <a href="/wiki/Rajgir" title="Rajgir">Rajgir</a>. Communal recitation was one of the original ways of transmitting and preserving Early Buddhist texts.</div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_texts" title="Buddhist texts">Buddhist texts</a></div>
<p>Buddhism, like all Indian religions, was initially an <a href="/wiki/Oral_tradition" title="Oral tradition">oral tradition</a> in ancient times.<sup id="cite_ref-lopez2004busc1_385-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lopez2004busc1-385">&#91;340&#93;</a></sup> The Buddha's words, the early doctrines and concepts, and the interpretations were transmitted from one generation to the next by the word of mouth in monasteries, and not through written texts. They earliest texts were transmitted in Middle <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_languages" title="Indo-Aryan languages">Indo-Aryan languages</a> called <a href="/wiki/Prakrits" class="mw-redirect" title="Prakrits">Prakrits</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Pali" title="Pali">Pali</a>, through the use communal recitation and other <a href="/wiki/Mnemonic" title="Mnemonic">mnemonic</a> techniques.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199839–41_386-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199839–41-386">&#91;341&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The first Buddhist canonical texts were likely written down in Sri Lanka, about 400 years after the Buddha died.<sup id="cite_ref-lopez2004busc1_385-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lopez2004busc1-385">&#91;340&#93;</a></sup> The texts were part of the <i><a href="/wiki/Tripi%E1%B9%ADaka" title="Tripiṭaka">Tripitakas</a></i>, and many versions appeared thereafter claiming to be the words of the Buddha. Scholarly Buddhist commentary texts, with named authors, appeared in India, around the 2nd century CE.<sup id="cite_ref-lopez2004busc1_385-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lopez2004busc1-385">&#91;340&#93;</a></sup> These texts were written in Pali or Sanskrit, sometimes regional languages, as <a href="/wiki/Palm-leaf_manuscript" title="Palm-leaf manuscript">palm-leaf manuscripts</a>, birch bark, painted scrolls, carved into temple walls, and later on paper.<sup id="cite_ref-lopez2004busc1_385-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lopez2004busc1-385">&#91;340&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Unlike what the <a href="/wiki/Bible" title="Bible">Bible</a> is to <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a> is to <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, but like all major ancient Indian religions, there is no consensus among the different Buddhist traditions as to what constitutes the scriptures or a common canon in Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-lopez2004busc1_385-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lopez2004busc1-385">&#91;340&#93;</a></sup> The general belief among Buddhists is that the canonical corpus is vast.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">&#91;342&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin2008xiv_388-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin2008xiv-388">&#91;343&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEliot193516_389-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEliot193516-389">&#91;344&#93;</a></sup> This corpus includes the ancient <i>Sutras</i> organised into <i><a href="/wiki/Nik%C4%81ya" title="Nikāya">Nikayas</a></i> or <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%80gama_(Buddhism)" title="Āgama (Buddhism)">Agamas</a></i>, itself the part of three basket of texts called the <i>Tripitakas</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">&#91;345&#93;</a></sup> Each Buddhist tradition has its own collection of texts, much of which is translation of ancient Pali and Sanskrit Buddhist texts of India. The <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Buddhist_canon" title="Chinese Buddhist canon">Chinese Buddhist canon</a>, for example, includes 2184 texts in 55 volumes, while the <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhist_canon" title="Tibetan Buddhist canon">Tibetan canon</a> comprises 1108 texts&#160;&#8211;&#32;all claimed to have been spoken by the Buddha&#160;&#8211;&#32;and another 3461 texts composed by Indian scholars revered in the Tibetan tradition.<sup id="cite_ref-lopez2004busc2_391-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lopez2004busc2-391">&#91;346&#93;</a></sup> The Buddhist textual history is vast; over 40,000 manuscripts&#160;&#8211;&#32;mostly Buddhist, some non-Buddhist&#160;&#8211;&#32;were discovered in 1900 in the Dunhuang Chinese cave alone.<sup id="cite_ref-lopez2004busc2_391-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lopez2004busc2-391">&#91;346&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Buddhist_texts">Early Buddhist texts</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Fragmentary_Buddhist_text_-_Gandhara_birchbark_scrolls_(1st_C),_part_31_-_BL_Or._14915.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Fragmentary_Buddhist_text_-_Gandhara_birchbark_scrolls_%281st_C%29%2C_part_31_-_BL_Or._14915.jpg/220px-Fragmentary_Buddhist_text_-_Gandhara_birchbark_scrolls_%281st_C%29%2C_part_31_-_BL_Or._14915.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="135" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Fragmentary_Buddhist_text_-_Gandhara_birchbark_scrolls_%281st_C%29%2C_part_31_-_BL_Or._14915.jpg/330px-Fragmentary_Buddhist_text_-_Gandhara_birchbark_scrolls_%281st_C%29%2C_part_31_-_BL_Or._14915.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Fragmentary_Buddhist_text_-_Gandhara_birchbark_scrolls_%281st_C%29%2C_part_31_-_BL_Or._14915.jpg/440px-Fragmentary_Buddhist_text_-_Gandhara_birchbark_scrolls_%281st_C%29%2C_part_31_-_BL_Or._14915.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2204" data-file-height="1351" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Fragmentary_Buddhist_text_-_Gandhara_birchbark_scrolls_(1st_C),_part_31_-_BL_Or._14915.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Gandhara birchbark scroll fragments (c. 1st century) from British Library Collection</div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Early_Buddhist_Texts" title="Early Buddhist Texts">Early Buddhist Texts</a></div><p>The Early Buddhist Texts refers to the literature which is considered by modern scholars to be the earliest Buddhist material. The first four <a href="/wiki/Pali" title="Pali">Pali</a> <a href="/wiki/Nikayas" class="mw-redirect" title="Nikayas">Nikayas</a>, and the corresponding Chinese <a href="/wiki/%C4%80gama_(Buddhism)" title="Āgama (Buddhism)">Āgamas</a> are generally considered to be among the earliest material.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199842–43_392-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199842–43-392">&#91;347&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESujatoBrahmali20159–10_393-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESujatoBrahmali20159–10-393">&#91;348&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">&#91;349&#93;</a></sup> Apart from these, there are also fragmentary collections of EBT materials in other languages such as <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saka_language" title="Saka language">Khotanese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Classical_Tibetan" title="Classical Tibetan">Tibetan</a> and <a href="/wiki/G%C4%81ndh%C4%81r%C4%AB_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Gāndhārī language">Gāndhārī</a>. The modern study of <a href="/wiki/Pre-sectarian_Buddhism" title="Pre-sectarian Buddhism">early Buddhism</a> often relies on comparative scholarship using these various early Buddhist sources to identify parallel texts and common doctrinal content.<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">&#91;350&#93;</a></sup> One feature of these early texts are literary structures which reflect oral transmission, such as widespread repetition.<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">&#91;351&#93;</a></sup></p><table class="vertical-navbox nowraplinks hlist" style="float:right;clear:right;width:22.0em;margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em;background:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em;border-spacing:0.4em 0;text-align:center;line-height:1.4em;font-size:88%;text-align: left;"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-title" style="padding:0.2em 0.4em 0.2em;font-size:145%;line-height:1.2em;padding: 0.4em 0;"><a href="/wiki/P%C4%81li_Canon" title="Pāli Canon">Pāli Canon</a></th></tr><tr><th class="navbox-abovebelow" style="padding:0.1em;text-align: left; font-size: 1.1em; padding: 0.25em 0;">
<a href="/wiki/Vinaya_Pitaka" class="mw-redirect" title="Vinaya Pitaka">Vinaya Pitaka</a></th></tr><tr><td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Suttavibhanga" title="Suttavibhanga">Suttavibhanga</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Khandhaka" title="Khandhaka">Khandhaka</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Parivara" class="mw-redirect" title="Parivara">Parivara</a></li></ul></td>
</tr><tr><th class="navbox-abovebelow" style="padding:0.1em;text-align: left; font-size: 1.1em; padding: 0.25em 0;">
<a href="/wiki/Sutta_Pitaka" class="mw-redirect" title="Sutta Pitaka">Sutta Pitaka</a></th></tr><tr><td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Digha_Nikaya" class="mw-redirect" title="Digha Nikaya">Digha Nikaya</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Majjhima_Nikaya" title="Majjhima Nikaya">Majjhima Nikaya</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Samyutta_Nikaya" class="mw-redirect" title="Samyutta Nikaya">Samyutta Nikaya</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Anguttara_Nikaya" class="mw-redirect" title="Anguttara Nikaya">Anguttara Nikaya</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Khuddaka_Nikaya" title="Khuddaka Nikaya">Khuddaka Nikaya</a></li></ul></td>
</tr><tr><th class="navbox-abovebelow" style="padding:0.1em;text-align: left; font-size: 1.1em; padding: 0.25em 0;">
<a href="/wiki/Abhidhamma_Pitaka" class="mw-redirect" title="Abhidhamma Pitaka">Abhidhamma Pitaka</a></th></tr><tr><td style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Dhammasangani" title="Dhammasangani">Dhammasangani</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Vibhanga" title="Vibhanga">Vibhanga</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Dhatukatha" title="Dhatukatha">Dhatukatha</a> and <a href="/wiki/Puggalapannatti" title="Puggalapannatti">Puggalapannatti</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Kathavatthu" title="Kathavatthu">Kathavatthu</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Yamaka" title="Yamaka">Yamaka</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Patthana" title="Patthana">Patthana</a></li></ul></td>
</tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:PaliCanon" title="Template:PaliCanon"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:PaliCanon" title="Template talk:PaliCanon"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:PaliCanon&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Tripitakas">The Tripitakas</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tripi%E1%B9%ADaka" title="Tripiṭaka">Tripiṭaka</a></div>
<p>After the development of the different <a href="/wiki/Early_Buddhist_schools" title="Early Buddhist schools">early Buddhist schools</a>, these schools began to develop their own textual collections, which were termed <i>Tripiṭakas</i> (Triple Baskets).<sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">&#91;352&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Many early <i>Tripiṭakas</i>, like the Pāli <i>Tipitaka</i>, were divided into three sections: <i><a href="/wiki/Vinaya" title="Vinaya">Vinaya Pitaka</a></i> (focuses on <a href="/wiki/Monasticism" title="Monasticism">monastic rule</a>), <i><a href="/wiki/Sutta_Pitaka" class="mw-redirect" title="Sutta Pitaka">Sutta Pitaka</a></i> (Buddhist discourses) and <i><a href="/wiki/Abhidhamma" class="mw-redirect" title="Abhidhamma">Abhidhamma Pitaka</a>,</i> which contain expositions and commentaries on the doctrine.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/P%C4%81li_Canon" title="Pāli Canon">Pāli <i>Tipitaka</i></a> (also known as the Pali Canon) of the Theravada School constitutes the only complete collection of Buddhist texts in an <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_languages" title="Indo-Aryan languages">Indic language</a> which has survived until today.<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">&#91;353&#93;</a></sup> However, many <i>Sutras</i>, <i>Vinayas</i> and <i>Abhidharma</i> works from other schools survive in Chinese translation, as part of the Chinese Buddhist Canon. According to some sources, some early schools of Buddhism had five or seven <i>pitakas</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESkilling1992114_399-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESkilling1992114-399">&#91;354&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Much of the material in the Pali Canon is not specifically "Theravadin", but is instead the collection of teachings that this school preserved from the early, non-sectarian body of teachings. According to Peter Harvey, it contains material at odds with later Theravadin orthodoxy. He states: "The Theravadins, then, may have <i>added</i> texts to the Canon for some time, but they do not appear to have tampered with what they already had from an earlier period."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey19959_400-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey19959-400">&#91;355&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Abhidharma_and_the_Commentaries">Abhidharma and the Commentaries</span></h3>
<p>A distinctive feature of many Tripitaka collections is the inclusion of a genre called <a href="/wiki/Abhidharma" title="Abhidharma">Abhidharma</a>, which dates from the 3rd century BCE and later. According to Collett Cox, the genre began as explanations and elaborations of the teachings in the suttas but over time evolved into an independent system of doctrinal exposition.<sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401">&#91;356&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Over time, the various Abhidharma traditions developed various disagreements which each other on points of doctrine, which were discussed in the different Abhidharma texts of these schools.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199854–55_46-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199854–55-46">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup> The major Abhidharma collections which modern scholars have the most information about are those of the <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravāda</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sarvastivada" title="Sarvastivada">Sarvāstivāda</a> schools.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199848_402-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199848-402">&#91;357&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In Sri Lanka and South India, the <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravāda</a> Abhidhamma system was the most influential. In addition to the Abhidharma project, some of the schools also began accumulating a literary tradition of scriptural commentary on their respective Tripitakas. These commentaries were particularly important in the <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravāda</a> school, and the Pali commentaries (<i><a href="/wiki/Atthakatha" title="Atthakatha">Aṭṭhakathā</a></i>) remain influential today. Both Abhidhamma and the Pali Commentaries influenced the <i><a href="/wiki/Visuddhimagga" title="Visuddhimagga">Visuddhimagga</a>,</i> an important 5th-century text by the Theravada scholar <a href="/wiki/Buddhaghosa" title="Buddhaghosa">Buddhaghosa</a>, who also translated and compiled many of the <i>Aṭṭhakathās</i> from older Sinhalese sources.<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">&#91;358&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199855_404-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199855-404">&#91;359&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Sarvastivada" title="Sarvastivada">Sarvāstivāda</a> school was one of the most influential Abhidharma traditions in North India.<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">&#91;360&#93;</a></sup> The magnum opus of this tradition was the massive Abhidharma commentary called the <a href="/wiki/Mahavibhasa" title="Mahavibhasa"><i>Mahāvibhaṣa</i></a> ('Great Commentary'), compiled at a great synod in Kashmir during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Kanishka_II" title="Kanishka II">Kanishka II</a> (c. 158–176).<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">&#91;361&#93;</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Abhidharmako%C5%9Bak%C4%81rik%C4%81" title="Abhidharmakośakārikā">Abhidharmakosha</a></i> of <a href="/wiki/Vasubandhu" title="Vasubandhu">Vasubandhu</a> is another very influential Abhidharma work from the northern tradition, which continues to be studied in <a href="/wiki/East_Asian_Buddhism" title="East Asian Buddhism">East Asian Buddhism</a> and in Indo-Tibetan Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199856_407-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199856-407">&#91;362&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Mah.C4.81y.C4.81na_texts"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Mahāyāna_texts">Mahāyāna texts</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mahayana_sutras" title="Mahayana sutras">Mahayana sutras</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Tripiṭaka Koreana in South Korea, over 81,000 wood printing blocks stored in racks" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg/220px-Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg/330px-Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg/440px-Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Tripitaka_Koreana" title="Tripitaka Koreana">Tripiṭaka Koreana</a> in South Korea, an edition of the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Buddhist_canon" title="Chinese Buddhist canon">Chinese Buddhist canon</a> carved and preserved in over 81,000 wood printing blocks</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Mahayana_sutras" title="Mahayana sutras">Mahāyāna sūtras</a> are a very broad genre of Buddhist scriptures that the <a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahāyāna</a> Buddhist tradition holds are original teachings of <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">the Buddha</a>. Modern historians generally hold that the first of these texts were composed probably around the 1st century BCE or 1st century CE.<sup id="cite_ref-Buddhism_2004,_page_293_408-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Buddhism_2004,_page_293-408">&#91;363&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hirakawa_Akira_1993,_p._252_409-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hirakawa_Akira_1993,_p._252-409">&#91;364&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004494_410-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004494-410">&#91;365&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In Mahāyāna, these texts are generally given greater authority than the early Āgamas and Abhidharma literature, which are called "<a href="/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C4%81vakay%C4%81na" title="Śrāvakayāna">Śrāvakayāna</a>" or "<a href="/wiki/Hinayana" title="Hinayana">Hinayana</a>" to distinguish them from Mahāyāna sūtras.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">&#91;366&#93;</a></sup> Mahāyāna traditions mainly see these different classes of texts as being designed for different types of persons, with different levels of spiritual understanding. The Mahāyāna sūtras are mainly seen as being for those of "greater" capacity.<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">&#91;367&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="this claim needs a non-sectarian source (September 2019)">better&#160;source&#160;needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>The Mahāyāna sūtras often claim to articulate the Buddha's deeper, more advanced doctrines, reserved for those who follow the <a href="/wiki/Bodhisattva" title="Bodhisattva">bodhisattva</a> path. That path is explained as being built upon the motivation to liberate all living beings from unhappiness. Hence the name <i>Mahāyāna</i> (lit., <i>the Great Vehicle</i>). Besides the teaching of the bodhisattva, Mahāyāna texts also contain expanded cosmologies and mythologies, with many more Buddhas and powerful bodhisattvas, as well as new spiritual practices and ideas.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">&#91;368&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The modern Theravada school does not treat the Mahāyāna sūtras as authoritative or authentic teachings of the Buddha.<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">&#91;369&#93;</a></sup> Likewise, these texts were not recognized as authoritative by many early Buddhist schools and in some cases, communities such as the <a href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81s%C4%81%E1%B9%83ghika" title="Mahāsāṃghika">Mahāsāṃghika</a> school split up due to this disagreement.<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">&#91;370&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Konchog-wangdu.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="Buddhist monk Geshe Konchog Wangdu in red robe reads Mahayana sutras on stand" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Konchog-wangdu.jpeg/220px-Konchog-wangdu.jpeg" decoding="async" width="220" height="246" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f5/Konchog-wangdu.jpeg 1.5x" data-file-width="224" data-file-height="250" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Konchog-wangdu.jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Buddhist monk Geshe Konchog Wangdu reads Mahayana sutras from an old woodblock copy of the Tibetan Kanjur.</div></div></div>
<p>Recent scholarship has discovered many early Mahāyāna texts which shed light into the development of Mahāyāna. Among these is the <i><a href="/wiki/Salistamba_Sutra" title="Salistamba Sutra">Śālistamba Sutra</a></i> which survives in Tibetan and Chinese translation. This text contains numerous sections which are remarkably similar to Pali suttas.<sup id="cite_ref-karlpotter1996p26_416-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-karlpotter1996p26-416">&#91;371&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">&#91;372&#93;</a></sup> The <i>Śālistamba Sutra</i> was cited by Mahāyāna scholars such as the 8th-century Yasomitra to be authoritative.<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">&#91;373&#93;</a></sup> This suggests that Buddhist literature of different traditions shared a common core of Buddhist texts in the early centuries of its history, until Mahāyāna literature diverged about and after the 1st century CE.<sup id="cite_ref-karlpotter1996p26_416-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-karlpotter1996p26-416">&#91;371&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Mahāyāna also has a very large literature of philosophical and exegetical texts. These are often called <a href="/wiki/Shastras" class="mw-redirect" title="Shastras"><i>śāstra</i></a> (treatises) or <i>vrittis</i> (commentaries). Some of this literature was also written in verse form (<i>karikās</i>), the most famous of which is the <i><a href="/wiki/Mulamadhyamakakarika" class="mw-redirect" title="Mulamadhyamakakarika">Mūlamadhyamika-karikā</a></i> (Root Verses on the Middle Way) by <a href="/wiki/Nagarjuna" title="Nagarjuna">Nagarjuna</a>, the foundational text of the <a href="/wiki/Madhyamika" class="mw-redirect" title="Madhyamika">Madhyamika</a> school.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tantric_texts">Tantric texts</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tantras_(Buddhism)" title="Tantras (Buddhism)">Tantras (Buddhism)</a></div><p>During the <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta Empire</a>, a new class of Buddhist sacred literature began to develop, which are called the <a href="/wiki/Tantras_(Buddhism)" title="Tantras (Buddhism)">Tantras</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419">&#91;374&#93;</a></sup> By the 8th century, the tantric tradition was very influential in India and beyond. Besides drawing on a <a href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81y%C4%81na" class="mw-redirect" title="Mahāyāna">Mahāyāna</a> Buddhist framework, these texts also borrowed deities and material from other Indian religious traditions, such as the <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Aaiva" class="mw-redirect" title="Śaiva">Śaiva</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pancharatra" title="Pancharatra">Pancharatra</a> traditions, local god/goddess cults, and local spirit worship (such as <a href="/wiki/Yaksha" title="Yaksha">yaksha</a> or <a href="/wiki/N%C4%81ga" title="Nāga">nāga</a> spirits).<sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">&#91;375&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">&#91;376&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Some features of these texts include the widespread use of mantras, meditation on the <a href="/wiki/Lung_(Tibetan_Buddhism)#Subtle_Body" title="Lung (Tibetan Buddhism)">subtle body</a>, worship of <a href="/wiki/Fierce_deities" title="Fierce deities">fierce deities</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Antinomian" class="mw-redirect" title="Antinomian">antinomian</a> and <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/transgressive" class="extiw" title="wikt:transgressive">transgressive</a> practices such as ingesting <a href="/wiki/Alcohol_(drug)" title="Alcohol (drug)">alcohol</a> and performing sexual rituals.<sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">&#91;377&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">&#91;378&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">&#91;379&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Buddhism" title="History of Buddhism">History of Buddhism</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Historical_roots">Historical roots</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:ElloraPuja.jpg" class="image"><img alt="people sitting before stone shrine the Buddhist &quot;Carpenter&#39;s Cave&quot; at Ellora in Maharashtra, India" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/ElloraPuja.jpg/220px-ElloraPuja.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/ElloraPuja.jpg/330px-ElloraPuja.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/ElloraPuja.jpg/440px-ElloraPuja.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="960" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:ElloraPuja.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Buddhist "Carpenter's Cave" at <a href="/wiki/Ellora" class="mw-redirect" title="Ellora">Ellora</a> in <a href="/wiki/Maharashtra" title="Maharashtra">Maharashtra</a>, India</div></div></div>
<p>Historically, the roots of Buddhism lie in the religious thought of <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age_India" class="mw-redirect" title="Iron Age India">Iron Age India</a> around the middle of the first millennium BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin2008xv_425-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin2008xv-425">&#91;380&#93;</a></sup> This was a period of great intellectual ferment and socio-cultural change known as the <a href="/wiki/History_of_India#&quot;Second_urbanisation&quot;_(c._600_–_c._200_BCE)" title="History of India">"Second urbanisation"</a>, marked by the composition of the <a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishads</a> and the historical emergence of the Sramanic traditions.<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">&#91;381&#93;</a></sup> <sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198826–41_427-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198826–41-427">&#91;382&#93;</a></sup>
<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">&#91;note 36&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>New ideas developed both in the <a href="/wiki/Historical_Vedic_religion" title="Historical Vedic religion">Vedic tradition</a> in the form of the <a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishads</a>, and outside of the Vedic tradition through the <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Arama%E1%B9%87a" title="Śramaṇa">Śramaṇa</a> movements.<sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431">&#91;385&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432">&#91;386&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Olivelle1992_433-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Olivelle1992-433">&#91;387&#93;</a></sup> The term Śramaṇa refers to several Indian religious movements parallel to but separate from the <a href="/wiki/Historical_Vedic_religion" title="Historical Vedic religion">historical Vedic religion</a>, including Buddhism, <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a> and others such as <a href="/wiki/%C4%80j%C4%ABvika" title="Ājīvika">Ājīvika</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">&#91;388&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Several Śramaṇa movements are known to have existed in India before the 6th century BCE (pre-Buddha, pre-<a href="/wiki/Mahavira" title="Mahavira">Mahavira</a>), and these influenced both the <a href="/wiki/%C4%80stika_and_n%C4%81stika" title="Āstika and nāstika">āstika and nāstika</a> traditions of <a href="/wiki/Indian_philosophy" title="Indian philosophy">Indian philosophy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-reginaldray247_435-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reginaldray247-435">&#91;389&#93;</a></sup> According to Martin Wilshire, the Śramaṇa tradition evolved in India over two phases, namely <a href="/wiki/Pratyekabuddha" title="Pratyekabuddha">Paccekabuddha</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C4%81vaka" title="Śrāvaka">Savaka</a> phases, the former being the tradition of individual ascetic and the latter of disciples, and that Buddhism and <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a> ultimately emerged from these.<sup id="cite_ref-wiltshire293_436-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wiltshire293-436">&#91;390&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Historical_Vedic_religion" title="Historical Vedic religion">Brahmanical</a> and non-Brahmanical ascetic groups shared and used several similar ideas,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2010123–125_437-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2010123–125-437">&#91;391&#93;</a></sup> but the Śramaṇa traditions also drew upon already established Brahmanical concepts and philosophical roots, states Wiltshire, to formulate their own doctrines.<sup id="cite_ref-reginaldray247_435-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reginaldray247-435">&#91;389&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wiltshire226_438-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wiltshire226-438">&#91;392&#93;</a></sup> Brahmanical motifs can be found in the oldest Buddhist texts, using them to introduce and explain Buddhist ideas.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShults2014126_439-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShults2014126-439">&#91;393&#93;</a></sup> For example, prior to Buddhist developments, the Brahmanical tradition internalised and variously reinterpreted the <a href="/wiki/Srauta" class="mw-redirect" title="Srauta">three Vedic sacrificial fires</a> as concepts such as Truth, Rite, Tranquility or Restraint.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShults2014127_440-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShults2014127-440">&#91;394&#93;</a></sup> Buddhist texts also refer to the three Vedic sacrificial fires, reinterpreting and explaining them as ethical conduct.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShults2014125–129_441-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShults2014125–129-441">&#91;395&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Śramaṇa religions challenged and broke with the Brahmanic tradition on core assumptions such as <a href="/wiki/Atman_(Hinduism)" class="mw-redirect" title="Atman (Hinduism)">Atman</a> (soul, self), <a href="/wiki/Brahman" title="Brahman">Brahman</a>, the nature of afterlife, and they rejected the authority of the <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Upanishad" class="mw-redirect" title="Upanishad">Upanishads</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442">&#91;396&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJaini200147–48_443-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJaini200147–48-443">&#91;397&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Siderits2007p16_444-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Siderits2007p16-444">&#91;398&#93;</a></sup> Buddhism was one among several Indian religions that did so.<sup id="cite_ref-Siderits2007p16_444-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Siderits2007p16-444">&#91;398&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rock-cut_Lord_--Buddha--_Statue_at_Bojjanakonda_near_Anakapalle_of_Visakhapatnam_dist_in_AP.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Rock-cut Lord Buddha statue at Bojjanakonda near Anakapalle India" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Rock-cut_Lord_--Buddha--_Statue_at_Bojjanakonda_near_Anakapalle_of_Visakhapatnam_dist_in_AP.jpg/220px-Rock-cut_Lord_--Buddha--_Statue_at_Bojjanakonda_near_Anakapalle_of_Visakhapatnam_dist_in_AP.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Rock-cut_Lord_--Buddha--_Statue_at_Bojjanakonda_near_Anakapalle_of_Visakhapatnam_dist_in_AP.jpg/330px-Rock-cut_Lord_--Buddha--_Statue_at_Bojjanakonda_near_Anakapalle_of_Visakhapatnam_dist_in_AP.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Rock-cut_Lord_--Buddha--_Statue_at_Bojjanakonda_near_Anakapalle_of_Visakhapatnam_dist_in_AP.jpg/440px-Rock-cut_Lord_--Buddha--_Statue_at_Bojjanakonda_near_Anakapalle_of_Visakhapatnam_dist_in_AP.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Rock-cut_Lord_--Buddha--_Statue_at_Bojjanakonda_near_Anakapalle_of_Visakhapatnam_dist_in_AP.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Rock-cut Lord Buddha statue at Bojjanakonda near <a href="/wiki/Anakapalle" title="Anakapalle">Anakapalle</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Visakhapatnam" title="Visakhapatnam">Visakhapatnam</a> district of <a href="/wiki/Andhra_Pradesh" title="Andhra Pradesh">Andhra Pradesh</a>, India</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Indian_Buddhism">Indian Buddhism</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Buddhism_in_India" title="History of Buddhism in India">History of Buddhism in India</a></div>
<p>The history of Indian Buddhism may be divided into five periods:<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirakawa19937_445-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirakawa19937-445">&#91;399&#93;</a></sup> Early Buddhism (occasionally called <a href="/wiki/Pre-sectarian_Buddhism" title="Pre-sectarian Buddhism">pre-sectarian Buddhism</a>), <a href="/wiki/Nikaya_Buddhism" title="Nikaya Buddhism">Nikaya Buddhism</a> or Sectarian Buddhism: The period of the early Buddhist schools, Early <a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahayana Buddhism</a>, later Mahayana Buddhism, and <a href="/wiki/Vajrayana" title="Vajrayana">Vajrayana</a> Buddhism.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sanchi_Stupa_No_2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Sanchi_Stupa_No_2.jpg/220px-Sanchi_Stupa_No_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Sanchi_Stupa_No_2.jpg/330px-Sanchi_Stupa_No_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Sanchi_Stupa_No_2.jpg/440px-Sanchi_Stupa_No_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4609" data-file-height="3073" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Sanchi_Stupa_No_2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Sanchi Stupa</div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Pre-sectarian_Buddhism">Pre-sectarian Buddhism</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Pre-sectarian_Buddhism" title="Pre-sectarian Buddhism">Pre-sectarian Buddhism</a></div>
<p>According to <a href="/wiki/Lambert_Schmithausen" title="Lambert Schmithausen">Lambert Schmithausen</a> Pre-sectarian Buddhism is "the canonical period prior to the development of different schools with their different positions."<sup id="cite_ref-446" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-446">&#91;400&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Early_Buddhist_Texts" title="Early Buddhist Texts">early Buddhist Texts</a> include the four principal <a href="/wiki/Nik%C4%81ya" title="Nikāya">Nikāyas</a> <sup id="cite_ref-447" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-447">&#91;note 37&#93;</a></sup> (and their parallel <a href="/wiki/%C4%80gama_(Buddhism)" title="Āgama (Buddhism)">Agamas</a>) together with the main body of monastic rules, which survive in the various versions of the <a href="/wiki/Patimokkha" class="mw-redirect" title="Patimokkha">patimokkha</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESujatoBrahmali201539–41_448-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESujatoBrahmali201539–41-448">&#91;401&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin2008xviii_449-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin2008xviii-449">&#91;402&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-450" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450">&#91;403&#93;</a></sup> However, these texts were revised over time, and it is unclear what constitutes the earliest layer of Buddhist teachings. One method to obtain information on the oldest core of Buddhism is to compare the oldest extant versions of the Theravadin Pāli Canon and other texts.<sup id="cite_ref-453" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-453">&#91;note 38&#93;</a></sup> The reliability of the early sources, and the possibility to draw out a core of oldest teachings, is a matter of dispute.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi–xxxvii_296-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi–xxxvii-296">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup> According to Vetter, inconsistencies remain, and other methods must be applied to resolve those inconsistencies.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988ix_451-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988ix-451">&#91;404&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-456" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-456">&#91;note 39&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Schmithausen, three positions held by scholars of Buddhism can be distinguished:<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993vii_457-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993vii-457">&#91;408&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<ol><li>"Stress on the fundamental homogeneity and substantial authenticity of at least a considerable part of the Nikayic materials;"<sup id="cite_ref-462" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-462">&#91;note 40&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>"Scepticism with regard to the possibility of retrieving the doctrine of earliest Buddhism;"<sup id="cite_ref-465" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-465">&#91;note 41&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>"Cautious optimism in this respect."<sup id="cite_ref-472" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-472">&#91;note 42&#93;</a></sup></li></ol>
<h5><span class="mw-headline" id="Core_teachings">Core teachings</span></h5>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Buddhist_Chakras_at_ASI_Museum,_Amaravathi.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Buddhist_Chakras_at_ASI_Museum%2C_Amaravathi.jpg/220px-Buddhist_Chakras_at_ASI_Museum%2C_Amaravathi.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Buddhist_Chakras_at_ASI_Museum%2C_Amaravathi.jpg/330px-Buddhist_Chakras_at_ASI_Museum%2C_Amaravathi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Buddhist_Chakras_at_ASI_Museum%2C_Amaravathi.jpg/440px-Buddhist_Chakras_at_ASI_Museum%2C_Amaravathi.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3456" data-file-height="2304" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Buddhist_Chakras_at_ASI_Museum,_Amaravathi.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Buddhist Chakras at ASI Museum, Amaravathi</div></div></div>
<p>According to Mitchell, certain basic teachings appear in many places throughout the early texts, which has led most scholars to conclude that Gautama Buddha must have taught something similar to the <a href="/wiki/Four_Noble_Truths" title="Four Noble Truths">Four Noble Truths</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Noble_Eightfold_Path" title="Noble Eightfold Path">Noble Eightfold Path</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nirvana_(Buddhism)" title="Nirvana (Buddhism)">Nirvana</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Three_marks_of_existence" title="Three marks of existence">three marks of existence</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Skandha" title="Skandha">five aggregates</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prat%C4%ABtyasamutp%C4%81da" title="Pratītyasamutpāda">dependent origination</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karma_in_Buddhism" title="Karma in Buddhism">karma</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rebirth_(Buddhism)" title="Rebirth (Buddhism)">rebirth</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMitchell200234_473-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMitchell200234-473">&#91;415&#93;</a></sup> Yet critical analysis reveals discrepancies, which point to alternative possibilities.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESkorupski19905_474-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESkorupski19905-474">&#91;416&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst19984,_11_475-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst19984,_11-475">&#91;417&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchopen2002_476-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchopen2002-476">&#91;418&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Bruce Matthews notes that there is no cohesive presentation of karma in the Sutta Pitaka,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMatthews1986124_477-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMatthews1986124-477">&#91;419&#93;</a></sup> which may mean that the doctrine was incidental to the main perspective of early Buddhist soteriology.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMatthews1986124_477-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMatthews1986124-477">&#91;419&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Lambert_Schmithausen" title="Lambert Schmithausen">Schmithausen</a> has questioned whether karma already played a role in the theory of rebirth of earliest Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchmithausen1986_478-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmithausen1986-478">&#91;420&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (March 2015)">page&#160;needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199813_479-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199813-479">&#91;421&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-481" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-481">&#91;note 43&#93;</a></sup> According to Vetter, "the Buddha at first sought "the deathless" (<i>amata/amrta</i>), which is concerned with the here and now. Only later did he become acquainted with the doctrine of rebirth."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst19983_482-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst19983-482">&#91;423&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Johannes_Bronkhorst" title="Johannes Bronkhorst">Bronkhorst</a> disagrees, and concludes that the Buddha "introduced a concept of karma that differed considerably from the commonly held views of his time."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199816_483-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199816-483">&#91;424&#93;</a></sup> According to Bronkhorst, not physical and mental activities as such were seen as responsible for rebirth, but intentions and desire.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199814_484-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199814-484">&#91;425&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Another core problem in the study of early Buddhism is the relation between <i>dhyana</i> and insight.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988_162-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988-162">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993_269-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993-269">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich1997_292-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich1997-292">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup> Schmithausen states that the four noble truths as "liberating insight", may be a later addition to texts such as Majjhima Nikaya 36.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchmithausen1981_295-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmithausen1981-295">&#91;256&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (March 2015)">page&#160;needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199377–78,_Section_8.4.3_485-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199377–78,_Section_8.4.3-485">&#91;426&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter19885,_Quote:_&#91;T&#93;hey_do_not_teach_that_one_is_released_by_knowing_the_four_noble_truths,_but_by_practising_the_fourth_noble_truth,_the_eightfold_path,_which_culminates_in_right_samadhi_486-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter19885,_Quote:_[T]hey_do_not_teach_that_one_is_released_by_knowing_the_four_noble_truths,_but_by_practising_the_fourth_noble_truth,_the_eightfold_path,_which_culminates_in_right_samadhi-486">&#91;427&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to both Bronkhorst and Anderson, the <a href="/wiki/Four_Noble_Truths" title="Four Noble Truths">Four Noble Truths</a> became a substitution for prajna, or "liberating insight", in the suttas<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199399–100,_102–111_487-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199399–100,_102–111-487">&#91;428&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnderson1999_488-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnderson1999-488">&#91;429&#93;</a></sup> in those texts where "liberating insight" was preceded by the four jhānas.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993108_489-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993108-489">&#91;430&#93;</a></sup> The four truths may not have been formulated in earliest Buddhism, and did not serve in earliest Buddhism as a description of "liberating insight".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993107_490-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993107-490">&#91;431&#93;</a></sup> Gotama's teachings may have been personal, "adjusted to the need of each person."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993108_489-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993108-489">&#91;430&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Three_marks_of_existence" title="Three marks of existence">three marks of existence</a> – Dukkha, Annica, Anatta – may reflect Upanishadic or other influences. <a href="/wiki/K._R._Norman" title="K. R. Norman">K.R. Norman</a> supposes that these terms were already in use at the Buddha's time, and were familiar to his hearers.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENorman199726_491-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorman199726-491">&#91;432&#93;</a></sup> According to Vetter, the description of the Buddhist path may initially have been as simple as the term "the middle way".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988_162-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988-162">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup> In time, this short description was elaborated, resulting in the description of the eightfold path.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988_162-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988-162">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup> Similarly nibbāna is the common term for the desired goal of this practice, yet many other terms can be found throughout the Nikāyas, which are not specified.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xv_492-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xv-492">&#91;433&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-493" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-493">&#91;note 44&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Buddhist_schools">Early Buddhist schools</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Early_Buddhist_schools" title="Early Buddhist schools">Early Buddhist schools</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_councils" title="Buddhist councils">Buddhist councils</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%E5%9B%BA%E5%8E%9F%E9%A1%BB%E5%BC%A5%E5%B1%B1%E7%9F%B3%E7%AA%9F%E7%AC%AC5%E7%AA%9F%E5%A4%A7%E4%BD%9B%E6%A5%BC.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/%E5%9B%BA%E5%8E%9F%E9%A1%BB%E5%BC%A5%E5%B1%B1%E7%9F%B3%E7%AA%9F%E7%AC%AC5%E7%AA%9F%E5%A4%A7%E4%BD%9B%E6%A5%BC.JPG/220px-%E5%9B%BA%E5%8E%9F%E9%A1%BB%E5%BC%A5%E5%B1%B1%E7%9F%B3%E7%AA%9F%E7%AC%AC5%E7%AA%9F%E5%A4%A7%E4%BD%9B%E6%A5%BC.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/%E5%9B%BA%E5%8E%9F%E9%A1%BB%E5%BC%A5%E5%B1%B1%E7%9F%B3%E7%AA%9F%E7%AC%AC5%E7%AA%9F%E5%A4%A7%E4%BD%9B%E6%A5%BC.JPG/330px-%E5%9B%BA%E5%8E%9F%E9%A1%BB%E5%BC%A5%E5%B1%B1%E7%9F%B3%E7%AA%9F%E7%AC%AC5%E7%AA%9F%E5%A4%A7%E4%BD%9B%E6%A5%BC.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/%E5%9B%BA%E5%8E%9F%E9%A1%BB%E5%BC%A5%E5%B1%B1%E7%9F%B3%E7%AA%9F%E7%AC%AC5%E7%AA%9F%E5%A4%A7%E4%BD%9B%E6%A5%BC.JPG/440px-%E5%9B%BA%E5%8E%9F%E9%A1%BB%E5%BC%A5%E5%B1%B1%E7%9F%B3%E7%AA%9F%E7%AC%AC5%E7%AA%9F%E5%A4%A7%E4%BD%9B%E6%A5%BC.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="768" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:%E5%9B%BA%E5%8E%9F%E9%A1%BB%E5%BC%A5%E5%B1%B1%E7%9F%B3%E7%AA%9F%E7%AC%AC5%E7%AA%9F%E5%A4%A7%E4%BD%9B%E6%A5%BC.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Buddha at <a href="/wiki/Xumishan_Grottoes" title="Xumishan Grottoes">Xumishan Grottoes</a>, c. 6th century CE<sup id="cite_ref-494" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-494">&#91;434&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>According to the scriptures, soon after the <a href="/wiki/Parinirvana" title="Parinirvana"><i lang="sa-Latn" title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration">parinirvāṇa</i></a> (from Sanskrit: "highest extinguishment") of Gautama Buddha, the <a href="/wiki/First_Buddhist_council" title="First Buddhist council">first Buddhist council</a> was held. As with any ancient Indian tradition, transmission of teaching was done orally. The primary purpose of the assembly was to collectively recite the teachings to ensure that no errors occurred in oral transmission. <a href="/wiki/Richard_Gombrich" title="Richard Gombrich">Richard Gombrich</a> states that the monastic assembly recitations of the Buddha's teaching likely began during Buddha's lifetime, similar to the First Council, that helped compose Buddhist scriptures.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams2005175–176_495-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams2005175–176-495">&#91;435&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Second_Buddhist_council" title="Second Buddhist council">Second Buddhist council</a> resulted in the first schism in the <a href="/wiki/Sangha_(Buddhism)" class="mw-redirect" title="Sangha (Buddhism)">Sangha</a>, probably caused by a group of reformists called <a href="/wiki/Sthavira_nik%C4%81ya" title="Sthavira nikāya">Sthaviras</a> who split from the conservative majority <a href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81s%C4%81%E1%B9%83ghika" title="Mahāsāṃghika">Mahāsāṃghikas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201389–90_496-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201389–90-496">&#91;436&#93;</a></sup> After unsuccessfully trying to modify the <a href="/wiki/Vinaya" title="Vinaya">Vinaya</a>, a small group of "elderly members", i.e. <i>sthaviras</i>, broke away from the majority <a href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81s%C4%81%E1%B9%83ghika" title="Mahāsāṃghika">Mahāsāṃghika</a> during the Second Buddhist council, giving rise to the Sthavira Nikaya.<sup id="cite_ref-497" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-497">&#91;437&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Sthaviras gave rise to several schools, one of which was the <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada</a> school. Originally, these schisms were caused by disputes over monastic disciplinary codes of various fraternities, but eventually, by about 100 CE if not earlier, schisms were being caused by doctrinal disagreements too.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey199074–75_498-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey199074–75-498">&#91;438&#93;</a></sup> Buddhist monks of different fraternities became distinct schools and stopped doing official Sangha business together, but continued to study each other's doctrines.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey199074–75_498-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey199074–75-498">&#91;438&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Following (or leading up to) the schisms, each Saṅgha started to accumulate their own version of <a href="/wiki/Tripi%E1%B9%ADaka" title="Tripiṭaka">Tripiṭaka</a> (Pali Canons, triple basket of texts).<sup id="cite_ref-britannicatipitaka_48-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannicatipitaka-48">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Crandall2012p56_499-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Crandall2012p56-499">&#91;439&#93;</a></sup> In their Tripiṭaka, each school included the Suttas of the Buddha, a Vinaya basket (disciplinary code) and added an <a href="/wiki/Abhidharma" title="Abhidharma">Abhidharma</a> basket which were texts on detailed scholastic classification, summary and interpretation of the Suttas.<sup id="cite_ref-britannicatipitaka_48-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannicatipitaka-48">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201390–91_500-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201390–91-500">&#91;440&#93;</a></sup> The doctrine details in the Abhidharmas of various Buddhist schools differ significantly, and these were composed starting about the third century BCE and through the 1st millennium CE.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201390–93_501-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201390–93-501">&#91;441&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-502" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-502">&#91;442&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2004485_503-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2004485-503">&#91;443&#93;</a></sup> Eighteen early Buddhist schools are known, each with its own Tripitaka, but only one collection from Sri Lanka has survived, in a nearly complete state, into the modern era.<sup id="cite_ref-berkwitz2009p60_504-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-berkwitz2009p60-504">&#91;444&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Mahayana_Buddhism">Early Mahayana Buddhism</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahayana</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BuddhistTriad.JPG" class="image"><img alt="stone statue group, a Buddhist triad depicting, left to right, a Kushan, the future buddha Maitreya, Gautama Buddha, the bodhisattva Avalokiteśvara, and a Buddhist monk. 2nd–3rd century. Guimet Museum" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/BuddhistTriad.JPG/220px-BuddhistTriad.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="134" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/BuddhistTriad.JPG/330px-BuddhistTriad.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/BuddhistTriad.JPG/440px-BuddhistTriad.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1587" data-file-height="970" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:BuddhistTriad.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A Buddhist triad depicting, left to right, a <a href="/wiki/Kushan_Empire" title="Kushan Empire">Kushan</a>, the future buddha <a href="/wiki/Maitreya" title="Maitreya">Maitreya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Gautama Buddha</a>, the bodhisattva <a href="/wiki/Avalokite%C5%9Bvara" title="Avalokiteśvara">Avalokiteśvara</a>, and a <a href="/wiki/Bhikkhu" title="Bhikkhu">monk</a>. Second–third century. <a href="/wiki/Guimet_Museum" title="Guimet Museum">Guimet Museum</a></div></div></div>
<p>Several scholars have suggested that the <a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahayana Buddhist</a> tradition started in south India (modern <a href="/wiki/Andhra_Pradesh" title="Andhra Pradesh">Andhra Pradesh</a>), and it is there that <a href="/wiki/Prajnaparamita" title="Prajnaparamita">Prajnaparamita</a> sutras, among the earliest <a href="/wiki/Mahayana_sutras" title="Mahayana sutras">Mahayana sutras</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-505" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-505">&#91;445&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-506" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-506">&#91;446&#93;</a></sup> developed among the <a href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81s%C4%81%E1%B9%83ghika" title="Mahāsāṃghika">Mahāsāṃghika</a> along the <a href="/wiki/Krishna_River" title="Krishna River">Kṛṣṇa River</a> region about the 1st century BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-507" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-507">&#91;447&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirakawa1993252–253,_263,_268_508-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirakawa1993252–253,_263,_268-508">&#91;448&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-509" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-509">&#91;449&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-512" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-512">&#91;note 45&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>There is no evidence that Mahayana ever referred to a separate formal school or sect of Buddhism, but rather that it existed as a certain set of ideals, and later doctrines, for bodhisattvas.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENattier2003193–194_513-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENattier2003193–194-513">&#91;452&#93;</a></sup> Initially it was known as <i>Bodhisattvayāna</i> (the "Vehicle of the Bodhisattvas").<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown199658,_61_514-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown199658,_61-514">&#91;453&#93;</a></sup> Paul Williams states that the Mahāyāna never had nor ever attempted to have a separate <a href="/wiki/Vinaya" title="Vinaya">Vinaya</a> or ordination codes from the early schools of Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams20084–5_515-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams20084–5-515">&#91;454&#93;</a></sup> Records written by Chinese monks visiting India indicate that both Mahāyāna and non-Mahāyāna monks could be found in the same monasteries, with the difference that Mahayana monks worshipped figures of Bodhisattvas, while non-Mahayana monks did not.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200097_516-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200097-516">&#91;455&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Much of the early extant evidence for the origins of Mahāyāna comes from early Chinese translations of Mahāyāna texts. These Mahayana teachings were first propagated into China by <a href="/wiki/Lokaksema_(Buddhist_monk)" title="Lokaksema (Buddhist monk)">Lokakṣema</a>, the first translator of Mahayana sutras into Chinese during the 2nd century CE.<sup id="cite_ref-China_Buswell_2004_518-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-China_Buswell_2004-518">&#91;note 46&#93;</a></sup> Some scholars have traditionally considered the earliest <a href="/wiki/Mahayana_sutras" title="Mahayana sutras">Mahāyāna sūtras</a> to include the very first versions of the <a href="/wiki/Prajnaparamita" title="Prajnaparamita">Prajnaparamita</a> series, along with texts concerning <a href="/wiki/Akshobhya" title="Akshobhya">Akṣobhya</a>, which were probably composed in the 1st century BCE in the south of India.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirakawa1993252–253,_263,_268_508-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirakawa1993252–253,_263,_268-508">&#91;448&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-South_520-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-South-520">&#91;note 47&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Late_Mahayana_Buddhism">Late Mahayana Buddhism</span></h4>
<p>During the period of Late Mahāyāna, four major types of thought developed: <a href="/wiki/Madhyamaka" title="Madhyamaka">Madhyamaka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yogachara" title="Yogachara">Yogachara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddha-nature" title="Buddha-nature">Tathagatagarbha</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Indian_logic#Buddhist_logic" title="Indian logic">Buddhist logic</a> as the last and most recent.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirakawa19938–9_521-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirakawa19938–9-521">&#91;458&#93;</a></sup> In India, the two main philosophical schools of the Mahayana were the Madhyamaka and the later Yogachara.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey199095_522-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey199095-522">&#91;459&#93;</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Dan_Lusthaus" title="Dan Lusthaus">Dan Lusthaus</a>, Madhyamaka and Yogachara have a great deal in common, and the commonality stems from early Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELusthaus2002236–237_523-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELusthaus2002236–237-523">&#91;460&#93;</a></sup> There were no great Indian teachers associated with tathagatagarbha thought.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey1990113_524-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey1990113-524">&#91;461&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Vajrayana_.28Esoteric_Buddhism.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Vajrayana_(Esoteric_Buddhism)">Vajrayana (Esoteric Buddhism)</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Vajrayana" title="Vajrayana">Vajrayana</a></div>
<p>Scholarly research concerning <a href="/wiki/Vajrayana" title="Vajrayana">Esoteric Buddhism</a> is still in its early stages and has a number of problems that make research difficult:<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirakawa19939_525-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirakawa19939-525">&#91;462&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<ol><li>Vajrayana Buddhism was influenced by <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>, and therefore research must include exploring Hinduism as well.</li>
<li>The scriptures of Vajrayana have not yet been put in any kind of order.</li>
<li>Ritual must be examined as well, not just doctrine.</li></ol>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Spread_of_Buddhism">Spread of Buddhism</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Buddhism" title="Timeline of Buddhism">Timeline of Buddhism</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r889293853/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{text-align:left;background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:431px;max-width:431px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:155px;max-width:155px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Asoka%CC%A0_Buddhist_Missions.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Asoka%CC%A0_Buddhist_Missions.png/153px-Asoka%CC%A0_Buddhist_Missions.png" decoding="async" width="153" height="157" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Asoka%CC%A0_Buddhist_Missions.png/230px-Asoka%CC%A0_Buddhist_Missions.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Asoka%CC%A0_Buddhist_Missions.png/306px-Asoka%CC%A0_Buddhist_Missions.png 2x" data-file-width="1252" data-file-height="1284" /></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:272px;max-width:272px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Buddhism_Growth_in_Hellenic_World.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Buddhism_Growth_in_Hellenic_World.png/270px-Buddhism_Growth_in_Hellenic_World.png" decoding="async" width="270" height="157" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Buddhism_Growth_in_Hellenic_World.png/405px-Buddhism_Growth_in_Hellenic_World.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Buddhism_Growth_in_Hellenic_World.png/540px-Buddhism_Growth_in_Hellenic_World.png 2x" data-file-width="20000" data-file-height="11624" /></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:left;background-color:transparent">The spread of Buddhism within <a href="/wiki/South_Asia" title="South Asia">South Asia</a> and beyond.</div></div></div></div>
<p>Buddhism may have spread only slowly in India until the time of the <a href="/wiki/Maurya_Empire" title="Maurya Empire">Mauryan</a> emperor <a href="/wiki/Ashoka" title="Ashoka">Ashoka</a>, who was a public supporter of the religion. The support of Aśoka and his descendants led to the construction of more <a href="/wiki/Stupa" title="Stupa">stūpas</a> (Buddhist religious memorials) and to its spread throughout the <a href="/wiki/Maurya_Empire" title="Maurya Empire">Maurya empire</a> and into neighbouring lands such as <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a> and to the island of <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a>. These two missions, in opposite directions, would ultimately lead, in the first case to the spread of Buddhism into China, Korea and Japan, and in the second case, to the emergence of Sinhalese <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravāda Buddhism</a> and its spread from <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a> to much of Southeast Asia.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a href="/wiki/File:MenandrosCoin.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Coin depicting Indo-Greek king Menander facing right with headband" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/MenandrosCoin.jpg/190px-MenandrosCoin.jpg" decoding="async" width="190" height="185" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/MenandrosCoin.jpg/285px-MenandrosCoin.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/MenandrosCoin.jpg/380px-MenandrosCoin.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1079" data-file-height="1052" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:MenandrosCoin.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Coin depicting <a href="/wiki/Indo-Greek" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Greek">Indo-Greek</a> king <a href="/wiki/Menander_I" title="Menander I">Menander</a>, who, according to Buddhist tradition records in the <a href="/wiki/Milinda_Panha" title="Milinda Panha">Milinda Panha</a>, converted to the Buddhist faith and became an <a href="/wiki/Arhat" title="Arhat">arhat</a> in the 2nd century BCE (<a href="/wiki/British_Museum" title="British Museum">British Museum</a>)</div></div></div>
<p>This period marks the first known spread of Buddhism beyond India. According to the <a href="/wiki/Edicts_of_Ashoka" title="Edicts of Ashoka">edicts of Aśoka</a>, emissaries were sent to various countries west of India to spread Buddhism (Dharma), particularly in eastern provinces of the neighbouring <a href="/wiki/Seleucid_Empire" title="Seleucid Empire">Seleucid Empire</a>, and even farther to <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Hellenistic civilization">Hellenistic</a> kingdoms of the Mediterranean. It is a matter of disagreement among scholars whether or not these emissaries were accompanied by Buddhist missionaries.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich2006135_526-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich2006135-526">&#91;463&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In central and west Asia, Buddhist influence grew, through Greek-speaking Buddhist monarchs and ancient Asian trade routes. An example of this is evidenced in Chinese and Pali Buddhist records, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Milinda_Panha" title="Milinda Panha">Milindapanha</a></i> and the <a href="/wiki/Greco-Buddhist_art" title="Greco-Buddhist art">Greco-Buddhist art</a> of <a href="/wiki/Gandhara" title="Gandhara">Gandhāra</a>. The <i>Milindapanha</i> describes a conversation between a Buddhist monk and the 2nd-century BCE Greek king <a href="/wiki/Menander_I" title="Menander I">Menander</a>, after which Menander abdicates and himself goes into monastic life in the pursuit of nirvana.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor2004103,_119_527-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor2004103,_119-527">&#91;464&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-528" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-528">&#91;465&#93;</a></sup> Some scholars have questioned the <i>Milindapanha</i> version, expressing doubts whether Menander was Buddhist or just favourably disposed to Buddhist monks.<sup id="cite_ref-529" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-529">&#91;466&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Kushan_Empire" title="Kushan Empire">Kushans</a> (mid 1st–3rd century CE) came to control the Silk Road trade through Central and South Asia, which brought them to interact with ancient Buddhist monasteries and societies involved in trade in these regions. They patronised Buddhist institutions, and Buddhist monastery influence, in turn, expanded into a world religion, according to Xinru Liu.<sup id="cite_ref-Liu2010p42_530-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Liu2010p42-530">&#91;467&#93;</a></sup> Buddhism spread to <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Khotan" title="Kingdom of Khotan">Khotan</a> and China, eventually to other parts of the far east.<sup id="cite_ref-531" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-531">&#91;468&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Some of the earliest written documents of the Buddhist faith are the <a href="/wiki/Gandharan_Buddhist_texts" class="mw-redirect" title="Gandharan Buddhist texts">Gandharan Buddhist texts</a>, dating from about the 1st century CE, and connected to the <a href="/wiki/Dharmaguptaka" title="Dharmaguptaka">Dharmaguptaka</a> school. These texts are written in the <a href="/wiki/Kharosthi" title="Kharosthi">Kharosthi</a> script, a script that was predominantly used in the <a href="/wiki/Greco-Bactrian" class="mw-redirect" title="Greco-Bactrian">Greco-Bactrian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indo-Greek" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-Greek">Indo-Greek</a> kingdoms of northern India and that played a prominent role in the coinage and inscriptions of their kings.<sup id="cite_ref-Warder,_A.K._2000._p._278_532-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Warder,_A.K._2000._p._278-532">&#91;469&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-533" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-533">&#91;470&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-534" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-534">&#91;471&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Persia" title="Muslim conquest of Persia">Islamic conquest</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Iranian_Plateau" title="Iranian Plateau">Iranian Plateau</a> in the 7th-century, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquests_of_Afghanistan" title="Muslim conquests of Afghanistan">Muslim conquests of Afghanistan</a> and the later establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Ghaznavids" title="Ghaznavids">Ghaznavid kingdom</a> with Islam as the state religion in Central Asia between the 10th- and 12th-century led to the decline and disappearance of Buddhism from most of these regions.<sup id="cite_ref-Kudara2002_535-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kudara2002-535">&#91;472&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="To_East_and_Southeast_Asia">To East and Southeast Asia</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:WhiteHorseTemple.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/WhiteHorseTemple.jpg/220px-WhiteHorseTemple.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="179" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/WhiteHorseTemple.jpg/330px-WhiteHorseTemple.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/WhiteHorseTemple.jpg/440px-WhiteHorseTemple.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2360" data-file-height="1920" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:WhiteHorseTemple.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/White_Horse_Temple" title="White Horse Temple">White Horse Temple</a> (est. 68 CE), traditionally held to be at the origin of Chinese Buddhism.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Prasat_Bayon_2014.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Prasat_Bayon_2014.JPG/220px-Prasat_Bayon_2014.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Prasat_Bayon_2014.JPG/330px-Prasat_Bayon_2014.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Prasat_Bayon_2014.JPG/440px-Prasat_Bayon_2014.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2000" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Prasat_Bayon_2014.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Angkor_Thom" title="Angkor Thom">Angkor Thom</a> build by <a href="/wiki/Khmer_Empire" title="Khmer Empire">Khmer</a> King <a href="/wiki/Jayavarman_VII" title="Jayavarman VII">Jayavarman VII</a> (c. 1120–1218).</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road_transmission_of_Buddhism" title="Silk Road transmission of Buddhism">Silk Road transmission of Buddhism</a> to China is most commonly thought to have started in the late 2nd or the 1st century CE, though the literary sources are all open to question.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZürcher197222–27_536-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZürcher197222–27-536">&#91;473&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hill_538-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hill-538">&#91;note 48&#93;</a></sup> The first documented translation efforts by foreign <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_monk" class="mw-redirect" title="Buddhist monk">Buddhist monks</a> in China were in the 2nd century CE, probably as a consequence of the expansion of the <a href="/wiki/Kushan_Empire" title="Kushan Empire">Kushan Empire</a> into the Chinese territory of the <a href="/wiki/Tarim_Basin" title="Tarim Basin">Tarim Basin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZürcher197223_539-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZürcher197223-539">&#91;475&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The first documented Buddhist texts translated into Chinese are those of the Parthian <a href="/wiki/An_Shigao" title="An Shigao">An Shigao</a> (148–180 CE).<sup id="cite_ref-540" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-540">&#91;476&#93;</a></sup> The first known <a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahāyāna</a> scriptural texts are translations into Chinese by the Kushan monk <a href="/wiki/Lokaksema_(Buddhist_monk)" title="Lokaksema (Buddhist monk)">Lokakṣema</a> in <a href="/wiki/Luoyang" title="Luoyang">Luoyang</a>, between 178 and 189 CE.<sup id="cite_ref-541" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-541">&#91;477&#93;</a></sup> From China, Buddhism was introduced into its neighbours <a href="/wiki/Korea" title="Korea">Korea</a> (4th century), <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a> (6th–7th centuries), and <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a> (c. 1st–2nd centuries).<sup id="cite_ref-Dykstra,_Yoshiko_Kurata_2001_p._100_542-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dykstra,_Yoshiko_Kurata_2001_p._100-542">&#91;478&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-543" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-543">&#91;479&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Dykstra,_Yoshiko_Kurata_2001_p._100_542-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dykstra,_Yoshiko_Kurata_2001_p._100-542">&#91;478&#93;</a></sup>
