</p><p>During the Chinese <a href="/wiki/Tang_dynasty" title="Tang dynasty">Tang dynasty</a> (618–907), <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Esoteric_Buddhism" title="Chinese Esoteric Buddhism">Chinese Esoteric Buddhism</a> was introduced from India and <a href="/wiki/Chan_Buddhism" title="Chan Buddhism">Chan Buddhism</a> (Zen) became a major religion.<sup id="cite_ref-544" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-544">&#91;480&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-545" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-545">&#91;481&#93;</a></sup> Chan continued to grow in the <a href="/wiki/Song_dynasty" title="Song dynasty">Song dynasty</a> (960–1279) and it was during this era that it strongly influenced Korean Buddhism and Japanese Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-546" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-546">&#91;482&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pure_Land_Buddhism" title="Pure Land Buddhism">Pure Land Buddhism</a> also became popular during this period and was often practised together with Chan.<sup id="cite_ref-547" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-547">&#91;483&#93;</a></sup> It was also during the Song that the entire <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Buddhist_canon" title="Chinese Buddhist canon">Chinese canon</a> was printed using over 130,000 wooden printing blocks.<sup id="cite_ref-548" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-548">&#91;484&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>During the Indian period of Esoteric Buddhism (from the 8th century onwards), Buddhism spread from India to Tibet and <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a>. Johannes Bronkhorst states that the esoteric form was attractive because it allowed both a secluded monastic community as well as the social rites and rituals important to laypersons and to kings for the maintenance of a political state during succession and wars to resist invasion.<sup id="cite_ref-Bronkhorst2011_549-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bronkhorst2011-549">&#91;485&#93;</a></sup> During the Middle Ages, Buddhism slowly declined in India,<sup id="cite_ref-550" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-550">&#91;486&#93;</a></sup> while it vanished from Persia and Central Asia as Islam became the state religion.<sup id="cite_ref-larsfogelin6_551-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-larsfogelin6-551">&#91;487&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-552" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-552">&#91;488&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada</a> school arrived in Sri Lanka sometime in the 3rd century BCE. Sri Lanka became a base for its later spread to <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">southeast Asia</a> after the 5th century CE (<a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a> and coastal <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-553" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-553">&#91;489&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-554" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-554">&#91;490&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada Buddhism</a> was the dominant religion in <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Burma</a> during the Mon <a href="/wiki/Hanthawaddy_Kingdom" title="Hanthawaddy Kingdom">Hanthawaddy Kingdom</a> (1287–1552).<sup id="cite_ref-555" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-555">&#91;491&#93;</a></sup> It also became dominant in the <a href="/wiki/Khmer_Empire" title="Khmer Empire">Khmer Empire</a> during the 13th and 14th centuries and in the Thai <a href="/wiki/Sukhothai_Kingdom" title="Sukhothai Kingdom">Sukhothai Kingdom</a> during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Ram_Khamhaeng" title="Ram Khamhaeng">Ram Khamhaeng</a> (1237/1247–1298).<sup id="cite_ref-556" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-556">&#91;492&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-557" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-557">&#91;493&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Schools_and_traditions">Schools and traditions</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Schools_of_Buddhism" title="Schools of Buddhism">Schools of Buddhism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Buddhahood" title="Buddhahood">Buddhahood</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Buddhist_sects.png" class="image"><img alt="color map showing Buddhism is a major religion worldwide" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Buddhist_sects.png/280px-Buddhist_sects.png" decoding="async" width="280" height="221" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Buddhist_sects.png/420px-Buddhist_sects.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Buddhist_sects.png/560px-Buddhist_sects.png 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="791" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Buddhist_sects.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Distribution of major Buddhist traditions</div></div></div>
<p>Buddhists generally classify themselves as either <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada</a> or <a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahayana</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown199612_558-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown199612-558">&#91;494&#93;</a></sup> This classification is also used by some scholars<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESmith2006_559-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmith2006-559">&#91;495&#93;</a></sup> and is the one ordinarily used in the English language.<sup id="cite_ref-560" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-560">&#91;web 10&#93;</a></sup> An alternative scheme used by some scholars<sup id="cite_ref-alternative_scheme_561-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-alternative_scheme-561">&#91;note 49&#93;</a></sup> divides Buddhism into the following three traditions or geographical or cultural areas: <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada</a>, <a href="/wiki/East_Asian_Buddhism" title="East Asian Buddhism">East Asian Buddhism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism" title="Tibetan Buddhism">Tibetan Buddhism</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Preah_Pithu_T_Monks_-_Siem_Reap.jpg" class="image"><img alt="monks in orange robes on stone steps in Cambodia" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Preah_Pithu_T_Monks_-_Siem_Reap.jpg/220px-Preah_Pithu_T_Monks_-_Siem_Reap.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Preah_Pithu_T_Monks_-_Siem_Reap.jpg/330px-Preah_Pithu_T_Monks_-_Siem_Reap.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Preah_Pithu_T_Monks_-_Siem_Reap.jpg/440px-Preah_Pithu_T_Monks_-_Siem_Reap.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4896" data-file-height="3264" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Preah_Pithu_T_Monks_-_Siem_Reap.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Young monks in <a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a></div></div></div>
<p>Some scholars<sup id="cite_ref-other_schemes_563-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-other_schemes-563">&#91;note 50&#93;</a></sup> use other schemes. Buddhists themselves have a variety of other schemes. <a href="/wiki/Hinayana" title="Hinayana">Hinayana</a> (literally "lesser or inferior vehicle") is used by Mahayana followers to name the family of early philosophical schools and traditions from which contemporary Theravada emerged, but as the Hinayana term is considered derogatory, a variety of other terms are used instead, including <a href="/wiki/Shravakayana" class="mw-redirect" title="Shravakayana">Śrāvakayāna</a>, Nikaya Buddhism, early Buddhist schools, sectarian Buddhism and conservative Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-kwmorganp410_564-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kwmorganp410-564">&#91;497&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-565" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-565">&#91;498&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Not all traditions of Buddhism share the same philosophical outlook, or treat the same concepts as central. Each tradition, however, does have its own core concepts, and some comparisons can be drawn between them:<sup id="cite_ref-566" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-566">&#91;499&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-567" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-567">&#91;500&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li>Both Theravada and Mahayana traditions accept <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">the Buddha</a> as the founder, Theravada considers him unique, but Mahayana considers him one of many Buddhas</li>
<li>Both accept the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Way" title="Middle Way">Middle Way</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prat%C4%ABtyasamutp%C4%81da" title="Pratītyasamutpāda">dependent origination</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Four_Noble_Truths" title="Four Noble Truths">Four Noble Truths</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Noble_Eightfold_Path" title="Noble Eightfold Path">Noble Eightfold Path</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Three_marks_of_existence" title="Three marks of existence">three marks of existence</a></li>
<li>Nirvana is attainable by the monks in Theravada tradition, while Mahayana considers it broadly attainable; Arhat state is aimed for in the Theravada, while Buddhahood is aimed for in the Mahayana</li>
<li>Religious practice consists of meditation for monks and prayer for laypersons in Theravada, while Mahayana includes prayer, chanting and meditation for both</li>
<li>Theravada has been a more rationalist, historical form of Buddhism; while Mahayana has included more rituals, mysticism and worldly flexibility in its scope.<sup id="cite_ref-568" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-568">&#91;501&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Timeline">Timeline</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Buddhism#Common_Era" title="Timeline of Buddhism">Timeline of Buddhism: Common Era</a></div>
<p>This is a rough timeline of the development of the different schools/traditions:
</p>

</tbody></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Theravada_school">Theravada school</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:A_young_monk_against_the_background_of_Big_Buddha_statue_in_Weherahena_Temple._Matara,_Southern_Province,_Sri_Lanka.jpg" class="image"><img alt="A young monk in saffron robes standing in Sri Lanka temple" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/A_young_monk_against_the_background_of_Big_Buddha_statue_in_Weherahena_Temple._Matara%2C_Southern_Province%2C_Sri_Lanka.jpg/220px-A_young_monk_against_the_background_of_Big_Buddha_statue_in_Weherahena_Temple._Matara%2C_Southern_Province%2C_Sri_Lanka.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="331" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/A_young_monk_against_the_background_of_Big_Buddha_statue_in_Weherahena_Temple._Matara%2C_Southern_Province%2C_Sri_Lanka.jpg/330px-A_young_monk_against_the_background_of_Big_Buddha_statue_in_Weherahena_Temple._Matara%2C_Southern_Province%2C_Sri_Lanka.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/A_young_monk_against_the_background_of_Big_Buddha_statue_in_Weherahena_Temple._Matara%2C_Southern_Province%2C_Sri_Lanka.jpg/440px-A_young_monk_against_the_background_of_Big_Buddha_statue_in_Weherahena_Temple._Matara%2C_Southern_Province%2C_Sri_Lanka.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1996" data-file-height="3000" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:A_young_monk_against_the_background_of_Big_Buddha_statue_in_Weherahena_Temple._Matara,_Southern_Province,_Sri_Lanka.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A young <a href="/wiki/Bhikkhu" title="Bhikkhu">bhikkhu</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a></div></div></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada</a></div>
<p>The Theravada tradition traces its roots to the words of the Buddha preserved in the Pali Canon, and considers itself to be the more orthodox form of Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-572" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-572">&#91;503&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-573" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-573">&#91;504&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Theravada flourished in south India and Sri Lanka in ancient times; from there it spread for the first time into mainland southeast Asia about the 11th century into its elite urban centres.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECollins199818_574-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECollins199818-574">&#91;505&#93;</a></sup> By the 13th century, Theravada had spread widely into the rural areas of mainland southeast Asia,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECollins199818_574-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECollins199818-574">&#91;505&#93;</a></sup> displacing Mahayana Buddhism and some traditions of Hinduism which had arrived in places such as Thailand, Cambodia, Vietnam, Indonesia and Malaysia around the mid-1st millennium CE. The later traditions were well established in south Thailand and Java by the 7th century, under the sponsorship of the Srivijaya dynasty.<sup id="cite_ref-575" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-575">&#91;506&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-576" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-576">&#91;507&#93;</a></sup> The political separation between Khmer and Sukhothai led the Sukhothai king to welcome Sri Lankan emissaries, helping them establish the first Theravada Buddhist <i>sangha</i> in the 13th century, in contrast to the Mahayana tradition of Khmer earlier.<sup id="cite_ref-577" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-577">&#91;508&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Sinhalese Buddhist reformers in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries portrayed the <a href="/wiki/Pali_Canon" class="mw-redirect" title="Pali Canon">Pali Canon</a> as the original version of scripture. They also emphasised Theravada being rational and scientific.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel200816–17_578-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel200816–17-578">&#91;509&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Theravāda is primarily practised today in <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Sri_Lanka" title="Buddhism in Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Burma" class="mw-redirect" title="Buddhism in Burma">Burma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Laos" title="Buddhism in Laos">Laos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Thailand" title="Buddhism in Thailand">Thailand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Cambodia" title="Buddhism in Cambodia">Cambodia</a> as well as small portions of China, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Vietnam" title="Buddhism in Vietnam">Vietnam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Malaysia" title="Buddhism in Malaysia">Malaysia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Bangladesh" title="Buddhism in Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a>. It has a growing presence in the west.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mahayana_traditions">Mahayana traditions</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahayana</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Tsapa_Namgyal_-_The_Teacher_and_Philosopher_Nagarjuna_-_Walters_543008.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Nagarjuna, a Mahayana scholar" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Tsapa_Namgyal_-_The_Teacher_and_Philosopher_Nagarjuna_-_Walters_543008.jpg/220px-Tsapa_Namgyal_-_The_Teacher_and_Philosopher_Nagarjuna_-_Walters_543008.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="327" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Tsapa_Namgyal_-_The_Teacher_and_Philosopher_Nagarjuna_-_Walters_543008.jpg/330px-Tsapa_Namgyal_-_The_Teacher_and_Philosopher_Nagarjuna_-_Walters_543008.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Tsapa_Namgyal_-_The_Teacher_and_Philosopher_Nagarjuna_-_Walters_543008.jpg/440px-Tsapa_Namgyal_-_The_Teacher_and_Philosopher_Nagarjuna_-_Walters_543008.jpg 2x" data-file-width="768" data-file-height="1142" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Tsapa_Namgyal_-_The_Teacher_and_Philosopher_Nagarjuna_-_Walters_543008.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The ideas of the 2nd century scholar Nagarjuna helped shape the Mahayana traditions.</div></div></div>
<p>Mahayana schools consider the <a href="/wiki/Mahayana_Sutras" class="mw-redirect" title="Mahayana Sutras">Mahayana Sutras</a> as authoritative scriptures and accurate rendering of Buddha's words.<sup id="cite_ref-karlpotter1996p26_416-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-karlpotter1996p26-416">&#91;371&#93;</a></sup> These traditions have been the more liberal form of Buddhism allowing different and new interpretations that emerged over time.<sup id="cite_ref-chengp60_579-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chengp60-579">&#91;510&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Mahayana flourished in India from the time of Ashoka,<sup id="cite_ref-karlpotter1996p26_416-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-karlpotter1996p26-416">&#91;371&#93;</a></sup> through to the dynasty of the <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Guptas</a> (4th to 6th-century). Mahāyāna monastic foundations and centres of learning were established by the Buddhist kings, and the Hindu kings of the Gupta dynasty as evidenced by records left by three Chinese visitors to India.<sup id="cite_ref-scharfe2002p144_580-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scharfe2002p144-580">&#91;511&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-581" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-581">&#91;512&#93;</a></sup> The Gupta dynasty, for example, helped establish the famed <a href="/wiki/Nalanda_University" title="Nalanda University">Nālandā University</a> in Bihar.<sup id="cite_ref-scharfe2002p144_580-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scharfe2002p144-580">&#91;511&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-582" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-582">&#91;513&#93;</a></sup> These monasteries and foundations helped Buddhist scholarship, as well as studies into non-Buddhist traditions and secular subjects such as medicine, host visitors and spread Buddhism into East and Central Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-scharfe2002p144_580-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scharfe2002p144-580">&#91;511&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-higham2014p121_583-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-higham2014p121-583">&#91;514&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Native Mahayana Buddhism is practised today in China, Japan, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Buddhism in Korea">Korea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Singapore" title="Buddhism in Singapore">Singapore</a>, parts of Russia and most of <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a> (also commonly referred to as "Eastern Buddhism"). The Buddhism practised in Tibet, the Himalayan regions, and Mongolia is also Mahayana in origin, but is discussed below under the heading of Vajrayana (also commonly referred to as "Northern Buddhism"). There are a variety of strands in Eastern Buddhism, of which "the Pure Land school of Mahayana is the most widely practised today.".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClarkeBeyer200986_584-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClarkeBeyer200986-584">&#91;515&#93;</a></sup> In most of this area however, they are fused into a single unified form of Buddhism. <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Japan" title="Buddhism in Japan">In Japan in particular</a>, they form separate denominations with the five major ones being: <a href="/wiki/Nichiren_Buddhism" title="Nichiren Buddhism">Nichiren</a>, peculiar to Japan; <a href="/wiki/Pure_Land_Buddhism" title="Pure Land Buddhism">Pure Land</a>; <a href="/wiki/Shingon" class="mw-redirect" title="Shingon">Shingon</a>, a form of Vajrayana; <a href="/wiki/Tendai" title="Tendai">Tendai</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Zen" title="Zen">Zen</a>. In Korea, nearly all Buddhists belong to the <a href="/wiki/Jogye_Order" title="Jogye Order">Chogye school</a>, which is officially Son (Zen), but with substantial elements from other traditions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004430,_435_585-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004430,_435-585">&#91;516&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Vajrayana_traditions">Vajrayana traditions</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Vajrayana" title="Vajrayana">Vajrayana</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Potala_palace21.jpg" class="image"><img alt="7th century Buddhist monastery" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Potala_palace21.jpg/220px-Potala_palace21.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="142" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Potala_palace21.jpg/330px-Potala_palace21.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Potala_palace21.jpg/440px-Potala_palace21.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3504" data-file-height="2268" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Potala_palace21.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>7th-century <a href="/wiki/Potala_Palace" title="Potala Palace">Potala Palace</a> in Lhasa valley symbolises Tibetan Buddhism and is a UNESCO world heritage site.<sup id="cite_ref-586" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-586">&#91;517&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The goal and philosophy of the Vajrayāna remains Mahāyānist, but its methods are seen by its followers as far more powerful, so as to lead to Buddhahood in just one lifetime.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013189_587-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013189-587">&#91;518&#93;</a></sup> The practice of using <a href="/wiki/Mantras" class="mw-redirect" title="Mantras">mantras</a> was adopted from <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>, where they were first used in the <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedas</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013180_588-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013180-588">&#91;519&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Various classes of Vajrayana literature developed as a result of royal courts sponsoring both Buddhism and <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Saivism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-589" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-589">&#91;520&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ma%C3%B1ju%C5%9Br%C4%AB-m%C5%ABla-kalpa" title="Mañjuśrī-mūla-kalpa">Mañjusrimulakalpa</a>, which later came to classified under <a href="/wiki/Outer_Tantras#Kriyatantra" title="Outer Tantras">Kriyatantra</a>, states that mantras taught in the Saiva, Garuda and Vaisnava tantras will be effective if applied by Buddhists since they were all taught originally by <a href="/wiki/Manjushri" title="Manjushri">Manjushri</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-590" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-590">&#91;521&#93;</a></sup> The Guhyasiddhi of Padmavajra, a work associated with the <a href="/wiki/Guhyasam%C4%81ja_tantra" class="mw-redirect" title="Guhyasamāja tantra">Guhyasamaja tradition</a>, prescribes acting as a Saiva guru and initiating members into <a href="/wiki/Shaiva_Siddhanta" title="Shaiva Siddhanta">Saiva Siddhanta</a> scriptures and mandalas.<sup id="cite_ref-591" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-591">&#91;522&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Cakrasa%E1%B9%83vara_Tantra" title="Cakrasaṃvara Tantra">Samvara tantra</a> texts adopted the <a href="/wiki/Hindu_pilgrimage_sites" title="Hindu pilgrimage sites">pitha</a> list from the Saiva text <i>Tantrasadbhava</i>, introducing a copying error where a deity was mistaken for a place.<sup id="cite_ref-592" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-592">&#91;523&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism" title="Tibetan Buddhism">Tibetan Buddhism</a> preserves the Vajrayana teachings of eighth-century India.<sup id="cite_ref-White_2000_21_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-White_2000_21-12">&#91;11&#93;</a></sup> Tantric Buddhism is largely concerned with ritual and meditative practices.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams1989185_593-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams1989185-593">&#91;524&#93;</a></sup> A central feature of Buddhist Tantra is <a href="/wiki/Deity_yoga" title="Deity yoga">deity yoga</a> which includes visualisation and identification with an enlightened <a href="/wiki/Yidam" title="Yidam">yidam</a> or meditation deity and its associated <a href="/wiki/Mandala" title="Mandala">mandala</a>. Another element of Tantra is the need for ritual initiation or empowerment (abhiṣeka) by a <a href="/wiki/Guru" title="Guru">Guru</a> or <a href="/wiki/Lama" title="Lama">Lama</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-594" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-594">&#91;525&#93;</a></sup> Some Tantras like the <a href="/wiki/Guhyasam%C4%81ja_Tantra" title="Guhyasamāja Tantra">Guhyasamāja Tantra</a> features new forms of antinomian ritual practice such as the use taboo substances like alcohol, <a href="/wiki/Karmamudra" class="mw-redirect" title="Karmamudra">sexual yoga</a>, and charnel ground practices which evoke <a href="/wiki/Wrathful_deities" class="mw-redirect" title="Wrathful deities">wrathful deities</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-595" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-595">&#91;526&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2004781_596-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2004781-596">&#91;527&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Zen">Zen</span></h4>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Zen" title="Zen">Zen</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ginkakuji_Temple_Togudo_2009_059.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Ginkaku-ji, a Zen temple in Kyoto, Japan with stone slab bridge over stream" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Ginkakuji_Temple_Togudo_2009_059.jpg/220px-Ginkakuji_Temple_Togudo_2009_059.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Ginkakuji_Temple_Togudo_2009_059.jpg/330px-Ginkakuji_Temple_Togudo_2009_059.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Ginkakuji_Temple_Togudo_2009_059.jpg/440px-Ginkakuji_Temple_Togudo_2009_059.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="960" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ginkakuji_Temple_Togudo_2009_059.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ginkaku-ji" title="Ginkaku-ji">Ginkaku-ji</a>, a Zen temple in <a href="/wiki/Kyoto" title="Kyoto">Kyoto</a>, Japan</div></div></div>
<p>Zen Buddhism (禅), pronounced <i><a href="/wiki/Chinese_Ch%C3%A1n" class="mw-redirect" title="Chinese Chán">Chán</a></i> in Chinese, <i>seon</i> in Korean or <i>zen</i> in Japanese (derived from the Sanskrit term <i>dhyāna</i>, meaning "meditation") is a form of Mahayana Buddhism found in China, Korea and Japan. It lays special emphasis on meditation, and direct discovery of the Buddha-nature.<sup id="cite_ref-chengp60_579-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chengp60-579">&#91;510&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Prebish_598-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Prebish-598">&#91;note 53&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Zen Buddhism is divided into two main schools: <a href="/wiki/Rinzai" class="mw-redirect" title="Rinzai">Rinzai</a> (臨済宗) and <a href="/wiki/S%C5%8Dt%C5%8D" title="Sōtō">Sōtō</a> (曹洞宗), the former greatly favouring the use in meditation on the <a href="/wiki/Koan" class="mw-redirect" title="Koan">koan</a> (公案, a meditative riddle or puzzle) as a device for spiritual break-through, and the latter (while certainly employing koans) focusing more on <i><a href="/wiki/Shikantaza" title="Shikantaza">shikantaza</a></i> or "just sitting".<sup id="cite_ref-Prebish_B_600-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Prebish_B-600">&#91;note 54&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Zen Buddhism is primarily found in Japan, with some presence in South Korea and Vietnam. The scholars of Japanese Soto Zen tradition in recent times have critiqued the mainstream Japanese Buddhism for <i>dhatu-vada</i>, that is assuming things have substantiality, a view they assert to be non-Buddhist and "out of tune with the teachings of non-Self and conditioned arising", states Peter Harvey.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013145,_407–408_601-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2013145,_407–408-601">&#91;530&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Buddhism_in_the_modern_era">Buddhism in the modern era</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_by_country" title="Buddhism by country">Buddhism by country</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_Buddhism" class="mw-redirect" title="Western Buddhism">Western Buddhism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_modernism" title="Buddhist modernism">Buddhist modernism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A5%D1%83%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA.JPG" class="image"><img alt="Buddhist monk in Siberia in robes leaning on railing looking at temple" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/%D0%A5%D1%83%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA.JPG/220px-%D0%A5%D1%83%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/%D0%A5%D1%83%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA.JPG/330px-%D0%A5%D1%83%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/%D0%A5%D1%83%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA.JPG/440px-%D0%A5%D1%83%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3456" data-file-height="2304" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A5%D1%83%D0%B2%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%BA.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Buryats" title="Buryats">Buryat</a> Buddhist monk in <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Colonial_era">Colonial era</span></h3>
<p>Buddhism has faced various challenges and changes during the colonisation of Buddhist states by Christian countries and its persecution under modern states. Like other religions, the findings of modern science has challenged its basic premises. One response to some of these challenges has come to be called <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_modernism" title="Buddhist modernism">Buddhist modernism</a>. Early Buddhist modernist figures such as the American convert <a href="/wiki/Henry_Steel_Olcott" title="Henry Steel Olcott">Henry Olcott</a> (1832– 1907) and <a href="/wiki/Anagarika_Dharmapala" title="Anagarika Dharmapala">Anagarika Dharmapala</a>  (1864–1933) reinterpreted and promoted Buddhism as a scientific and rational religion which they saw as compatible with modern science.<sup id="cite_ref-602" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-602">&#91;531&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/East_Asian_Buddhism" title="East Asian Buddhism">East Asian Buddhism</a> meanwhile suffered under various wars which ravaged China during the modern era, such as the <a href="/wiki/Taiping_Rebellion" title="Taiping Rebellion">Taiping rebellion</a> and the <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> (which also affected <a href="/wiki/Korean_Buddhism" title="Korean Buddhism">Korean Buddhism</a>). During the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)" title="Republic of China (1912–1949)">Republican period</a> (1912–49), a new movement called <a href="/wiki/Humanistic_Buddhism" title="Humanistic Buddhism">Humanistic Buddhism</a> was developed by figures such as <a href="/wiki/Taixu" title="Taixu">Taixu</a> (1899–1947), and though Buddhist institutions were destroyed during the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Revolution" title="Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a> (1966–76), there has been a revival of the religion in China after 1977.<sup id="cite_ref-603" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-603">&#91;532&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Japan" title="Buddhism in Japan">Japanese Buddhism</a> also went through a period of modernisation during the <a href="/wiki/Meiji_period" class="mw-redirect" title="Meiji period">Meiji period</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-604" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-604">&#91;533&#93;</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a> meanwhile, the arrival of <a href="/wiki/Communism" title="Communism">Communist</a> repression to <a href="/wiki/Tibet" title="Tibet">Tibet</a> (1966–1980) and <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a>  (between 1924–1990) had a strong negative impact on Buddhist institutions, though the situation has improved somewhat since the 80s and 90s.<sup id="cite_ref-605" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-605">&#91;534&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Buddhism_in_the_West">Buddhism in the West</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:1893parliament.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/1893parliament.jpg/220px-1893parliament.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="101" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/1893parliament.jpg/330px-1893parliament.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/1893parliament.jpg/440px-1893parliament.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3462" data-file-height="1582" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:1893parliament.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>1893 <a href="/wiki/World_Parliament_of_Religions" class="mw-redirect" title="World Parliament of Religions">World Parliament of Religions</a> in <a href="/wiki/Chicago" title="Chicago">Chicago</a></div></div></div>
<p>While there were some encounters of Western travellers or missionaries such as St. <a href="/wiki/Francis_Xavier" title="Francis Xavier">Francis Xavier</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ippolito_Desideri" title="Ippolito Desideri">Ippolito Desideri</a> with Buddhist cultures, it was not until the 19th century that Buddhism began to be studied by Western scholars. It was the work of pioneering scholars such as <a href="/wiki/Eug%C3%A8ne_Burnouf" title="Eugène Burnouf">Eugène Burnouf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Max_M%C3%BCller" title="Max Müller">Max Müller</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hermann_Oldenberg" title="Hermann Oldenberg">Hermann Oldenberg</a> and <a href="/wiki/Thomas_William_Rhys_Davids" class="mw-redirect" title="Thomas William Rhys Davids">Thomas William Rhys Davids</a> that paved the way for modern <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_studies" title="Buddhist studies">Buddhist studies</a> in the West. The English words such as Buddhism, "Boudhist", "Bauddhist" and Buddhist were coined in the early 19th-century in the West,<sup id="cite_ref-606" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-606">&#91;535&#93;</a></sup> while in 1881, Rhys Davids founded the <a href="/wiki/Pali_Text_Society" title="Pali Text Society">Pali Text Society</a> – an influential Western resource of Buddhist literature in the Pali language and one of the earliest publisher of a journal on <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_studies" title="Buddhist studies">Buddhist studies</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-607" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-607">&#91;536&#93;</a></sup> It was also during the 19th century that Asian Buddhist immigrants (mainly from China and Japan) began to arrive in Western countries such as the United States and Canada, bringing with them their Buddhist religion. This period also saw the first Westerners to formally convert to Buddhism, such as <a href="/wiki/Helena_Blavatsky" title="Helena Blavatsky">Helena Blavatsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Henry_Steel_Olcott" title="Henry Steel Olcott">Henry Steel Olcott</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_608-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-608">&#91;537&#93;</a></sup> An important event in the introduction of Buddhism to the West was the 1893 <a href="/wiki/World_Parliament_of_Religions" class="mw-redirect" title="World Parliament of Religions">World Parliament of Religions</a>, which for the first time saw well-publicized speeches by major Buddhist leaders alongside other religious leaders.
</p><p>The 20th century saw a prolific growth of new Buddhist institutions in Western countries, including the <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_Society,_London" class="mw-redirect" title="Buddhist Society, London">Buddhist Society, London</a> (1924), <a href="/wiki/Das_Buddhistische_Haus" title="Das Buddhistische Haus">Das Buddhistische Haus</a> (1924) and <a href="/wiki/Datsan_Gunzechoinei" title="Datsan Gunzechoinei">Datsan Gunzechoinei</a> in <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg" title="Saint Petersburg">St Petersburg</a>. The publication and translations of Buddhist literature in Western languages thereafter accelerated. After the <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">second world war</a>, further immigration from Asia, globalisation, the <a href="/wiki/Secularisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Secularisation">secularisation</a> on Western culture as well a renewed interest in Buddhism among the 60s <a href="/wiki/Counterculture" title="Counterculture">counterculture</a> led to further growth in Buddhist institutions.<sup id="cite_ref-609" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-609">&#91;538&#93;</a></sup> Influential figures on post-war <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_the_West" title="Buddhism in the West">Western Buddhism</a> include <a href="/wiki/Shunryu_Suzuki" class="mw-redirect" title="Shunryu Suzuki">Shunryu Suzuki</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jack_Kerouac" title="Jack Kerouac">Jack Kerouac</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alan_Watts" title="Alan Watts">Alan Watts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Th%C3%ADch_Nh%E1%BA%A5t_H%E1%BA%A1nh" title="Thích Nhất Hạnh">Thích Nhất Hạnh</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/14th_Dalai_Lama" title="14th Dalai Lama">14th Dalai Lama</a>. While Buddhist institutions have grown, some of the central premises of Buddhism such as the cycles of rebirth and <a href="/wiki/Four_Noble_Truths" title="Four Noble Truths">Four Noble Truths</a> have been problematic in the West.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKonik2009ix_610-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKonik2009ix-610">&#91;539&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHayes2013172_611-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHayes2013172-611">&#91;540&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELamb2001258_612-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELamb2001258-612">&#91;541&#93;</a></sup> In contrast, states Christopher Gowans, for "most ordinary [Asian] Buddhists, today as well as in the past, their basic moral orientation is governed by belief in karma and rebirth".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGowans201418–23,_76–88_613-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGowans201418–23,_76–88-613">&#91;542&#93;</a></sup> Most Asian Buddhist laypersons, states Kevin Trainor, have historically pursued Buddhist rituals and practices seeking better rebirth,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeown200960–63,_74–85,_185–187_614-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeown200960–63,_74–85,_185–187-614">&#91;543&#93;</a></sup> not nirvana or freedom from rebirth.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFowler199965_615-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFowler199965-615">&#91;544&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r889293853/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Nouvelle_g%C3%A9ographie_universelle_-_la_terre_et_les_hommes_(1876)_(14592652167).jpg" class="image"><img alt="Buddha statue in 1896, Bamiyan" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Nouvelle_g%C3%A9ographie_universelle_-_la_terre_et_les_hommes_%281876%29_%2814592652167%29.jpg/200px-Nouvelle_g%C3%A9ographie_universelle_-_la_terre_et_les_hommes_%281876%29_%2814592652167%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="135" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Nouvelle_g%C3%A9ographie_universelle_-_la_terre_et_les_hommes_%281876%29_%2814592652167%29.jpg/300px-Nouvelle_g%C3%A9ographie_universelle_-_la_terre_et_les_hommes_%281876%29_%2814592652167%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Nouvelle_g%C3%A9ographie_universelle_-_la_terre_et_les_hommes_%281876%29_%2814592652167%29.jpg/400px-Nouvelle_g%C3%A9ographie_universelle_-_la_terre_et_les_hommes_%281876%29_%2814592652167%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2848" data-file-height="1928" /></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Destroyed_Statue,_July_17,_2005_at_15-53.jpg" class="image"><img alt="After statue destroyed by Islamist Taliban in 2001" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Destroyed_Statue%2C_July_17%2C_2005_at_15-53.jpg/200px-Destroyed_Statue%2C_July_17%2C_2005_at_15-53.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Destroyed_Statue%2C_July_17%2C_2005_at_15-53.jpg/300px-Destroyed_Statue%2C_July_17%2C_2005_at_15-53.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Destroyed_Statue%2C_July_17%2C_2005_at_15-53.jpg/400px-Destroyed_Statue%2C_July_17%2C_2005_at_15-53.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944" /></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:left;background-color:transparent"><a href="/wiki/Buddhas_of_Bamiyan" class="mw-redirect" title="Buddhas of Bamiyan">Buddhas of Bamiyan</a>, Afghanistan in 1896 (top) and after destruction in 2001 by the <a href="/wiki/Taliban" title="Taliban">Taliban</a> Islamists.<sup id="cite_ref-616" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-616">&#91;545&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div></div>
<p>Buddhism has spread across the world,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHenderson200242_617-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHenderson200242-617">&#91;546&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETamney199868_618-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETamney199868-618">&#91;547&#93;</a></sup> and Buddhist texts are increasingly translated into local languages. While <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_the_West" title="Buddhism in the West">Buddhism in the West</a> is often seen as exotic and progressive, in the East it is regarded as familiar and traditional. In countries such as <a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bhutan" title="Bhutan">Bhutan</a>, it is recognised as the <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">state religion</a> and receives government support.
</p><p>In certain regions such as Afghanistan and Pakistan, militants have targeted violence and destruction of historic Buddhist monuments.<sup id="cite_ref-619" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-619">&#91;548&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-620" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-620">&#91;549&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Neo-Buddhism_movements">Neo-Buddhism movements</span></h3>
<p>A number of modern movements in Buddhism emerged during the second half of the 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEParanjpe1998351_621-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEParanjpe1998351-621">&#91;550&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPavāra2009xv–xviii_622-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPavāra2009xv–xviii-622">&#91;551&#93;</a></sup> These <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_modernism" title="Buddhist modernism">new forms of Buddhism</a> are diverse and significantly depart from traditional beliefs and practices.<sup id="cite_ref-623" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-623">&#91;552&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In India, <a href="/wiki/B.R._Ambedkar" class="mw-redirect" title="B.R. Ambedkar">B.R. Ambedkar</a> launched the Navayana tradition – literally, "new vehicle". Ambedkar's Buddhism rejects the foundational doctrines and historic practices of traditional Theravada and Mahayana traditions, such as monk lifestyle after renunciation, karma, rebirth, samsara, meditation, nirvana, Four Noble Truths and others.<sup id="cite_ref-624" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-624">&#91;553&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-625" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-625">&#91;554&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Skaria_2015_450–452_626-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Skaria_2015_450–452-626">&#91;555&#93;</a></sup> Ambedkar's Navayana Buddhism considers these as superstitions and re-interprets the original Buddha as someone who taught about <a href="/wiki/Class_conflict" title="Class conflict">class struggle</a> and social equality.<sup id="cite_ref-627" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-627">&#91;556&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-628" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-628">&#91;557&#93;</a></sup> Ambedkar urged low caste Indian <a href="/wiki/Dalit" title="Dalit">Dalits</a> to convert to his Marxism-inspired<sup id="cite_ref-Skaria_2015_450–452_626-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Skaria_2015_450–452-626">&#91;555&#93;</a></sup> reinterpretation called the <a href="/wiki/Navayana" title="Navayana">Navayana</a> Buddhism, also known as Bhimayana Buddhism. Ambedkar's effort led to the expansion of Navayana Buddhism in India.<sup id="cite_ref-629" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-629">&#91;558&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Jacobsen2015p361_630-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jacobsen2015p361-630">&#91;559&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Thai <a href="/wiki/Mongkut" title="Mongkut">King Mongkut</a> (r. 1851–68), and his son <a href="/wiki/Chulalongkorn" title="Chulalongkorn">King Chulalongkorn</a> (r. 1868–1910), were responsible for modern reforms of <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Thailand" title="Buddhism in Thailand">Thai Buddhism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-631" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-631">&#91;560&#93;</a></sup> Modern Buddhist movements include <a href="/wiki/Secular_Buddhism" title="Secular Buddhism">Secular Buddhism</a> in many countries, <a href="/wiki/Won_Buddhism" title="Won Buddhism">Won Buddhism</a> in Korea, the <a href="/wiki/Dhammakaya_movement" class="mw-redirect" title="Dhammakaya movement">Dhammakaya movement</a> in Thailand and several Japanese organisations, such as <a href="/wiki/Shinnyo-en" title="Shinnyo-en">Shinnyo-en</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rissh%C5%8D_K%C5%8Dsei_Kai" title="Risshō Kōsei Kai">Risshō Kōsei Kai</a> or <a href="/wiki/Soka_Gakkai" title="Soka Gakkai">Soka Gakkai</a>.
</p><p>Some of these movements have brought internal disputes and strife within regional Buddhist communities. For example, the Dhammakaya movement in Thailand teaches a "true self" doctrine, which traditional Theravada monks consider as heretically denying the fundamental <i>anatta</i> (not-self) doctrine of Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-Williams2008p125_632-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Williams2008p125-632">&#91;561&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-633" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-633">&#91;562&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-634" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-634">&#91;563&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_by_country" title="Buddhism by country">Buddhism by country</a></div>
<p>Buddhism is practised by an estimated 488 million,<sup id="cite_ref-auto_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-5">&#91;web 1&#93;</a></sup> 495 million,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJohnson201334–37_635-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJohnson201334–37-635">&#91;564&#93;</a></sup> or 535 million<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey20135_636-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey20135-636">&#91;565&#93;</a></sup> people as of the 2010s, representing 7% to 8% of the world's total population.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Buddhism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Buddhist_data_by_Pew_Research.svg" class="image"><img alt="purple Percentage of Buddhists by country, showing high in Burma to low in United States" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Buddhism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Buddhist_data_by_Pew_Research.svg/330px-Buddhism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Buddhist_data_by_Pew_Research.svg.png" decoding="async" width="330" height="169" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Buddhism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Buddhist_data_by_Pew_Research.svg/495px-Buddhism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Buddhist_data_by_Pew_Research.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Buddhism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Buddhist_data_by_Pew_Research.svg/660px-Buddhism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Buddhist_data_by_Pew_Research.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="863" data-file-height="443" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Buddhism_percent_population_in_each_nation_World_Map_Buddhist_data_by_Pew_Research.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Percentage of Buddhists by country, according to the <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew Research Center</a>, as of 2010</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> is the country with the largest population of Buddhists, approximately 244 million or 18% of its total population.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_5-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-5">&#91;web 1&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-638" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-638">&#91;note 55&#93;</a></sup> They are mostly followers of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Buddhism" title="Chinese Buddhism">Chinese schools</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/Mahayana" title="Mahayana">Mahayana</a></i>, making this the largest body of Buddhist traditions. Mahayana, also practised in broader <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">East Asia</a>, is followed by over half of world Buddhists.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_5-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-5">&#91;web 1&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>According to a demographic analysis reported by Peter Harvey (2013):<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey20135_636-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey20135-636">&#91;565&#93;</a></sup> <i>Mahayana</i> has 360 million adherents; <i><a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada</a></i> has 150 million adherents; and <i><a href="/wiki/Vajrayana" title="Vajrayana">Vajrayana</a></i> has 18.2 million adherents.
</p><p>According to Johnson and Grim (2013), Buddhism has grown from a total of 138 million adherents in 1910, of which 137 million were in <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>, to 495 million in 2010, of which 487 million are in Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJohnson201334–37_635-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJohnson201334–37-635">&#91;564&#93;</a></sup> Over 98% of all Buddhists live in the Asia-Pacific and South Asia region.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center2012_639-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center2012-639">&#91;567&#93;</a></sup> North America had about 3.9 million Buddhists, Europe 1.3 million, while South America, Africa and the Middle East had an estimated combined total of about 1 million Buddhists in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center2012_639-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center2012-639">&#91;567&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Buddhism is the dominant religion in <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Bhutan" title="Buddhism in Bhutan">Bhutan</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-The_Pew_Forum_640-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Pew_Forum-640">&#91;568&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Myanmar" title="Buddhism in Myanmar">Myanmar</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-The_Pew_Forum_640-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Pew_Forum-640">&#91;568&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Cambodia" title="Buddhism in Cambodia">Cambodia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-The_Pew_Forum_640-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Pew_Forum-640">&#91;568&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Tibet" class="mw-redirect" title="Buddhism in Tibet">Tibet</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-The_Pew_Forum_640-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Pew_Forum-640">&#91;568&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Laos" title="Buddhism in Laos">Laos</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-The_Pew_Forum_640-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Pew_Forum-640">&#91;568&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Mongolia" title="Buddhism in Mongolia">Mongolia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-The_Pew_Forum_640-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Pew_Forum-640">&#91;568&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Sri_Lanka" title="Buddhism in Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a><sup id="cite_ref-The_Pew_Forum_640-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Pew_Forum-640">&#91;568&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Thailand" title="Buddhism in Thailand">Thailand</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Pew_Forum_640-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Pew_Forum-640">&#91;568&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-641" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-641">&#91;569&#93;</a></sup> Large Buddhist populations live in <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Buddhism" title="Chinese Buddhism">China</a> (18%),<sup id="cite_ref-The_Pew_Forum_640-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Pew_Forum-640">&#91;568&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Japan" title="Buddhism in Japan">Japan</a> (36%),<sup id="cite_ref-The_Pew_Forum_640-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Pew_Forum-640">&#91;568&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Taiwan" title="Buddhism in Taiwan">Taiwan</a> (35%),<sup id="cite_ref-The_Pew_Forum_640-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Pew_Forum-640">&#91;568&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Macau" title="Religion in Macau">Macau</a> (17%),<sup id="cite_ref-The_Pew_Forum_640-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Pew_Forum-640">&#91;568&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Buddhism in Korea">North Korea</a> (14%),<sup id="cite_ref-The_Pew_Forum_640-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Pew_Forum-640">&#91;568&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Nepal" title="Buddhism in Nepal">Nepal</a> (11%),<sup id="cite_ref-The_Pew_Forum_640-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Pew_Forum-640">&#91;568&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Vietnam" title="Buddhism in Vietnam">Vietnam</a> (10%),<sup id="cite_ref-The_Pew_Forum_640-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Pew_Forum-640">&#91;568&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Singapore" title="Buddhism in Singapore">Singapore</a> (33%),<sup id="cite_ref-The_Pew_Forum_640-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Pew_Forum-640">&#91;568&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Hong_Kong" title="Buddhism in Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> (15%)<sup id="cite_ref-The_Pew_Forum_640-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Pew_Forum-640">&#91;568&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Buddhism in Korea">South Korea</a> (23%).<sup id="cite_ref-The_Pew_Forum_640-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Pew_Forum-640">&#91;568&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In Russia, Buddhists form majority in the <a href="/wiki/Tuva" title="Tuva">Tuva</a> (62%). The <a href="/wiki/Kalmykia" title="Kalmykia">Kalmykia</a> (38%) and <a href="/wiki/Buryatia" title="Buryatia">Buryatia</a> (20%) also have significant Buddhist population.<sup id="cite_ref-ArenaAtlas2012_642-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ArenaAtlas2012-642">&#91;570&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Buddhism is also growing by conversion. In United States, only about a third (32%) of Buddhists in the United States are Asian; a majority (53%) are white. Buddhism in the America is primarily made up of native-born adherents, whites and converts.<sup id="cite_ref-643" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-643">&#91;571&#93;</a></sup> In New Zealand, about 25–35% of the total Buddhists are converts to Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-644" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-644">&#91;572&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-645" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-645">&#91;573&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After China, where nearly half of the worldwide Buddhists live, the 10 countries with the largest Buddhist population densities are:<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center2012_639-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPew_Research_Center2012-639">&#91;567&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
