<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em; list-style-type: decimal;">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-26"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-26">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Buddhist texts such as the <a href="/wiki/Jataka_tales" title="Jataka tales">Jataka tales</a> of the Theravada Buddhist tradition, and early biographies such as the <i><a href="/wiki/Buddhacarita" title="Buddhacarita">Buddhacarita</a></i>, the <a href="/wiki/Lokottarav%C4%81da" title="Lokottaravāda">Lokottaravādin</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Mah%C4%81vastu" title="Mahāvastu">Mahāvastu</a></i>, the <a href="/wiki/Sarvastivada" title="Sarvastivada">Sarvāstivādin</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Lalitavistara_S%C5%ABtra" title="Lalitavistara Sūtra">Lalitavistara Sūtra</a></i>, give different accounts about the life of the Buddha; many include stories of his many rebirths, and some add significant embellishments.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESwearer2004177_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESwearer2004177-19">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199815–24_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199815–24-20">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> Keown and Prebish state, "In the past, modern scholars have generally accepted 486 or 483 BCE for this [Buddha's death], but the consensus is now that they rest on evidence which is too flimsy.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2010105–106_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish2010105–106-21">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> Scholars are hesitant to make unqualified claims about the historical facts of the Buddha's life. Most accept that he lived, taught and founded a monastic order, but do not consistently accept all of the details contained in his biographies."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004352_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004352-22">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELopez199516_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELopez199516-23">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarrithers198610_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarrithers198610-24">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEArmstrong2004xii_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEArmstrong2004xii-25">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-27"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-27">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The exact identity of this ancient place is unclear. Please see <a href="/wiki/Gautama_Buddha" title="Gautama Buddha">Gautama Buddha</a> article for various sites identified.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-29"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-29">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Bihar is derived from <i>Vihara</i>, which means monastery.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198849_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198849-28">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-34"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-34">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Other details about Buddha'a background are contested in modern scholarship. For example, Buddhist texts assert that Buddha described himself as a <i>kshatriya</i> (warrior class), but states Gombrich, little is known about his father and there is no proof that his father even knew the term <i>kshatriya</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198850_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198850-32">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> Mahavira, whose teachings helped establish another major ancient religion <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a>, is also claimed to be <i>ksatriya</i> by his early followers. Further, early texts of both Jainism and Buddhism suggest they emerged in a period of urbanisation in ancient India, one with city nobles and prospering urban centres, states, agricultural surplus, trade and introduction of money.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198850–51_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198850–51-33">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-41"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-41">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The earliest Buddhist biographies of the Buddha mention these Vedic-era teachers. However, outside of these early Buddhist texts, these names do not appear which has led some scholars to raise doubts about the historicity of these claims.<sup id="cite_ref-Wynne2007p8_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wynne2007p8-37">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup> According to Alexander Wynne, the evidence suggests that Buddha studied under these Vedic-era teachers and they "almost certainly" taught him, but the details of his education are unclear.<sup id="cite_ref-Wynne2007p8_37-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wynne2007p8-37">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirakawa199322–26_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirakawa199322–26-40">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-53"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-53">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Theravada tradition traces its origins as the oldest tradition holding the Pali Canon as the only authority, Mahayana tradition revers the Canon but also the derivative literature that developed in the 1st millennium CE and its roots are traceable to the 1st century BCE, while Vajrayana tradition is closer to the Mahayana, includes Tantra, is the younger of the three and traceable to the 1st millennium CE.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin19981–2,_49–58,_253–271_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin19981–2,_49–58,_253–271-51">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Samsara-61"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Samsara_61-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">On samsara, rebirth and redeath:<br />* Paul Williams: "All rebirth is due to karma and is impermanent. Short of attaining enlightenment, in each rebirth one is born and dies, to be reborn elsewhere in accordance with the completely impersonal causal nature of one's own karma. The endless cycle of birth, rebirth, and redeath, is samsara."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200274–75_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200274–75-56">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup><br />* Buswell and Lopez on "rebirth": "An English term that does not have an exact correlate in Buddhist languages, rendered instead by a range of technical terms, such as the Sanskrit <i>Punarjanman</i> (lit. "birth again") and <i>Punabhavan</i> (lit. "re-becoming"), and, less commonly, the related <a href="/wiki/Redeath" class="mw-redirect" title="Redeath">PUNARMRTYU</a> (lit. "redeath")."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708-57">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup><br /><br />See also Perry Schmidt-Leukel (2006) pp. 32–34, <sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchmidt-Leukel200632–34_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmidt-Leukel200632–34-58">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup> John J. Makransky (1997) p. 27.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMakransky199727_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMakransky199727-59">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup> for the use of the term "redeath." The term <i>Agatigati</i> or <i>Agati gati</i> (plus a few other terms) is generally translated as 'rebirth, redeath'; see any Pali-English dictionary; e.g. pp. 94–95 of Rhys Davids &amp; William Stede, where they list five Sutta examples with rebirth and re-death sense.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Moksha-77"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Moksha_77-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Graham Harvey: "Siddhartha Gautama found an end to rebirth in this world of suffering. His teachings, known as the dharma in Buddhism, can be summarized in the Four Noble truths."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2016_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2016-63">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup> Geoffrey Samuel (2008): "The Four Noble Truths [...] describe the knowledge needed to set out on the path to liberation from rebirth."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2008136_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2008136-64">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup> See also <sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpiro198242_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpiro198242-65">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi,_xxxi–xxxii_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi,_xxxi–xxxii-66">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMakransky199727–28_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMakransky199727–28-67">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200274–75_56-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200274–75-56">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELopez2009147_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELopez2009147-68">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2016_63-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2016-63">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKingsland2016286_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKingsland2016286-69">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-EB-DL_Four_Truths_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB-DL_Four_Truths-70">&#91;web 2&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">&#91;web 3&#93;</a></sup><br /><br />The Theravada tradition holds that insight into these four truths is liberating in itself.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarter19873179_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarter19873179-72">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup> This is reflected in the Pali canon.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnderson2013_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnderson2013-73">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup> According to Donald Lopez, "The Buddha stated in his first sermon that when he gained absolute and intuitive knowledge of the four truths, he achieved complete enlightenment and freedom from future rebirth."<sup id="cite_ref-EB-DL_Four_Truths_70-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EB-DL_Four_Truths-70">&#91;web 2&#93;</a></sup><br /><br />The <i><a href="/wiki/Maha-parinibbana_Sutta" class="mw-redirect" title="Maha-parinibbana Sutta">Maha-parinibbana Sutta</a></i> also refers to this liberation.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">&#91;web 4&#93;</a></sup> Carol Anderson: "The second passage where the four truths appear in the <i>Vinaya-pitaka</i> is also found in the <i>Mahaparinibbana-sutta</i> (D II 90–91). Here, the Buddha explains that it is by not understanding the four truths that rebirth continues."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnderson2013162_with_note_38,_for_context_see_pp._1–3_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnderson2013162_with_note_38,_for_context_see_pp._1–3-75">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup><br /><br />On the meaning of moksha as liberation from rebirth, see Patrick Olivelle in the <i>Encyclopædia Britannica</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Brittanica_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brittanica-76">&#91;web 5&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-80"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-80">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">As opposite to <i>sukha</i>, "pleasure," it is better translated as "pain."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201526–31_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201526–31-79">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-90"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-90">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This explanation is more common in commentaries on the Four Noble Truths within the <a href="/wiki/Theravada" title="Theravada">Theravada</a> tradition: e.g. Ajahn Sucitta (2010); Ajahn Sumedho (ebook); Rahula (1974); etc.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Nirodha-95"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Nirodha_95-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Ending rebirth:<br />* Graham Harvey: "The Third Noble Truth is nirvana. The Buddha tells us that an end to suffering is possible, and it is nirvana. Nirvana is a "blowing out," just as a candle flame is extinguished in the wind, from our lives in samsara. It connotes an end to rebirth"<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2016_63-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2016-63">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup><br />* Spiro: "The Buddhis message then, as I have said, is not simply a psychological message, i.e. that desire is the cause of suffering because unsatisfied desire produces frustration. It does contain such a message to be sure; but more importantly it is an eschatological message. Desire is the cause of suffering because desire is the cause of rebirth; and the extinction of desire leads to deliverance from suffering because it signals release from the Wheel of Rebirth."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpiro198242_65-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpiro198242-65">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup><br />* John J. Makransky: "The third noble truth, cessation (<i>nirodha</i>) or nirvana, represented the ultimate aim of Buddhist practice in the Abhidharma traditions: the state free from the conditions that created samsara. Nirvana was the ultimate and final state attained when the supramundane yogic path had been completed. It represented salvation from samsara precisely because it was understood to comprise a state of complete freedom from the chain of samsaric causes and conditions, i.e., precisely because it was unconditioned (<i>asamskrta</i>)."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMakransky199727–28_67-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMakransky199727–28-67">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup><br />* Walpola Rahula: "Let us consider a few definitions and descriptions of Nirvana as found in the original Pali texts [...] 'It is the complete cessation of that very thirst (tanha), giving it up, renouncing it, emancipation from it, detachment from it.' [...] 'The abandoning and destruction of craving for these Five Aggregates of Attachment: that is the cessation of <i>dukkha</i>. [...] 'The Cessation of Continuity and becoming (<i>Bhavanirodha</i>) is Nibbana.'"<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERahula2014_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERahula2014-94">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-realms2-108"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-realms2_108-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Earlier Buddhist texts refer to five realms rather than six realms; when described as five realms, the god realm and demi-god realm constitute a single realm.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004711–712_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004711–712-107">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-118"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-118">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This merit gaining may be on the behalf of one's family members.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709_115-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709-115">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Neufeldt1986p123_116-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Neufeldt1986p123-116">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-SwatosKivisto1998p66_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SwatosKivisto1998p66-117">&#91;98&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-132"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-132">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The realms in which a being is reborn are:<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200460–63_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200460–63-121">&#91;101&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish201336–38_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish201336–38-122">&#91;102&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">&#91;subnote 1&#93;</a></sup>
<ol><li><a href="/wiki/Naraka_(Buddhism)" title="Naraka (Buddhism)">Naraka</a>: beings believed in Buddhism to suffer in one of many Narakas (Hells);</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Preta" title="Preta">Preta</a>: sometimes sharing some space with humans, but invisible; an important variety is the <a href="/wiki/Hungry_ghost" title="Hungry ghost">hungry ghost</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey199033_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey199033-125">&#91;103&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Animals_in_Buddhism" title="Animals in Buddhism">Tiryag</a> (animals): existence as an animal along with humans; this realm is traditionally thought in Buddhism to be similar to a hellish realm because animals are believed to be driven by impulse; they prey on each other and suffer.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish201336_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish201336-126">&#91;104&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Human_beings_in_Buddhism" title="Human beings in Buddhism">Manusya</a> (human beings): one of the realms of rebirth in which attaining Nirvana is possible; A rebirth in this realm is therefore considered as fortunate and an opportunity to end the endless Samsara and associated Dukkha.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200462_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200462-127">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish201336–37_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeownPrebish201336–37-128">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Asura_(Buddhism)" title="Asura (Buddhism)">Asuras</a>: variously translated as lowly deities, demi-gods, demons, titans, or anti-gods; recognised in Theravada tradition as part of the heavenly realm;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBareau1955212–223_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBareau1955212–223-129">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Deva_(Buddhism)" title="Deva (Buddhism)">Devas</a> including <a href="/wiki/Brahm%C4%81_(Buddhism)" title="Brahmā (Buddhism)">Brahmās</a>: variously translated as gods, deities, angels, or heavenly beings. The vast majority of Buddhist lay people have historically pursued Buddhist rituals and practices motivated by rebirth into the Deva realm.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200462_127-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200462-127">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Merv_Fowler_1999_65_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Merv_Fowler_1999_65-130">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Christopher_Gowans_2004_169_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Christopher_Gowans_2004_169-131">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup></li></ol>
</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-140"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-140">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Diseases and suffering induced by the disruptive actions of other people are examples of non-karma suffering.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340–41_139-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340–41-139">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-145"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-145">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The emphasis on intent in Buddhism marks its difference from the karma theory of Jainism where karma accumulates with or without intent.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201340-142">&#91;118&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKrishan199747,_55_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKrishan199747,_55-143">&#91;119&#93;</a></sup> The emphasis on intent is also found in Hinduism, and Buddhism may have influenced karma theories of Hinduism.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-154"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-154">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This Buddhist idea may have roots in the <i>quid-pro-quo</i> exchange beliefs of the Hindu Vedic rituals.<sup id="cite_ref-Egge2013_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Egge2013-152">&#91;127&#93;</a></sup> The "karma merit transfer" concept has been controversial, not accepted in later Jainism and Hinduism traditions, unlike Buddhism where it was adopted in ancient times and remains a common practice.<sup id="cite_ref-appletonp129_149-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-appletonp129-149">&#91;124&#93;</a></sup> According to Bruce Reichenbach, the "merit transfer" idea was generally absent in early Buddhism and may have emerged with the rise of Mahayana Buddhism; he adds that while major Hindu schools such as Yoga, Advaita Vedanta and others do not believe in merit transfer, some bhakti Hindu traditions later adopted the idea just like Buddhism.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">&#91;128&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-157"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-157">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Another variant, which may be condensed to the eightfold or tenfold path, starts with a <i>Tathagatha</i> entering this world. A layman hears his teachings, decides to leave the life of a householder, starts living according to the moral precepts, guards his sense-doors, practises mindfulness and the four jhanas, gains the three knowledges, understands the Four Noble Truths and destroys the <a href="/wiki/Asava" title="Asava">taints</a>, and perceives that he is liberated.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBucknell1984_98-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBucknell1984-98">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-169"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-169">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The early Mahayana Buddhism texts link their discussion of "emptiness" (<i>shunyata</i>) to <i>Anatta</i> and <i>Nirvana</i>. They do so, states Mun-Keat Choong, in three ways: first, in the common sense of a monk's meditative state of emptiness; second, with the main sense of <i>anatta</i> or 'everything in the world is empty of self'; third, with the ultimate sense of <i>nirvana</i> or realisation of emptiness and thus an end to rebirth cycles of suffering.<sup id="cite_ref-Choong1999p85_168-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Choong1999p85-168">&#91;141&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-172"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-172">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Some scholars such as Cousins and Sangharakshita translate <i>apranaihita</i> as "aimlessness or directionless-ness".<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">&#91;143&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-180"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-180">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">These descriptions of nirvana in Buddhist texts, states Peter Harvey, are contested by scholars because nirvana in Buddhism is ultimately described as a state of "stopped consciousness (blown out), but one that is not non-existent", and "it seems impossible to imagine what awareness devoid of any object would be like".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey201375–76_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey201375–76-178">&#91;149&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGethin199874-84_179-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGethin199874-84-179">&#91;150&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-182"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-182">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Scholars<sup id="cite_ref-Merv_Fowler_1999_65_130-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Merv_Fowler_1999_65-130">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Christopher_Gowans_2004_169_131-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Christopher_Gowans_2004_169-131">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup> note that better rebirth, not nirvana, has been the primary focus of a vast majority of lay Buddhists. This they attempt through merit accumulation and good <i>kamma</i>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-250"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-250">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The hundreds of rules vary by the <i>sangha</i>; 11th-century Chinese monastic texts include rules such as only reciting the <a href="/wiki/Buddhavacana" title="Buddhavacana">Buddha's Word</a> alone, not near commonplace people; not eating prohibited foods such as meat, fish, cheese, onions, garlic, animal fat; abstain from anything that can lead to sensual thoughts; etc.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">&#91;218&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-257"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-257">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Williams refers to Frauwallner (1973) p. 155</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-266"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-266">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Many ancient <a href="/wiki/Upanishad" class="mw-redirect" title="Upanishad">Upanishads</a> of Hinduism describe <a href="/wiki/Yoga" title="Yoga">yoga</a> and meditation as a means to liberation.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECollins2000199_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECollins2000199-263">&#91;230&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">&#91;231&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">&#91;232&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-281"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-281">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The state is described in a number of additional characteristics in different Buddhist texts. For example, success in the First Dhyana leads to a gem-like outer light emanating from the body, according to <i>Samahitabhumi</i> by Asanga; the nature of emanating light from one's body changes as the meditation successfully progresses from the first to the fourth Dhyana.<sup id="cite_ref-Wayman1984p81_279-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wayman1984p81-279">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-286"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-286">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Gombrich: "I know this is controversial, but it seems to me that the third and fourth jhanas are thus quite unlike the second."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWynne2007140,_note_58_285-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWynne2007140,_note_58-285">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-290"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-290">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Wynne: "Thus the expression <i>sato sampajāno</i> in the third <i>jhāna</i> must denote a state of awareness different from the meditative absorption of the second <i>jhāna</i> (<i>cetaso ekodibhāva</i>). It suggests that the subject is doing something different from remaining in a meditative state, i.e., that he has come out of his absorption and is now once again aware of objects. The same is true of the word <i>upek(k)hā</i>: it does not denote an abstract 'equanimity', [but] it means to be aware of something and indifferent to it [...] The third and fourth <i>jhāna-s</i>, as it seems to me, describe the process of directing states of meditative absorption towards the mindful awareness of objects."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWynne2007106–107_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWynne2007106–107-289">&#91;253&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-291"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-291">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to Gombrich, "the later tradition has falsified the jhana by classifying them as the quintessence of the concentrated, calming kind of meditation, ignoring the other – and indeed higher – element."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWynne2007140,_note_58_285-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWynne2007140,_note_58-285">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-294"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-294">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The problem was famously voiced in 1936 by Louis de La Vallee Poussin, in his text <i>Musila et Narada: Le Chemin de Nirvana</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993133–134_293-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1993133–134-293">&#91;255&#93;</a></sup> See <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.gampoabbey.org/documents/kosha-sources/La-Vallee-Poussin-Musila-and-Narada-The-Path-of-Nirvana-1937.pdf">Louis de La Vallée Poussin, <i>Musial and Narad</i></a>. Translated from the French by Gelongma Migme Chödrön and Gelong Lodrö Sangpo.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-297"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-297">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Schmithausen:<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchmithausen1981_295-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmithausen1981-295">&#91;256&#93;</a></sup>
<ol><li>The four Rupa Jhanas themselves constituted the core liberating practice of early buddhism, c.q. the Buddha;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi–xxxvii_296-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxi–xxxvii-296">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>Mastering the four Rupa Jhanas, where-after "liberating insight" is attained;</li>
<li>Mastering the four Rupa Jhanas and the four Arupa Jhanas, where-after "liberating insight" is attained.</li></ol>
</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-Vetter-dhyana-298"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Vetter-dhyana_298-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Vetter-dhyana_298-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">On Vetter and dhyana, see, for example, Vetter 1988:
<dl><dd><dl><dd><ul><li>page xxvii: "Originally this ["the fourth stage [...] that state of pure equanimity and awareness"] may have been the only ground of an experience of release."</li>
<li>page xxviii: "Incidentally, this state of pure equanimity and awareness may also have been the origin of the method of discriminating insight."</li>
<li>page xxviii–xxix: "In order to solve [...] a very practical way."</li>
<li>page xxxiii: "an older stage of the same path to salvation ends in the right samadhi,"</li></ul></dd></dl></dd></dl>
</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-310"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-310">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Buddha never claimed that the "four immeasurables" were his unique ideas, in a manner similar to "cessation, quieting, nirvana".<sup id="cite_ref-Aronson1980p71_309-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Aronson1980p71-309">&#91;268&#93;</a></sup> The Buddhist scripture <i><a href="/wiki/Digha_Nikaya" class="mw-redirect" title="Digha Nikaya">Digha Nikaya</a></i> II.251 asserts the Buddha to be calling the Brahmavihara as "that practice", and he then contrasts it with "my practice".<sup id="cite_ref-Aronson1980p71_309-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Aronson1980p71-309">&#91;268&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-338"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-338">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Tillmann Vetter: "Very likely the cause was the growing influence of a non-Buddhist spiritual environment·which claimed that one can be released only by some truth or higher knowledge. In addition the alternative (and perhaps sometimes competing) method of discriminating insight (fully established after the introduction of the four noble truths) seemed to conform so well to this claim."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxxiii_337-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xxxiii-337">&#91;295&#93;</a></sup><br /><br />According to Bronkhorst, this happened under influence of the "mainstream of meditation," that is, Vedic-Brahmanical oriented groups, which believed that the cessation of action could not be liberating, since action can never be fully stopped. Their solution was to postulate a fundamental difference between the inner soul or self and the body. The inner self is unchangeable, and unaffected by actions. By insight into this difference, one was liberated. To equal this emphasis on insight, Buddhists presented insight into their most essential teaching as equally liberating. What exactly was regarded as the central insight "varied along with what was considered most central to the teaching of the Buddha."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199354–55,_96,_99_336-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst199354–55,_96,_99-336">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-371"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-371">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Wayman and Wayman have disagreed with this view, and they state that the <i>Tathagatagarbha</i> is neither self nor sentient being, nor soul, nor personality.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPaul_Williams2008107_370-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPaul_Williams2008107-370">&#91;326&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-430"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-430">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">While some interpretations state that Buddhism may have originated as a social reform, other scholars state that it is incorrect and anachronistic to regard the Buddha as a social reformer.<sup id="cite_ref-QueenKing1996p17_428-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-QueenKing1996p17-428">&#91;383&#93;</a></sup> Buddha's concern was "to reform individuals, help them to leave society forever, not to reform the world... he never preached against social inequality". <a href="/wiki/Richard_Gombrich" title="Richard Gombrich">Richard Gombrich</a>, quoted by Christopher Queen.<sup id="cite_ref-QueenKing1996p17_428-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-QueenKing1996p17-428">&#91;383&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198830–31_429-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198830–31-429">&#91;384&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-447"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-447">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a href="/wiki/Digha_Nikaya" class="mw-redirect" title="Digha Nikaya">Digha Nikaya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Majjhima_Nikaya" title="Majjhima Nikaya">Majjhima Nikaya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samyutta_Nikaya" class="mw-redirect" title="Samyutta Nikaya">Samyutta Nikaya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anguttara_Nikaya" class="mw-redirect" title="Anguttara Nikaya">Anguttara Nikaya</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-453"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-453">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The surviving portions of the scriptures of <a href="/wiki/Sarvastivada" title="Sarvastivada">Sarvastivada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mulasarvastivada" title="Mulasarvastivada">Mulasarvastivada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mah%C4%AB%C5%9B%C4%81saka" title="Mahīśāsaka">Mahīśāsaka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dharmaguptaka" title="Dharmaguptaka">Dharmaguptaka</a> and other schools.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988ix_451-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988ix-451">&#91;404&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarder1999_452-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarder1999-452">&#91;405&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-456"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-456">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Exemplary studies are the study on descriptions of "liberating insight" by Lambert Schmithausen,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchmithausen1981_295-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmithausen1981-295">&#91;256&#93;</a></sup> the overview of early Buddhism by Tilmann Vetter,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988_162-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988-162">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup> the philological work on the four truths by K.R. Norman,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENorman1992_454-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorman1992-454">&#91;406&#93;</a></sup> the textual studies by Richard Gombrich,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich1997_292-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich1997-292">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup> and the research on early meditation methods by Johannes Bronkhorst.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1997_455-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1997-455">&#91;407&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-462"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-462">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Well-known proponents of the first position are <a href="/wiki/A._K._Warder" title="A. K. Warder">A. K. Warder</a><sup id="cite_ref-459" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-459">&#91;subnote 2&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Richard_Gombrich" title="Richard Gombrich">Richard Gombrich</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1997viii_460-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1997viii-460">&#91;410&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-461" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-461">&#91;subnote 3&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-465"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-465">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">A proponent of the second position is Ronald Davidson.<sup id="cite_ref-464" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-464">&#91;subnote 4&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-472"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-472">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Well-known proponents of the third position are J.W. de Jong,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJong199325_466-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJong199325-466">&#91;412&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Jong_467-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jong-467">&#91;subnote 5&#93;</a></sup> Johannes Bronkhorst<sup id="cite_ref-469" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-469">&#91;subnote 6&#93;</a></sup> and Donald Lopez.<sup id="cite_ref-471" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-471">&#91;subnote 7&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-481"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-481">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to Schmithausen, "the karma doctrine may have been incidental to early Buddhist soteriology."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchmithausen1986206–207_480-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchmithausen1986206–207-480">&#91;422&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-493"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-493">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Vetter: "I am especially thinking here of MN 26 (I p. 163,32; 165,15; 166,35) <i>kimkusalagavesi anuttaram santivarapadam pariyesamano</i> (searching for that which is beneficial, seeking the unsurpassable, best place of peace) and again MN 26 (passim), <i>anuttaramyagakkhemam nibbiinam pariyesati</i> (he seeks the unsurpassable safe place, the nirvana). <i>Anuppatta-sadattho</i> (one who has reached the right goal) is also a vague positive expression in the Arhatformula in MN 35 (I p, 235), see chapter 2, footnote 3, Furthermore, <i>satthi</i> (welfare) is important in e.g. SN 2.12 or 2.17 or Sn 269; and <i>sukha</i> and <i>rati</i> (happiness), in contrast to other places, as used in Sn 439 and 956. The oldest term was perhaps <i>amata</i> (immortal, immortality) [...] but one could say here that it is a negative term."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xv_492-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter1988xv-492">&#91;433&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-512"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-512">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Anthony Barber and Sree Padma note that "historians of Buddhist thought have been aware for quite some time that such pivotally important Mahayana Buddhist thinkers as <a href="/wiki/Nagarjuna" title="Nagarjuna">Nagarjuna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dign%C4%81ga" title="Dignāga">Dignāga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chandrakirti" title="Chandrakirti">Chandrakirti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aryadeva" title="Aryadeva">Aryadeva</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bh%C4%81viveka" title="Bhāviveka">Bhāviveka</a>, among many others, formulated their theories while living in Buddhist communities in Āndhra."<sup id="cite_ref-510" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-510">&#91;450&#93;</a></sup> They note that the ancient Buddhist sites in the lower Kṛṣṇa Valley, including <a href="/wiki/Amaravathi_(village),_Guntur_district" class="mw-redirect" title="Amaravathi (village), Guntur district">Amaravati</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nagarjunakonda" title="Nagarjunakonda">Nāgārjunakoṇḍā</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jaggayyapeta" title="Jaggayyapeta">Jaggayyapeṭa</a> "can be traced to at least the third century BCE, if not earlier."<sup id="cite_ref-511" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-511">&#91;451&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-China_Buswell_2004-518"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-China_Buswell_2004_518-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"The most important evidence – in fact the only evidence – for situating the emergence of the Mahayana around the beginning of the common era was not Indian evidence at all, but came from China. Already by the last quarter of the 2nd century CE, there was a small, seemingly idiosyncratic collection of substantial Mahayana sutras translated into what Erik Zürcher calls 'broken Chinese' by an Indoscythian, whose Indian name has been reconstructed as Lokaksema."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004492_517-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswell2004492-517">&#91;456&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-South-520"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-South_520-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"The south (of India) was then vigorously creative in producing Mahayana Sutras" Warder<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarder2000335_519-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarder2000335-519">&#91;457&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Hill-538"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Hill_538-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See Hill (2009), p. 30, for the Chinese text from the <i><a href="/wiki/Hou_Hanshu" class="mw-redirect" title="Hou Hanshu">Hou Hanshu</a></i>, and p. 31 for a translation of it.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHill200930–31_537-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHill200930–31-537">&#91;474&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-alternative_scheme-561"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-alternative_scheme_561-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">(Harvey 1990),(Gombrich,1984); Gethin (1998), pp. 1–2, identifies "three broad traditions" as: (1) "The Theravāda tradition of Sri Lanka and South-East Asia, also sometimes referred to as 'southern' Buddhism"; (2) "The East Asian tradition of China, Korea, Japan, and Vietnam, also sometimes referred to as 'eastern' Buddhism"; and, (3) "The Tibetan tradition, also sometimes referred to as 'northern' Buddhism."; Robinson &amp; Johnson (1982) divide their book into two parts: Part One is entitled "The Buddhism of South Asia" (which pertains to Early Buddhism in India); and, Part Two is entitled "The Development of Buddhism Outside of India" with chapters on "The Buddhism of Southeast Asia", "Buddhism in the Tibetan Culture Area", "East Asian Buddhism" and "Buddhism Comes West"; <i>Penguin Handbook of Living Religions</i>, 1984, p. 279; Prebish &amp; Keown, <i>Introducing Buddhism</i>, ebook, Journal of Buddhist Ethics, 2005, printed ed, Harper, 2006</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-other_schemes-563"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-other_schemes_563-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See e.g. the multi-dimensional classification in <i>Encyclopedia of Religion</i><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEliade1987440ff_562-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEliade1987440ff-562">&#91;496&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-timeline_Cousins-569"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-timeline_Cousins_569-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Cousins, L.S. (1996); Buswell (2003), Vol. I, p. 82; and, Keown &amp; Prebish (2004), p. 107. See also, Gombrich (1988/2002), p. 32: “…[T]he best we can say is that [the Buddha] was probably Enlightened between 550 and 450, more likely later rather than earlier."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-drawing_Williams-571"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-drawing_Williams_571-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"> Williams (2000, pp. 6-7) writes: "As a matter of fact Buddhism in mainland India itself had all but ceased to exist by the thirteenth century CE, although by that time it had spread to Tibet, China, Japan, and Southeast Asia."  <sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmbree1988_570-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmbree1988-570">&#91;502&#93;</a></sup> (Originally 1958), "Chronology," p. xxix: "c. 1000-1200: Buddhism disappears as [an] organized religious force in India." See also, Robinson &amp; Johnson (1970/1982), pp. 100-1, 108 Fig. 1; and, Harvey (1990/2007), pp. 139-40.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Prebish-598"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Prebish_598-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to Charles S. Prebish:<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPrebish1993244,_287_597-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPrebish1993244,_287-597">&#91;528&#93;</a></sup> "Although a variety of Zen 'schools' developed in Japan, they all emphasize Zen as a teaching that does not depend on sacred texts, that provides the potential for direct realization, that the realization attained is none other than the Buddha nature possessed by each sentient being ..."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Prebish_B-600"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Prebish_B_600-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Prebish comments (op. cit., p. 244): "It presumes that <i>sitting in meditation itself</i> (i.e. <i><a href="/wiki/Zazen" title="Zazen">zazen</a></i>) is an expression of Buddha nature." The method is to detach the mind from conceptual modes of thinking and perceive Reality directly. Speaking of Zen in general, Buddhist scholar Stephen Hodge writes: "... practitioners of Zen believe that Enlightenment, the awakening of the Buddha-mind or Buddha-nature, is our natural state, but has been covered over by layers of negative emotions and distorted thoughts. According to this view, Enlightenment is not something that we must acquire a bit at a time, but a state that can occur instantly when we cut through the dense veil of mental and emotional obscurations."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHodge200212–13_599-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHodge200212–13-599">&#91;529&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-638"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-638">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This is a contested number. Official numbers from the Chinese government are lower, while other surveys are higher. According to Katharina Wenzel-Teuber, in non-government surveys, "49 percent of self-claimed non-believers [in China] held some religious beliefs, such as believing in soul reincarnation, heaven, hell, or supernatural forces. Thus the 'pure atheists' make up only about 15 percent of the sample [surveyed]."<sup id="cite_ref-637" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-637">&#91;566&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div>
<p><i>Subnotes</i>
</p>
<div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em; list-style-type: decimal;">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-124"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-124">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The realms of rebirths in Buddhism are further subdivided into 31 planes of existence.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">&#91;web 8&#93;</a></sup> Rebirths in some of the higher heavens, known as the <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_cosmology#Pure_Abodes" title="Buddhist cosmology">Śuddhāvāsa Worlds</a> or Pure Abodes, can be attained only by skilled Buddhist practitioners known as <a href="/wiki/An%C4%81g%C4%81mi" title="Anāgāmi">anāgāmis</a> (non-returners). Rebirths in the <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_cosmology#Formless_Realm_(Ārūpyadhātu)" title="Buddhist cosmology">Ārūpyadhātu</a> (formless realms) can be attained by only those who can meditate on the <a href="/wiki/Ar%C5%ABpajh%C4%81na" class="mw-redirect" title="Arūpajhāna">arūpajhānas</a>, the highest object of meditation.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-459"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-459">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">According to A.K. Warder, in his 1970 publication "Indian Buddhism", from the oldest extant texts a common kernel can be drawn out.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarder1999_452-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarder1999-452">&#91;405&#93;</a></sup> According to Warder, c.q. his publisher: "This kernel of doctrine is presumably common Buddhism of the period before the great schisms of the fourth and third centuries BC. It may be substantially the Buddhism of the Buddha himself, although this cannot be proved: at any rate it is a Buddhism presupposed by the schools as existing about a hundred years after the parinirvana of the Buddha, and there is no evidence to suggest that it was formulated by anyone else than the Buddha and his immediate followers."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarder1999inside_flap_458-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarder1999inside_flap-458">&#91;409&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-461"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-461">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Richard Gombrich: "I have the greatest difficulty in accepting that the main edifice is not the work of a single genius. By "the main edifice" I mean the collections of the main body of sermons, the four Nikāyas, and of the main body of monastic rules."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich1997_292-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich1997-292">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-464"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-464">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Ronald Davidson: "While most scholars agree that there was a rough body of sacred literature (disputed)(sic) that a relatively early community (disputed)(sic) maintained and transmitted, we have little confidence that much, if any, of surviving Buddhist scripture is actually the word of the historic Buddha."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDavidson2003147_463-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDavidson2003147-463">&#91;411&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Jong-467"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Jong_467-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">J.W. De Jong: "It would be hypocritical to assert that nothing can be said about the doctrine of earliest Buddhism [...] the basic ideas of Buddhism found in the canonical writings could very well have been proclaimed by him [the Buddha], transmitted and developed by his disciples and, finally, codified in fixed formulas."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJong199325_466-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJong199325-466">&#91;412&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-469"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-469">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Bronkhorst: "This position is to be preferred to (ii) for purely methodological reasons: only those who seek nay find, even if no success is guaranteed."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1997vii_468-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBronkhorst1997vii-468">&#91;413&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-471"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-471">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Lopez: "The original teachings of the historical Buddha are extremely difficult, if not impossible, to recover or reconstruct."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELopez19954_470-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELopez19954-470">&#91;414&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTERoach2011-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoach2011_2-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFRoach2011">Roach 2011</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"Buddhism". (2009). <li id="cite_note-gordonconwell.edu-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-gordonconwell.edu_6-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170525141543/http://www.gordonconwell.edu/resources/documents/1IBMR2015.pdf">"Christianity 2015: Religious Diversity and Personal Contact"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. gordonconwell.edu. <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEKohn1991143-42"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKohn1991143_42-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFKohn1991">Kohn 1991</a>, p.&#160;143.</span>

<li id="cite_note-43"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-43">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Johannes Bronkhorst (2011). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=BaX58-E5-3MC"><i>Buddhism in the Shadow of Brahmanism</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201526–31-79"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201526–31_79-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFEmmanuel2015">Emmanuel 2015</a>, pp.&#160;26–31.</span>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich200647,_Quote:_&quot;All_phenomenal_existence_&#91;in_Buddhism&#93;_is_said_to_have_three_interlocking_characteristics:_impermanence,_suffering_and_lack_of_soul_or_essence.&quot;-81"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich200647,_Quote:_&quot;All_phenomenal_existence_[in_Buddhism]_is_said_to_have_three_interlocking_characteristics:_impermanence,_suffering_and_lack_of_soul_or_essence.&quot;_81-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFGombrich2006">Gombrich 2006</a>, p.&#160;47, Quote: "All phenomenal existence [in Buddhism] is said to have three interlocking characteristics: impermanence, suffering and lack of soul or essence.".</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-britannicaanatta-82"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-britannicaanatta_82-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.britannica.com/topic/anatta">Anatta Buddhism</a>, Encyclopædia Britannica (2013)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-83"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-83">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">[a] <cite class="citation book">Christmas Humphreys (2012). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=V3rYtmCZEIEC"><i>Exploring Buddhism</i></a>. Routledge. pp.&#160;42–43. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-136-22877-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-136-22877-3"><bdi>978-1-136-22877-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Exploring+Buddhism&amp;rft.pages=42-43&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-136-22877-3&amp;rft.au=Christmas+Humphreys&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DV3rYtmCZEIEC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/><br />[b] Gombrich (2006), p. 47, Quote: "(...) Buddha's teaching that beings have no soul, no abiding essence. This 'no-soul doctrine' (anatta-vada) he expounded in his second sermon."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-5sourcesanatta-84"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-5sourcesanatta_84-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><b>[a]</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.britannica.com/topic/anatta">Anatta</a>, Encyclopædia Britannica (2013), Quote: "Anatta in Buddhism, the doctrine that there is in humans no permanent, underlying soul. The concept of anatta, or anatman, is a departure from the Hindu belief in atman ("the self").";<br /><b>[b]</b> Steven Collins (1994), Religion and Practical Reason (Editors: Frank Reynolds, David Tracy), State Univ of New York Press, <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/><a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0791422175" title="Special:BookSources/978-0791422175">978-0791422175</a>, p. 64; "Central to Buddhist soteriology is the doctrine of not-self (Pali: anattā, Sanskrit: anātman, the opposed doctrine of ātman is central to Brahmanical thought). Put very briefly, this is the [Buddhist] doctrine that human beings have no soul, no self, no unchanging essence.";<br /><b>[c]</b> John C. Plott et al. (2000), <i>Global History of Philosophy: The Axial Age</i>, Volume 1, Motilal Banarsidass, <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/><a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-8120801585" title="Special:BookSources/978-8120801585">978-8120801585</a>, p. 63, Quote: "The Buddhist schools reject any Ātman concept. As we have already observed, this is the basic and ineradicable distinction between Hinduism and Buddhism";<br /><b>[d]</b> Katie Javanaud (2013), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://philosophynow.org/issues/97/Is_The_Buddhist_No-Self_Doctrine_Compatible_With_Pursuing_Nirvana">Is The Buddhist 'No-Self' Doctrine Compatible With Pursuing Nirvana?</a>, Philosophy Now;<br /><b>[e]</b> David Loy (1982), "Enlightenment in Buddhism and Advaita Vedanta: Are Nirvana and Moksha the Same?", <i>International Philosophical Quarterly</i>, Volume 23, Issue 1, pp. 65–74</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-85"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-85">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Brian Morris (2006). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=PguGB_uEQh4C&amp;pg=PA51"><i>Religion and Anthropology: A Critical Introduction</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. p.&#160;51. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-85241-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-85241-8"><bdi>978-0-521-85241-8</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Religion+and+Anthropology%3A+A+Critical+Introduction&amp;rft.pages=51&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-85241-8&amp;rft.au=Brian+Morris&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DPguGB_uEQh4C%26pg%3DPA51&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/>, Quote: "(...) anatta is the doctrine of non-self, and is an extreme empiricist doctrine that holds that the notion of an unchanging permanent self is a fiction and has no reality. According to Buddhist doctrine, the individual person consists of five skandhas or heaps – the body, feelings, perceptions, impulses and consciousness. The belief in a self or soul, over these five skandhas, is illusory and the cause of suffering."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-GombrichScherrer2008p209-86"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-GombrichScherrer2008p209_86-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Richard Francis Gombrich; Cristina Anna Scherrer-Schaub (2008). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=U7_Rea05eAMC"><i>Buddhist Studies</i></a>. Motilal Banarsidass. pp.&#160;209–210. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-208-3248-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-208-3248-0"><bdi>978-81-208-3248-0</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Buddhist+Studies&amp;rft.pages=209-210&amp;rft.pub=Motilal+Banarsidass&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=978-81-208-3248-0&amp;rft.au=Richard+Francis+Gombrich&amp;rft.au=Cristina+Anna+Scherrer-Schaub&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DU7_Rea05eAMC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-HoffmanMahinda2013p162-87"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-HoffmanMahinda2013p162_87-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Frank Hoffman; Deegalle Mahinda (2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=pSNeAgAAQBAJ"><i>Pali Buddhism</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEJuergensmeyerRoof2011271–272-100"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJuergensmeyerRoof2011271–272_100-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJuergensmeyerRoof2011271–272_100-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJuergensmeyerRoof2011271–272_100-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFJuergensmeyerRoof2011">Juergensmeyer &amp; Roof 2011</a>, pp.&#160;271–272.</span>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor200458,_Quote:_&quot;Buddhism_shares_with_Hinduism_the_doctrine_of_Samsara,_whereby_all_beings_pass_through_an_unceasing_cycle_of_birth,_death_and_rebirth_until_they_find_a_means_of_liberation_from_the_cycle._However,_Buddhism_differs_from_Hinduism_in_rejecting_the_assertion_that_every_human_being_possesses_a_changeless_soul_which_constitutes_his_or_her_ultimate_identity,_and_which_transmigrates_from_one_incarnation_to_the_next.-101"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor200458,_Quote:_&quot;Buddhism_shares_with_Hinduism_the_doctrine_of_Samsara,_whereby_all_beings_pass_through_an_unceasing_cycle_of_birth,_death_and_rebirth_until_they_find_a_means_of_liberation_from_the_cycle._However,_Buddhism_differs_from_Hinduism_in_rejecting_the_assertion_that_every_human_being_possesses_a_changeless_soul_which_constitutes_his_or_her_ultimate_identity,_and_which_transmigrates_from_one_incarnation_to_the_next._101-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFTrainor2004">Trainor 2004</a>, p.&#160;58, Quote: "Buddhism shares with Hinduism the doctrine of Samsara, whereby all beings pass through an unceasing cycle of birth, death and rebirth until they find a means of liberation from the cycle. However, Buddhism differs from Hinduism in rejecting the assertion that every human being possesses a changeless soul which constitutes his or her ultimate identity, and which transmigrates from one incarnation to the next..</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilson2010-102"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilson2010_102-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilson2010_102-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFWilson2010">Wilson 2010</a>.</span>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliamsTribeWynne201218–19,_chapter_1-104"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliamsTribeWynne201218–19,_chapter_1_104-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFWilliamsTribeWynne2012">Williams, Tribe &amp; Wynne 2012</a>, pp.&#160;18–19, chapter 1.</span>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEConze201371,_Quote:_&quot;Nirvana_is_the_&#39;&#39;raison_d&#39;être&#39;&#39;_of_Buddhism,_and_its_ultimate_justification.&quot;-105"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConze201371,_Quote:_&quot;Nirvana_is_the_&#39;&#39;raison_d&#39;être&#39;&#39;_of_Buddhism,_and_its_ultimate_justification.&quot;_105-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFConze2013">Conze 2013</a>, p.&#160;71, Quote: "Nirvana is the <i>raison d'être</i> of Buddhism, and its ultimate justification.".</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEChoong199928–29,_Quote:_&quot;Seeing_(&#39;&#39;passati&#39;&#39;)_the_nature_of_things_as_impermanent_leads_to_the_removal_of_the_view_of_self,_and_so_to_the_realisation_of_nirvana.&quot;-110"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChoong199928–29,_Quote:_&quot;Seeing_(&#39;&#39;passati&#39;&#39;)_the_nature_of_things_as_impermanent_leads_to_the_removal_of_the_view_of_self,_and_so_to_the_realisation_of_nirvana.&quot;_110-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFChoong1999">Choong 1999</a>, pp.&#160;28–29, Quote: "Seeing (<i>passati</i>) the nature of things as impermanent leads to the removal of the view of self, and so to the realisation of nirvana.".</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-Leaman2002p23-113"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Leaman2002p23_113-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Oliver Leaman (2002). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=vK-GAgAAQBAJ"><i>Eastern Philosophy: Key Readings</i></a>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-114"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-114">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">[a] <cite class="citation book">Christmas Humphreys (2012). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=V3rYtmCZEIEC"><i>Exploring Buddhism</i></a>. Routledge. pp.&#160;42–43. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-136-22877-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-136-22877-3"><bdi>978-1-136-22877-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Exploring+Buddhism&amp;rft.pages=42-43&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-136-22877-3&amp;rft.au=Christmas+Humphreys&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DV3rYtmCZEIEC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/><br />[b] <cite class="citation book">Brian Morris (2006). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=PguGB_uEQh4C&amp;pg=PA51"><i>Religion and Anthropology: A Critical Introduction</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. p.&#160;51. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-85241-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-85241-8"><bdi>978-0-521-85241-8</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Religion+and+Anthropology%3A+A+Critical+Introduction&amp;rft.pages=51&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-85241-8&amp;rft.au=Brian+Morris&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DPguGB_uEQh4C%26pg%3DPA51&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/>, Quote: "(...) anatta is the doctrine of non-self, and is an extreme empiricist doctrine that holds that the notion of an unchanging permanent self is a fiction and has no reality. According to Buddhist doctrine, the individual person consists of five skandhas or heaps – the body, feelings, perceptions, impulses and consciousness. The belief in a self or soul, over these five skandhas, is illusory and the cause of suffering."<br />[c] Gombrich (2006), p. 47, Quote: "(...) Buddha's teaching that beings have no soul, no abiding essence. This 'no-soul doctrine' (anatta-vada) he expounded in his second sermon."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709-115"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709_115-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709_115-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709_115-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBuswellLopez2003708–709_115-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFBuswellLopez2003">Buswell &amp; Lopez 2003</a>, pp.&#160;708–709.</span>

<li id="cite_note-Merv_Fowler_1999_65-130"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Merv_Fowler_1999_65_130-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Merv_Fowler_1999_65_130-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Merv Fowler (1999). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=A7UKjtA0QDwC"><i>Buddhism: Beliefs and Practices</i></a>. Sussex Academic Press. p.&#160;65. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-898723-66-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-898723-66-0"><bdi>978-1-898723-66-0</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Buddhism%3A+Beliefs+and+Practices&amp;rft.pages=65&amp;rft.pub=Sussex+Academic+Press&amp;rft.date=1999&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-898723-66-0&amp;rft.au=Merv+Fowler&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DA7UKjtA0QDwC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/>, Quote: "For a vast majority of Buddhists in Theravadin countries, however, the order of monks is seen by lay Buddhists as a means of gaining the most merit in the hope of accumulating good karma for a better rebirth."</span>

<li id="cite_note-164"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-164">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Steven Collins (2010). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=d5pshUYiUVwC"><i>Nirvana: Concept, Imagery, Narrative</i></a>. Cambridge University Press. p.&#160;31. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-88198-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-88198-2"><bdi>978-0-521-88198-2</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Nirvana%3A+Concept%2C+Imagery%2C+Narrative&amp;rft.pages=31&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-88198-2&amp;rft.au=Steven+Collins&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dd5pshUYiUVwC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/>, Quote: "This general scheme remained basic to later Hinduism, to Jainism, and to Buddhism. Eternal salvation, to use the Christian term, is not conceived of as world without end; we have already got that, called samsara, the world of rebirth and redeath: that is the problem, not the solution. The ultimate aim is the timeless state of moksha, or as the Buddhists seem to have been the first to call it, nirvana."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-165"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-165">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Steven Collins (1990). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=8sLMkNn26-gC&amp;pg=PA5"><i>Selfless Persons: Imagery and Thought in Theravada Buddhism</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-226"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-226">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Shōhei Ichimura (2001). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=xTW6XNxOxbkC"><i>Buddhist Critical Spirituality: Prajñā and Śūnyatā</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-330"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-330">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Merv Fowler (1999). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=A7UKjtA0QDwC"><i>Buddhism: Beliefs and Practices</i></a>. Sussex Academic Press. pp.&#160;49–52. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-898723-66-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-898723-66-0"><bdi>978-1-898723-66-0</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Buddhism%3A+Beliefs+and+Practices&amp;rft.pages=49-52&amp;rft.pub=Sussex+Academic+Press&amp;rft.date=1999&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-898723-66-0&amp;rft.au=Merv+Fowler&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DA7UKjtA0QDwC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-331"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-331">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Joseph Mitsuo Kitagawa; Frank E. Reynolds; Theodore M. Ludwig (1980). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=p4UeAAAAIAAJ"><i>Transitions and Transformations in the History of Religions: Essays in Honor of Joseph M. Kitagawa</i></a>. Brill Academic. pp.&#160;56–58. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-90-04-06112-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-90-04-06112-5"><bdi>978-90-04-06112-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Transitions+and+Transformations+in+the+History+of+Religions%3A+Essays+in+Honor+of+Joseph+M.+Kitagawa&amp;rft.pages=56-58&amp;rft.pub=Brill+Academic&amp;rft.date=1980&amp;rft.isbn=978-90-04-06112-5&amp;rft.au=Joseph+Mitsuo+Kitagawa&amp;rft.au=Frank+E.+Reynolds&amp;rft.au=Theodore+M.+Ludwig&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dp4UeAAAAIAAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/>, Quote: Suffering describes the condition of samsaric (this worldly) existence that arises from actions generated by <i>ignorance</i> of anatta and anicca. The doctrines of no-self and impermanence are thus the keystones of <i>dhammic</i> order."</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-352"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-352">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/John_Bowker_(theologian)" title="John Bowker (theologian)">John Bowker</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Oxford_Dictionary_of_World_Religions" title="Oxford Dictionary of World Religions">The Oxford Dictionary of World Religions</a></i> (1997), Oxford University Press, <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/><a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-19-213965-7" title="Special:BookSources/0-19-213965-7">0-19-213965-7</a></span>
