<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliams200264,_Quote:_In_the_&#39;&#39;Mahatanhasankhaya_Sutta&#39;&#39;_the_Buddha_&#91;stresses&#93;_that_things_originate_in_dependence_upon_causal_conditioning,_and_this_emphasis_on_causality_describes_the_central_feature_of_Buddhist_ontology._All_elements_of_samsara_exist_in_some_sense_or_another_relative_to_their_causes_and_conditions.-353"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliams200264,_Quote:_In_the_&#39;&#39;Mahatanhasankhaya_Sutta&#39;&#39;_the_Buddha_[stresses]_that_things_originate_in_dependence_upon_causal_conditioning,_and_this_emphasis_on_causality_describes_the_central_feature_of_Buddhist_ontology._All_elements_of_samsara_exist_in_some_sense_or_another_relative_to_their_causes_and_conditions._353-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFWilliams2002">Williams 2002</a>, p.&#160;64, Quote: In the <i>Mahatanhasankhaya Sutta</i> the Buddha [stresses] that things originate in dependence upon causal conditioning, and this emphasis on causality describes the central feature of Buddhist ontology. All elements of samsara exist in some sense or another relative to their causes and conditions..</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-354"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-354">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Robert Neville (2004).  Jeremiah Hackett (ed.). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=kEER8fGxCfMC"><i>Philosophy of Religion for a New Century: Essays in Honor of Eugene Thomas Long</i></a>. Jerald Wallulis. Springer. p.&#160;257. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4020-2073-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4020-2073-5"><bdi>978-1-4020-2073-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Philosophy+of+Religion+for+a+New+Century%3A+Essays+in+Honor+of+Eugene+Thomas+Long&amp;rft.pages=257&amp;rft.pub=Springer&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4020-2073-5&amp;rft.au=Robert+Neville&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DkEER8fGxCfMC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/>, Quote: "[Buddhism's ontological hypotheses] that nothing in reality has its own-being and that all phenomena reduce to the relativities of pratitya samutpada. The Buddhist ontological hypothesese deny that there is any ontologically ultimate object such a God, Brahman, the Dao, or any transcendent creative source or principle."</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201551–66-361"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEmmanuel201551–66_361-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFEmmanuel2015">Emmanuel 2015</a>, pp.&#160;51–66.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey199054,_Quote:_&quot;The_main_concrete_application_of_the_abstract_principle_is_in_the_form_of_a_series_of_conditioned_links_(&#39;&#39;nidanas&#39;&#39;),_culminating_in_the_arising_of_dukkha.&quot;_(...)_&quot;This_&#91;doctrine&#93;_states_the_principle_of_conditionality,_that_all_things,_mental_and_physical,_arise_and_exist_due_to_the_presence_of_certain_conditions,_and_cease_once_their_conditions_are_removed:_nothing_(except_&#39;&#39;Nibbana&#39;&#39;)_is_independent._The_doctrine_thus_compliments_the_teaching_that_no_permanent,_independent_self_can_be_found.&quot;-362"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey199054,_Quote:_&quot;The_main_concrete_application_of_the_abstract_principle_is_in_the_form_of_a_series_of_conditioned_links_(&#39;&#39;nidanas&#39;&#39;),_culminating_in_the_arising_of_dukkha.&quot;_(...)_&quot;This_[doctrine]_states_the_principle_of_conditionality,_that_all_things,_mental_and_physical,_arise_and_exist_due_to_the_presence_of_certain_conditions,_and_cease_once_their_conditions_are_removed:_nothing_(except_&#39;&#39;Nibbana&#39;&#39;)_is_independent._The_doctrine_thus_compliments_the_teaching_that_no_permanent,_independent_self_can_be_found.&quot;_362-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHarvey1990">Harvey 1990</a>, p.&#160;54, Quote: "The main concrete application of the abstract principle is in the form of a series of conditioned links (<i>nidanas</i>), culminating in the arising of dukkha." (...) "This [doctrine] states the principle of conditionality, that all things, mental and physical, arise and exist due to the presence of certain conditions, and cease once their conditions are removed: nothing (except <i>Nibbana</i>) is independent. The doctrine thus compliments the teaching that no permanent, independent self can be found.".</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTELindtner1997324-363"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTELindtner1997324_363-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFLindtner1997">Lindtner 1997</a>, p.&#160;324.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEKochumuttom19991-364"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKochumuttom19991_364-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFKochumuttom1999">Kochumuttom 1999</a>, p.&#160;1.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEKochumuttom19995-365"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKochumuttom19995_365-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFKochumuttom1999">Kochumuttom 1999</a>, p.&#160;5.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEPaul_Williams2008103–109,_161-367"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPaul_Williams2008103–109,_161_367-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFPaul_Williams2008">Paul Williams 2008</a>, pp.&#160;103–109, 161.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEHookham1991100–104-368"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHookham1991100–104_368-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHookham1991">Hookham 1991</a>, pp.&#160;100–104.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEPaul_Williams2008104-369"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPaul_Williams2008104_369-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFPaul_Williams2008">Paul Williams 2008</a>, p.&#160;104.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEPaul_Williams2008107-370"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPaul_Williams2008107_370-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFPaul_Williams2008">Paul Williams 2008</a>, p.&#160;107.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEPaul_Williams2008104–105,_108–109;_Quote:_&quot;...&amp;nbsp;&#91;The_&#39;&#39;Mahaparinirvana_Sutra&#39;&#39;&#93;_refers_to_the_Buddha_using_the_term_&quot;Self&quot;_in_order_to_win_over_non-Buddhist_ascetics.&quot;-372"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPaul_Williams2008104–105,_108–109;_Quote:_&quot;...&amp;nbsp;[The_&#39;&#39;Mahaparinirvana_Sutra&#39;&#39;]_refers_to_the_Buddha_using_the_term_&quot;Self&quot;_in_order_to_win_over_non-Buddhist_ascetics.&quot;_372-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFPaul_Williams2008">Paul Williams 2008</a>, pp.&#160;104–105, 108–109; Quote: "...&#160;[The <i>Mahaparinirvana Sutra</i>] refers to the Buddha using the term "Self" in order to win over non-Buddhist ascetics.".</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-373"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-373">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Merv Fowler (1999). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=A7UKjtA0QDwC"><i>Buddhism: Beliefs and Practices</i></a>. Sussex Academic Press. pp.&#160;101–102. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-898723-66-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-898723-66-0"><bdi>978-1-898723-66-0</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Buddhism%3A+Beliefs+and+Practices&amp;rft.pages=101-102&amp;rft.pub=Sussex+Academic+Press&amp;rft.date=1999&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-898723-66-0&amp;rft.au=Merv+Fowler&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DA7UKjtA0QDwC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/>, Quote: "Some texts of the <i>tathagatagarbha</i> literature, such as the <i>Mahaparinirvana Sutra</i> actually refer to an <i>atman</i>, though other texts are careful to avoid the term. This would be in direct opposition to the general teachings of Buddhism on <i>anatta</i>. Indeed, the distinctions between the general Indian concept of <i>atman</i> and the popular Buddhist concept of Buddha-nature are often blurred to the point that writers consider them to be synonymous."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEPaul_Williams2008112-374"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPaul_Williams2008112_374-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFPaul_Williams2008">Paul Williams 2008</a>, p.&#160;112.</span>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTETrainor2004108–109,_Quote:_&quot;(...)_both_textual_and_archaeological_evidence_shows_that_devotion_has_long_been_a_part_of_Buddhism._The_practice_of_venerating_relics_and_images_has_long_played_a_central_role_even_in_Buddhist_traditions_that_strongly_emphasize_that_Gautama_Buddha_was_a_human_being_(...)&quot;.-380"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTETrainor2004108–109,_Quote:_&quot;(...)_both_textual_and_archaeological_evidence_shows_that_devotion_has_long_been_a_part_of_Buddhism._The_practice_of_venerating_relics_and_images_has_long_played_a_central_role_even_in_Buddhist_traditions_that_strongly_emphasize_that_Gautama_Buddha_was_a_human_being_(...)&quot;._380-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFTrainor2004">Trainor 2004</a>, pp.&#160;108–109, Quote: "(...) both textual and archaeological evidence shows that devotion has long been a part of Buddhism. The practice of venerating relics and images has long played a central role even in Buddhist traditions that strongly emphasize that Gautama Buddha was a human being (...)"..</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Wolter2007p59-381"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Wolter2007p59_381-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Wolter2007p59_381-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Doris Wolter (2007). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=5Rxi-sQr18YC"><i>Losing the Clouds, Gaining the Sky: Buddhism and the Natural Mind</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-390"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-390">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Donald Lopez (2004). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=6Pd-2IIzip4C"><i>Buddhist Scriptures</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-lopez2004busc2-391"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-lopez2004busc2_391-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-lopez2004busc2_391-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Donald Lopez (2004). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=6Pd-2IIzip4C"><i>Buddhist Scriptures</i></a>. State University of New York Press. pp.&#160;17–18. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7914-2844-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7914-2844-3"><bdi>978-0-7914-2844-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Engaged+Buddhism%3A+Buddhist+Liberation+Movements+in+Asia&amp;rft.pages=17-18&amp;rft.pub=State+University+of+New+York+Press&amp;rft.date=1996&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7914-2844-3&amp;rft.au=Christopher+S.+Queen&amp;rft.au=Sallie+B.+King&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D6ZsTgY1lNNsC%26pg%3DPA17&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEGombrich198830–31-429"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGombrich198830–31_429-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFGombrich1988">Gombrich 1988</a>, pp.&#160;30–31.</span>

<li id="cite_note-431"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-431">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Hajime Nakamura (1983). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=asNLliQHDNQC"><i>A History of Early Vedānta Philosophy</i></a>. Motilal Banarsidass. pp.&#160;102–104, 264–269, 294–295. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-208-0651-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-208-0651-1"><bdi>978-81-208-0651-1</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+History+of+Early+Ved%C4%81nta+Philosophy&amp;rft.pages=102-104%2C+264-269%2C+294-295&amp;rft.pub=Motilal+Banarsidass&amp;rft.date=1983&amp;rft.isbn=978-81-208-0651-1&amp;rft.au=Hajime+Nakamura&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DasNLliQHDNQC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/>; Quote: "But the Upanishadic ultimate meaning of the Vedas, was, from the viewpoint of the Vedic canon in general, clearly a new idea.."; p. 95:  The [oldest] Upanishads in particular were part of the Vedic corpus (...) <li id="cite_note-432"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-432">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Klaus G. Witz (1998). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=2jnPlEqwe_UC"><i>The Supreme Wisdom of the Upaniṣads: An Introduction</i></a>. Motilal Banarsidass. pp.&#160;1–2, 23. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-81-208-1573-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-81-208-1573-5"><bdi>978-81-208-1573-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Supreme+Wisdom+of+the+Upani%E1%B9%A3ads%3A+An+Introduction&amp;rft.pages=1-2%2C+23&amp;rft.pub=Motilal+Banarsidass&amp;rft.date=1998&amp;rft.isbn=978-81-208-1573-5&amp;rft.au=Klaus+G.+Witz&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D2jnPlEqwe_UC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/>; Quote: "In the <a href="/wiki/Aranyaka" title="Aranyaka">Aranyakas</a> therefore, thought and inner spiritual awareness started to separate subtler, deeper aspects from the context of ritual performance and myth with which they had been united up to then. This process was then carried further and brought to completion in the <a href="/wiki/Upanishad" class="mw-redirect" title="Upanishad">Upanishads</a>. (...) The knowledge and attainment of the Highest Goal had been there from the Vedic times. But in the Upanishads inner awareness, aided by major intellectual breakthroughs, arrived at a language in which Highest Goal could be dealt with directly, independent of ritual and sacred lore".<br /><cite class="citation book">Edward Fitzpatrick Crangle (1994). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=HOzdcIxJy2sC"><i>The Origin and Development of Early Indian Contemplative Practices</i></a>. </li>

<li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEVetter19885,_Quote:_&#91;T&#93;hey_do_not_teach_that_one_is_released_by_knowing_the_four_noble_truths,_but_by_practising_the_fourth_noble_truth,_the_eightfold_path,_which_culminates_in_right_samadhi-486"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVetter19885,_Quote:_[T]hey_do_not_teach_that_one_is_released_by_knowing_the_four_noble_truths,_but_by_practising_the_fourth_noble_truth,_the_eightfold_path,_which_culminates_in_right_samadhi_486-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFVetter1988">Vetter 1988</a>, p.&#160;5, Quote: [T]hey do not teach that one is released by knowing the four noble truths, but by practising the fourth noble truth, the eightfold path, which culminates in right samadhi.</span>

<li id="cite_note-633"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-633">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Rory Mackenzie (2007). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Or99AgAAQBAJ"><i>New Buddhist Movements in Thailand: Towards an Understanding of Wat Phra Dhammakaya and Santi Asoke</i></a>. Routledge. pp.&#160;175–179. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-134-13262-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-134-13262-1"><bdi>978-1-134-13262-1</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=New+Buddhist+Movements+in+Thailand%3A+Towards+an+Understanding+of+Wat+Phra+Dhammakaya+and+Santi+Asoke&amp;rft.pages=175-179&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-134-13262-1&amp;rft.au=Rory+Mackenzie&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DOr99AgAAQBAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ABuddhism" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-ArenaAtlas2012-642"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ArenaAtlas2012_642-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://docviewer.yandex.com/view/0/?*=rvAv5PGTc%2Fw%2BBFV6QOUZtaf5gYF7InVybCI6InlhLWRpc2stcHVibGljOi8vMWV1aDl5RDFpcnZKeVZNNSswWWFaZktqRFhoOXZDNWhldUlGTU5uQU4zQT0iLCJ0aXRsZSI6IlNyZWRhX2Jsb2tfcHJlc3Nfc20yLnBkZiIsInVpZCI6IjAiLCJub2lmcmFtZSI6ZmFsc2UsInRzIjoxNTI0NDg3NTUzMTcwfQ%3D%3D&amp;page=1">"Арена: Атлас религий и национальностей"</a> &#91;Arena: Atlas of Religions and Nationalities&#93; <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. </div></td></tr></tbody></table></div>
